title: L01E03 Group vs. Team (SS22)

submissions.text:
A team is a group of people who are strongly connected and work together on a specific goal which requires coordination or teamwork in some way. On the other side there is a group who are loosely connected and where every one is work on a project on his own.

An example for a team would be any of the team sports where a group of people is working to achieve a goal such as winning a tournament or ranking up in the sports team. It is most likely coached and the bonds in the Team are strong.

On the other hand an example for a group could be any kind of weight lifting where a set group is working on its own to achieve a set goal sometimes tought by a coach but often alone with theire Friends.

Group is an enity of various people united by a higher purpose. The members of a group do not necessarly know each other. For example the enity of students are united by the purpose of listen to a lecture.
Team is an enity of various people who work togehter for more than just one reason. The members of a team work on the same activity or have a shared goal. For example the members of a scrum team.

Team: Bewältigt gemeinsam eine Aufgabe und spricht sich mit den anderen Teampartnern ab. Die Personen kennen sich untereinander.

Gruppe: Eine Gruppe von Leuten kann in gemeinsam in einen Raum sein. Es kann jedoch sein, dass sich die Personen untereinander nicht kennen.

While both are terms for a number of people, the differences lie in:
	- The reason the members are connected
	- The goal of the individual people

In a group, the people are together due to outer circumstances, for instance being in the same room. Their goals are not aligned, therefore everyone has a own goal which is being pursued on it's own.

A team on the other hand, is defined by people being together due to choice, and having the same goal that can only be accomplished by each team member participating and working together to achieve the goal.
So it's a group of people working together for an aligned goal.

Group is a number of people, that communicate and coordinate with each other and also have something in common but dont have a commone purpose. So everyone is working on his own.
Team is a number of people, who are strongly connected to each other and have a commone purpose. So they trust each other and work together to achieve their goal.
For example on the exam we are a group of students that pass the same exam at the same time so we meet and talk to each other but during the exam each one should work on his own. However at work we have to achieve a specific project. That means all the members of the team have to work toghether and trust each other to get the job done.

Group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another
Team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal

difference: 1. Team has one or more leader, while group has no leader.
                  2. The departure of a team member can have a significant influence on the achievement of overall goals, while the departure of a team member does not have as much of an impact.

a group is a collection of individualls, who are technikly able to work together but who are not able to use their individuall abilities to their fullest potetion by helping each other. a team on the other hand works together and puts their streinghts together, to make the best out of their individuell abilities.
//2 beispiele noch machen lol

Group is just a number of people who have loose relationship to one another. They do not focus on specific outcomes or a common goal and everyone works independently. For example, the students who participate in the lecture EIST are loosely connected to one another, and do not necessarily have the same goal, as some might aim at passing the exam, while the others might want to achieve good grades. Students can also work on their own instead of working together.

Team is a group of people who are strongly connected with one another, have a common goal, work together and coordinate the activities. The example can be a soccer team in which 11 people must work together and cooperate with one another to achieve the common goal, winning the play. Independent working is not possible in the soccer team and cannot help achieve the goal.

Both groups and teams have in common that some people are connected in some way. While
groups are limited to the definition of a bunch of people, teams often have a goal that they are trying to
to achieve. This is why people often talk about sports teams or teams at work. Teams want to achieve something together. 
For instance you speak may call you and your friends a group of friends. Your are a bunch of people maybe strong or loose connected, but you don't have one special goal. Maybe your team wants to winn the paintball-game or goes together on Mountains, but that is not the main focus, the reason why you interact with the other people.
In contrast, a team is often very strong connected. For example a basketball-team. They have the same goal to win game and they have one specific relationship, the sport. They have to work together to achieve their goals.

A group consists of several people that have some kind of connection, whereas a team can be seen as a group that tries to achieve common objective.
For example, you can divide a class into groups of students by their year of birth. The students of these groups are connected but don't represent a team if they don’t have a common goal.
Even if they work on the same objective stated by the teacher, you can’t consider them as a team as long as they don’t work together and coordinate their tasks.

A group is a "collection of people", who are associated together because they are in similar setting or situation. They might not (although not necessarily) know each other and each person might be working on his individual goals. Two examples for groups are a group of students attending a lecture or a group of  athletes (individual sports like swimming) who train together.

A team on the other hand do have a common goal towards which they are working to fulfill. They depend on each others and help each others out (by delegating tasks, communicating effectively, etc.) in order to achieve their common goal. These people might know each other and/or know each other in the process of working together. They can become friends and communicate even after the goal has been achieved. Examples of teams are like a team working on a student project working to finish their project effectively or an athletic team (group sports like basketball or football) working together to win a single match or getting the medal.

A Group is just a collection of a few/ many persons, who are connected on a not emotionally (formal) way.
They don't have a common aim or the same passion.
A really nice example is sports:
While it's nessesarly to go together on a golf "flight" (group of mostly four persons who play together 18 holes) all player play on their one and count their points one their one. They don't have a goal they want to reach together and neither split up parts of the game. Soccer on the other hand is played in teams. All players are emotionally connected together and they all define a common aim. They will win or lose a game always together and all players are a part of the team and the game even if someone doesn't even took place in the game.
They also of course split the tasks; defense/offense and so on.
Another example is developing a software:
There are basically two ways:
First one is when all developers of a specific part of a company(group) just do their job and just develop/fix some tickets from a kanban board for example.
They just do that to not lose their job and to get money.
The other, much better way is the way when a team is communicating and helping on problems as well as control the code after completing a part of code. They have the aim to develop the best possible software.

Say a game requires 4 people to form a team in order to achieve a certain goal.
But a group of 4 people can be just a group with no goal or purpose.

Similarly, 2 people can form a team to participate in a men's double or women's double in a sport game, 
whereas we can randomly form a group of 2 just to distribute the classmates in a classroom.

Groups are loosely connected people without concrete plans or aims. They do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose. For example a group of runners has some loose connections to another, but they run their races on their own and for their own success. 

Teams have been going through a building process with building, storming, norming and performing. A team focusses on a specific aim and works well thought and planned to reach it. For example in a football team players shouldn't only work for themselves, but for the success of the team.

A group consists of a certain number of people which do not have a real tight relationship to one another, therefore the members aren't well connected, nor do they focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose.
Every single member works on their own.

In a team however the members have a way stronger relationship to one another which leads to a stronger connection in the team itself. Therefore they focus on a specific outcome which requires coordination of tasks and activities. 

In a project a group would simply divide all tasks for each member so they can work on each task by themselves. In a team however they'll work on each task together, help each other out as each member has his own special abilities.

A group is the preliminary stage for a team. In a group everyone do what they want. They are not working together and maybe not even communicating. But in a team they are like a family. They are communicating and also exchanging their work. The members in a team have the same goals and they are working together to achieve those goals. For example a group is working on a project, but everyone works for himself and in a team they are helping each other or even work together on the same task. Another example is that the members of a group don't even know each other but the members of a team are like friends.

Several people form a group. They are somehow connected but don't work on one specific project and don't have a common goal. An example would be the students of EIST or the residents of a dormitory. In contrast the members of a team work towards a certain goal like a sportsteam trying to win or a group of people in a company working on a project.

1) Team members work together to make a common task more efficient and faster.

A few builders will be able to make a much better building than individual builders. Each builder on the team has their own strengths and is best at doing a certain part of the job, such as painting the walls.

Each builder from the group builds his own individual building. Since every builder has strengths and weaknesses, some part of the building will have flaws. While the individual builder builds his building, the team will build several buildings (or one building, but much larger).

2) Good communication is an important part of teamwork.

Each builder from the team must build according to the general plan, and also listen to the instructions of the foreman (Chief Engineer). Thus, everyone will know at what stage the construction is to prevent bad incidents.

Communication between builders from the group is very weak. Since everyone is doing their own small project, they can only share what success (or unsuccess) they have achieved so far.

The difference between a group an a team is that in a group for example the members may only be friends or they don't even have to know each other very good. They may not event work together at a project of any form (and if they work together it isn't guaranteed that it will work out). For instance, the important part in a team is that all members work together on one or more projects and complete each other in their strength and weaknesses. 

A group for example, are friends playing a party-game at a birthday party.

A team for example, is a Formula 1 TEAM. Which you can divide in to different parts again but they all work for one specific goal. To win.

Team and Group are terms often used wrongly simultaneously but actually differ in on what the work/efforts as well as relationship builds on. 
1. Common goal vs. no common goal
For example, in a team the members share a common goal which achievement they are all working towards together collectively. On the other hand in a simple group this common purpose is missing and therefore the members work on their own, just "next to each other". A good soccer team has to be, as the word says, a team - otherwise it could never win a championship. Therefore the effort would be collective working towards the goal. Lets on the other hand suppose that in a project group members all had their own personal goal where the different goals might even be partly exclusive, then the people would not work towards this goal together in a shared effort out of belief but only separately on their own. Some members might even have information that would be crucial for another member but due to the lack of sharing of information this would not come through resulting in problems and/or time loss.
2. Strength of relationship between members
Moreover a second example is the kind of relationship the members have. In the case of a group there of course is some relationship, but it is only loose and therefore the members are independent and might not even trust each other. In a team on the other hand the relationship is strong and profound resulting in interdependence in a positive way. For example if there is a team in a company they usually split up the different tasks because they trust each other’s capabilities and can therefore work efficiently. If these people on the other hand were acting like a group, this trust would not be there and it could even be that the different members would try to do everything on their own without sharing important information.

A Group contains a number of people which are loosely connected to each other and don't have a common goal/purpose which all follow. The individuals do not work together. 

A Team is a group of people who all follow a common goal which requires the members to coordinate the task/activities and work together. This implies that they are strongly connected or fail if not so.

A football team needs to work together to get the ball into the goal because they are facing a common enemy. Therefore they are coordinate the tasks. Fore example the goalkeeper is defending the goal with other players while they rest of the team tries to get a goal and they apply strategies which the coach formed before the game. A good team works perfectly together and achieve their goal.

A example for a group are the students in this lecture. They have a some relationship with each other they all want to pass the exam. But they are not working together the exam cannot be solved in a team. They are not focusing  a specific outcome one wants to pass it with a 2,0 another with 3,9.

Group: A group is a unified collection of people that are connected in some sense but without a specific goal that they want to achieve by working together. Each member in the group is there for an individual purpose to achieve his goals. 

Example: People joining  a course to study for their driver license. They are a group of people learning the basic rules of driving together but each individual needs to pass his or her exam at the end which is an individual goal. 

Team: A team is a collection of people based on a specific goal or outcome. Each individual contributes to the end result which results in an overall achievement for the team. Everyone is working together to achieve that goal and contributes towards it.  A team requires good communication and exchange within the collection of people. 

Example: A team of Formula 1 engineers working together to make the perfect race car. Each individual contributes their knowledge towards making the best race car possible to achieve victory together.

In sports:
If you look at the Tour de Frace, for example, you will notice that there is usually a leading group and several groups of chasers behind it. Both groups, in turn, stagger themselves so that they ride as efficiently as possible, in the sense that they take advantage of the slipstream. In this aspect, they pursue a common goal. However, when it comes to victory, everyone fights for themselves. A rowing team, on the other hand, must fight together from the beginning to the end in a rhythm with one goal in order to ultimately emerge as the winner.

From the school area,
when it came to group work, each group was given a main topic and each member of the group was graded individually. Therefore, everyone focuses on being able to communicate their sub-topic as well as possible. At the same time, the work was not done as a team. On the other hand, an assignment in which the "group", in this case the team, receives a uniform grade, requires active cooperation in order to ultimately receive the best grade together.

Group - an undefined amount of people, who might or might not possess common attributes (interests, ideas, views e.t.c.), but definitely do not possess common purposes and do not work for together to achieve a specific outcome.

Team - an undefined amount of people, who definitely possess common ideas and interests and who work together to achieve a specific outcome in a most efficient way.


Example: 

In the beginning of the EIST lecture the students are a group of people who have common interests and views (complete the course successfully for example), but do not communicate and do not work together to achieve a specific outcome. BUT after the lecturer's request to do the "stadium wave", the students have now become a team who communicate and adjust to each other to achieve a specific outcome, which in this case an ideal "stadium wave". :)

A team is always more than a group. A group are just some people having one or more similar characteristics or interests. For example some tourist listening to a city guide. They do not know each, but have in that moment the same aim, listen to the tour guide. And they won't interact with each other. They are not a team.
Because a team has like a group one or more things in common but they have a connection to each other. They are connecting, interacting and exchanging their similiraity, most often a same goal, like finishing a project. 
Another clear difference between groups and teams is given in sports. A handful of girls playing volleyball. Classicly, we expect a team willing to win a competition or just even practice hard, consequently, together. Anyway, at school sports this looks quiet different. Some girls are standing in the playing field, the volleyball is flying over the net to their side and noone moves. Noone is speaking, everybody is disappointed that the ball drops the ground and the next round starts. These girls are no team at all. They are just a group having sports lesson.

team members have a common goal to solve a specific problem, they unite their best competencies.
group is a couple of individual that coordinate in a task to complete.

A group is set of people connected in any way to each other.
A team on the other hand is interactive, stronger connected and shares the same goal.

For example in a company software can be written by teams.
If groups would try to write code together it could end in a mess because they communicate not enough and cannot trust each other to write good or the right code.

A group merely is a number of people that have a relationship with one another. They do not have a shared vision in common nor do they work on the same goals and hope for the same outcomes. A group of students can be used as a good example, as they all have a form of connection between each other in form of their studies, but they basically all work on their own in order to fullfill their goal of successfully accomplishing their courses.

A team on the other hand is a group, where all members have the same goals and work together in order to accomplish those goals. They have stronger connections with one another than a group has.
A great example of a team is a soccer team, in which all members play together in order to fullfill the mutual goal of winning the game.

Example number one: 
In a video game like Valorant, casual players who join a random team form a group. Everyone works on their own and has different expectations. Communication is usually poor, which reduces efficiency. They choose characters of their personal preferences without considering whether they will work as a team. In contrast, a valorant team, usually found in e-stores, works together perfectly and efficiently. The coordination, movement and rotation between different points works perfectly.  Communication and a balanced mix of characters have been formed in countless hours of intensive training. They all have only one goal, to win the game.

Example number two:
On a basketball court, a group of people wants to play a game together, they form two teams and start playing. Since they have never played together before, they don't know each other's strengths. They play mostly alone and make few passes and many mistakes. Again, the group works together very inefficiently. Whereas a professional team knows exactly the strengths of each player, they all have a fixed position and share tasks. Unlike the group, the team trusts each other and they have trained and optimized strategies to hit the basket.

For example a group of people are students who are loosely connected and are studying by themselves the same specialty and a team are programmers who work together with a common goal like developing a software system.

A group is a collection of people who only have one thing in common, for example being in the same place, but aren`t connected with each other or share any goals. They don't work together.
Teams are different because a team is a group of people who have a common interest work together to achieve it. They make decisions together, split the work into tasks and help each other.

A group is for example the people who are hanging out at a beach, they don't necessarily know each other, have common interests (besides spending time at the beach) or work together on something.
A team would be a group of people on a beach who build a sandcastle together. They have a common goal of building the castle and have to be familiar with each other e.g. to know the others skills or ideas of the castle. They communicate and come to agreements like what the castle should look like and who should do the different parts of the work.

- Group is a term to show that a bunch of people are (barely) connected
   eg: - bachelor students of TUM
	 - employees of a multinational company
- Team refers to a bunch of people which shares the same vision and goal and cooperate with each other in order 			 
   to reach that goal
   eg: - employees working together on a certain project 
	 - a group of thieves working together to steal a picture from a museum

In a group the participants have a rather loose relationship to one another.  While members of a group don't focus on specifc outcomes/purpose or work with each other, members of a team do focus on a specific outcome. In a team tasks and activities are coordinated and hence everybody works hand in hand. 

A good example for a team is a soccer team. Everybody has its own role during a soccer game, but in order to score goals or play a good defense (which is the goal of the whole team), everybody has to work with one another which requires coordination both during the game and beforehand during training. 
A travel group is a good example for a group. While everybody visits the same places and probably sleeps in the same hotels, not everybody knows everybody and thus not everybdoy works with one another. Furthermore, they may be different purposes for the journey - one may want to spend time with his family, another wants to get to know a new culture.

A group is a collection of individuals, each of whom has a different goal. Such a group does not have strong connections (e.g., a group of students in a lecture who are mostly alone responsible for accomplishing their goals).

A group of individuals can form a team if the group is working towards a common goal and the team is jointly responsible for the success or failure (e.g. a student project group working on a project for a longer period of time which is jointly evaluated).

Whereas the term "group" refers generally to a number of people who are just connected due to external circumstances without a specific purpose, a team is actively pursuing a common goal. 
A group could for example be a group of students who are taking the same course in university, but are working individually working on their assignments. All students are pursuing the same goal on their own, but there is no interaction between the students, the group is not pursuing a common goal. All students can eventually also pursue different individual goals. One student can for example aim for the best possible grade, whereas other students just want to pass the final exam. 
The pure assignment to a group also does not require additional efforts from the students. 

A team is pursuing a common goal, which requires coordinated efforts of the team members, in order to achieve this common goal. 
If assignments in this respective university course are assigned to sub-groups of people, who should try to work on these assignments together, these sub-groups of people can therefore be called "teams". In order to achieve the common purpose of successfully completing the individual assignment (= project) a higher level of interaction between the team members and a coordination of the different tasks (sub-tasks of the common project) is required. 
Due to their assignment to a certain team, additional effort is required from the team members. As a team is working together on a common goal, the team has to invest effort into building good inter-personal relationships so that efficient collaborative working is possible.

"Team" is any group of people who are involved in the same activity having a common goal, whereas "Group" is simply a number of people who relate to each other.

Example 1:
If you are in a tennis club where you freely join and enjoy playing together, I would say the tennis club is a "group." However, once you aim to win a regional tournament together with other members and start a series of organized practices to improve the performance together, now it is a "team."

Example 2:
Emily and Ben are colleagues at a company. They greet each other and have a chat sometimes, but they don't really work together. They belong to the same "group." One day, they are assigned to the same project by their boss to develop software for one of their customers. Now they are involved same activity towards a goal, and they are a "team."

A group can be described as a number of people thrown together by chance, that usually hardly share any  interests or relationships with one another. Given their different goals they do not focus on one common objective, but are working individually for their own gain.

On a Team however anybody involved is working on the same task and on a common objective, what further binds them together. As a result the tasks need to be well coordinated in order for the members to work together effectively and in close cooperation,  all while focusing on the common goal.

Participants of a group have some things in common with each other, but not much. They do not focus on the same goal and don't really work together, like students in a lecture hall or people who have met at a job interview.

In a team all people work together towards a common goal. These people need to work together to achieve this goal, or else it might (or will) fail. They all want the same result, namely the good outcome of their goal. Examples are software engineers at Google that work on Chrome or players in a hockey team.

A group is a loose collection of individuals.

A team consists of members working towards a common goal.

Group:
A Group is a number of people that have some kind of relationship to one another, but they do not focus on a specific task or outcome.

Team: 
A Team is a group of people, who are involved in the same activity and task (for example work or sport). They need to work together in order to get a specific outcome.  

Example: 
A Group is for example the Family, because the do not focus on the same specific outcome and task, and every Family Member (more or less) works on his own. 
A Team on the other hand is for example the management of the EIST lecture: They need to work together in order to achieve their goal (for example: Teaching etc.).

A group contains of a number of people who stand in a relationship to each other. The relationship is quite loosely and they do not focus on a common purpose. However, every person works on his or her own. An example for a group are the students who are enrolled in EIST this semester and visited the lecture on campus today. Every students works on his or her own to pass the course. 

A team on the other side is a group of people who have a close relationship to each other and have a common goal and purpose on which they focus on. The connection between each person of the team is close and they have to work together in order to achieve their common goal. An example of a team is a football team. Their common goal is to win a game. To achieve this goal, they have to work together and  pass the ball to each other to be able to win because one person alone could never reach the goal.

A group is a number of people who have some connection with each other. An example could be a friendship circle. Friends have some individual connections but - in general - they do not share common goals or a common purpose. Beside some support, they do not work together on professional/private goals. Everybody has his own career, family, etc.

A team on the other hand is a number of people who share all these aspects: strong connection (dependence) and a common goal/purpose. Team members relay on each other to achieve these goals. An example could be a football team. The common goal is to win the match. But none of the players can do it alone. They have to play together to win the game.

A group consists of a number of people that have very little in common and these people are likely to each follow their own goals. 
E.g., students in a tutor group - they are all attending the same tutor group and have similar goals (understanding the topic) but still, they work on their own in pursuit of achieving this goal. In contrast to that, a team would most likely support each other (one might understand a topic a lot better and help his teammate) so that the average grade of the participants in this tutor group would probably be better

In difference to that teams work together on achieving a common goal. If they are not connected, they are most likely to get to know each other better, to improve their overall performance as a team, since they all aim for the best possible outcome. They work together and coordinate the tasks among each other (Make use of each individual's strenghts and weaknesses)

E.g., a football team - they need to work together to beat the opponents. Although all of them are good players, with coordination of the strengths and weaknesses (one might be a good offense and an exceptional defense) they can achieve a better outcome in total. This would not work if they would each play for themself.

A group is a collection of entities which are loosely connected but do not work or depend on one another, like a group of friends or students at our university.
A team is a collection of people who share a common goal, work together and depend on one another. A good example of a team could be a sports team, like in soccer.

A group, such as a friendship circle, consists of people with some loose connections to one another. Groups do not work to achieve a common goal and the members of the group work independently. For example, friends in a friendship group are independent individuals who care about their own goals and are only accountable to themselves.

A team, such as the management team in a company, consists of people with strong connections to one another. Teams work together collectively to accomplish a particular shared goal by coordinating on the things that need to be done. For example, the management team in a company work closely together to achieve the collective goals of the company e.g. increasing value for shareholders. The team members are interdependent and are accountable to one another.

A group consists of different people, which have some relationship and are only loosely connected. They don't have however a shared vision or goal for working together. A team on the other hand consists of people that do share a common goal or vision and thus have reason working together. They are strongly connected.

One example to highlight the difference could be a group of football fans and a football team. 
The fan group have a similar interest and are therefor in a relationship together. They like to go to matches and may even meet and discuss them. But they don't share a strong vision and don't work together for something other than enjoying the matches.

The football team has a very strong common goal, to win matches and improve their ranking. They will spend a lot of time together, get to know each other well and working together on the same goal. 

A second example would be a group of Computer Science students and a Software Developer Team.
The students have some relationship. They see each other, talk to each other and maybe even solve some exercises together. But in the end everyone writes there own exams and often they even compete between themselves. 

The team has with their project a common goal and they work together solving it step by step. They depend on each other and have to cooperate. 

In both examples we can see the differences very clearly. The teams spend a lot of time with their team members and have to work together. Groups on the other side don't have to work together and if they do, it is not vital. In general people in groups will work a lot of the time on their own rather than with others of the group.

Groups and Teams can be distinguished via three dimensions: connection, goal, and work-routine.
Groups are loosely connected, have no specific common goal and work on their own.
An example for a group might be people riding the same elevator.
They are connected by the riding the same elevator. Everyone has there own destination in mind (no common goal) and minds there own business ("work on their own").


On the other hand, teams are strongly connected, have a specific common goal and work together.
An example for a team might be any kind of sports team.
Teams are strongly connected, even represented by their jersey. They have a common goal (usually winning). Finally, they work together (eg. pass the ball in football) to achieve that common goal.

Group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another.
Team: any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work

Example 
1. Students who attend the same tutor class are a group. Those students only attend a class at the specific time. They don't even know each other and they are loosely connected. Some attend the class to be able to get the bonus. Some aim to pass the exam.  Maybe some of them only want to meet some friends. They do not focus on a specific goal. And most of time they only listen to the tutor and figure out a problem alone. 
2. Several students who work together to develop a website within a specific period are a team. They have a clear goal which is to develop a website that people can use with as few bugs as possible. To be able to achieve it, they have to coordinate with each other. Some students are responsible for designing and front end development. Some are in charge of  back end development. They also have to communicate with each other really often to make sure every part works well and they are approaching the goal gradually.

Groups are a relatively large amount of people who are somewhat related to another in a team there is a relatively large group who is connected by the same activity or goal.
Groups have a low/loose connection where as a team is actually build to have a strong connection.
A group is assigned for a task and it is not relevant of its outcome where a team is strongly focused on the outcome of the targeted task for example a team needs a specific outcome so the customer is satisfied with the product.
The last point is that members of a group are mostly working on their own where a team is only able to work if the team members are working together because every task is dependent on every member for example your task can only be finished if you get the base implementation of your other team members.

The members of a group are loosely connected where as the participants of a team are strongly connected. A team works closely together to achieve a goal. Example of  a group  :   A ​learning interest Group .

Example 1:
The spectators at a soccer game (Kreisliga) are a group, while the players playing the game are a team. The players have to work together to win the game and are therefore dependent on each other. They have the same goal in mind and are therefore very strongly connected to each other. The spectators are only loosely connected because while they all have something in common (namely enjoying to watch the game) there is no need for them to work together because they do not have a common goal.

Example 2:
A person and their children are a group while a person and their spouse are a team. Between a person and their kids there is usually conflicting interests. The children often have some vision of the future in their mind that is very different from what their parents want them to be. They are related to each other namely by living in the same house etc. but don't work towards the same things so they are not a team. A person and their spouse on the other hand have to work together very closely by managing their finances, living situation etc. They need to negotiate and balance both their visions of their future and need to try to align their goals to work together effectively.

-Group: is a number of people, every individual works on his own. The members are interdependent.
-Team: is a group of people having a common goal to achieve. They are strongly connected, they work, discuss and decide together. (Collective Work)

A group is a number of people that have some form of relationship to one another. A team are a group that are working towards a common goal, involved in the same activity.

First Example:
A group can be a Whatsapp group chat for EIST, the relationship to the 256 other people is simply the fact that we all are in the EIST course. We might have different goals. Some students want to pass the course with a 1.0 while others simply want to pass; some would like to give 100% in the project to receive full bonus points while others decide to not do the project. We are also all working for our own grade. Therefore the people in this group chat cannot be considered a team. 

Second Example:
A team can be a soccer team. The team players all have the same goal of winning against the opposing team and are all doing the same activity of playing football. They must all coordinate with one another and communicate well to win against the opposing team. Therefore a soccer team can be considered a team.

Grundsätzlich unterscheidet sich ein Team von einer Gruppe, indem ein klares Ziel verfolgt oder eine definierte Aufgabe bearbeitet wird. Insbesondere durch die Festlegung eines gewünschten, gemeinsamen Endzustandes wird beim Team die individuelle Leistung in den Hintergrund gerückt. Ebenso sollte darauf geachtet werden, dass das Team vor Bearbeitung der Aufgabe eine vom Projekt unabhängige Team-Aktivität nachgeht. Diese Form des Teambuildings sorgt dafür, dass die Teammitglieder schon im Vorhinein Vertrauen zu den restlichen Mitgliedern aufbauen können.
Im Gegensatz dazu kennzeichnet sich eine Gruppe dadurch aus, dass diese untereinander keine Arbeitsbeziehung aufbauen konnten. Durch das instinktive Misstrauen gegenüber Personen, mit denen man noch keine Erfahrungen sammeln konnte, sorgt dafür, dass individuelle Wege eingeschlagen werden. Dies führt zu einem wesentlichen schlechteren Informationsfluss, was zumeist das Projekt langfristig schädigt. Beispielsweise werden Teilaufgaben doppelt erledigt, oder sogar ganz darauf verzichtet, da es klar war, wer dafür zuständig war.  

Beispiel Team: OP-Personal im Klinikum
Durch Schulungen oder Teambuilding-Aktivitäten kann aus dem qualifizierten Personal ein gemeinsames Team geschaffen werden. Aufgrund der klaren Aufgabe, z.B.  Operation eines Herzschrittmachers, welcher ein bestimmtes Krankheitsbild therapiert, und dem vorherigen Briefing des Teams über den Verlauf der Operation, wird sichergestellt, dass jeder einzelne seine Aufgabe kennt und auch das große Ganze im Auge hat.
+ Ziel und Vorgehen genau definiert
+ Einzelleistung rückt weit in den Hintergrund. Therapie des Patienten ist das gemeinsame Ziel des Teams
+ Personal vertraut und stark verbunden

Beispiel Group: Politik-Komitee
Aufgrund eines kurzfristiges Ereignis (lokaler Katastrophenfall) sollte Politiker-Komitee gebildet werden. Damit jede Partei sich einbringen kann, darf jede Partei genau ein Mitglied einbringen.
Da jedes Mitglied dieser Gruppe mit den anderen Mitgliedern der anderen Parteien keine positive Arbeitsbeziehung besitzt und jede Partei eine andere Ideologie besitzt, sind Einzelleistungen schon vorprogrammiert. Ebenso priorisiert jede Partei bestimme Lösungsmöglichkeiten anders, wodurch kein Konsens gebildet werden kann. 
- Lösung erarbeitet jedes Mitglied individuell
- Durch Eigenleistungen wird versucht die eigene Partei in ein gutes Licht zu rücken
- Die Mitglieder haben zumeist kein gutes Verhältnis miteinander.

A Group is a number of people with any kind of relationship to each other, but do not work together on something. 
In contrast to that, a team is a group of people who work together on achieving a specific goal. 

An example of a group can be found with the people in a language course. They each work individually on their own goal to learn a new language, but not on an outcome for the whole group.

An example of a team is a basketball team, where individual players work together to win a game as the desired outcome. There is a strong connection between the players, but they still need to be coordinated and each one has their own position on the field.

An example of a team is a sports team (football, volleyball, rugby), because it consists of  players who each contribute toward the goal of winning a game.

Additionally a team has members that trust each others and can rely on one another. In a group are people that just have a connection but that connection is not strong or deep.

Groups are generally oriented towards efficient development, however its members mostly operate individually with their own goals. On the other hand, the idea of a team is to have its members work side by side towards a common goal, mutually aiding each other and thus also helping the team as a whole to achieve a shared objective.

On the other hand members of a team work towards a common goal. They are in constant exchange and need to trust each other to achieve their common goal.

group: In a tennis tournament (where you play 1v1) all players together are a group. The group is called memebers of the tennis tournament. They are loosely connected and work on their own. Everyone has their own goal and they do only care about themselves.

team: A soccer team for instance. All 11 players ( and also the players on the bench) have the same goal. They try to win the game. Group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another
• Participants are loosely connected
• Do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose
• Every individual works on his own

Team: any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal,
especially referring to sports and work
• Participants are strongly connected
• Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities
• Members need to work together

For example, there are students in the class for language learning.
[Group]
The professor asks the students to form "groups" to talk to each other for practice.
The connection of this kind of "group" is quite loose.
[Team]
But if the groups are required to do a research of different language, and need to do a presentation in the end.
The members in a group have to allocate themselves for different jobs in order to finish this research. Someone may good at coding, someone may good at modeling etc. They need to work together, and focus on a specific outcome. Then the groups becomes a "team".

Consider the EIST Course as this example's environment. 

Firstly, using the group definition, we identify the Students attending the course as multiple individuals with some relationship with each other, this relationship can be categorized in form of a "common learner/ or colleague". Nonetheless, a lack of a common goal exists. One can argue that the common goal is to pass the course, however, this goal is individual as each student has to work independently from the remaining students to pass the module. Here is where one important difference between Group & Team takes place, as in a team we observe again a number of people coming together in the same activity but with a shared goal in contrast to a group. 

Secondly, for example, the EIST Tutors can be considered a Team as it is bounded by the common goal of hosting a successful EIST course where they strive together to provide the best learning experience possible for students, thus having a specific outcome and a concrete set of activities that should be fulfilled to reach the outcome (e.g. correct and plan exercises, make sure questions are answered, recording work, etc .... ) and shared across all tutor participants (which of course don't do the exact same tasks, implying that coordination between tasks occurs within the tutors, e.g. some correct homework while other give tutor lectures etc ...).

To sum up, within the EIST Course environment we observe how Students can be classified as a Group and Tutors as a Team as they differ mainly in (1) the existence of a shared/common specific objective which Groups don't have while Teams do; (2) the necessity to work together with present in Teams and not in Groups; (3) and the type of connection between undertakings, which is in groups loose while in teams strong.

groups are people who have been allocated or joined together due to random factors. A group can only be considered a team if that group of people approach the same activity with a common goal and objective. There is trust between each participant of the group, resulting in better coordination of tasks and activity. Improving overall Efficiency.

In my opinion the difference between GROUP and TEAM is：
First of all, we can look at it from the point of view of time. 
Group is like a team that is put together because of a temporary event. Whereas a team is an interdependent team that has been working towards the same goal for a long period of time. 
Secondly, we can analyze the relationship between members. In a group, each person is independent and each group has only one leader. But in a team, there can be several leaders, who are responsible for different aspects in detail. The relationship between each member is inseparable and interdependent.

Two Examples:
1.For example, if a group achieves good results, the group leader may receive extra praise and attention. But for the TEAM, having achieved good results, everyone will receive the same praise.

2.We can also understand this with the example of a meeting. For example, a group is like a leader talking about a bunch of his ideas and goals, and people below him burying their heads in notes. A team, on the other hand, is a meeting where the junior staff speaks first, then the sub-leader summarizes the statement, and finally the largest leader listens to all the speakers and proposes a collective goal.

Group:

A design company has 70 different employees, working on 70 distinct projects - 1 project per person.

Team:

5 designers collaborate to modernize the web-design of a law firm. 

The main differentiator here is: in the second example, people involved with the project have a common goal and therefore try to enforce the highest efficiency when working (by helping each other).

In the first example, we do have a group of people. But if someone in this group would fail, it would not affect any other person within that group, but him/herself. In a team, people could cover for such cases which could save the outcome of the project.

A team on the other hand works like an organism.

But most importantly they aid each other achieving their goal.

1. A group could be all the people in a shopping centre, they do not have a common purpose/goal, are loosely connected and do not care for other's objectives, only on their own. Some may just be there to browse, some could be there to meet a friend, some could be doing quick grocery shopping and rushing home.
However, a team here could be a group of friends throwing a big party, with a shopping list for everyone to buy supplies (eg. drinks, cups, food, balloons etc.), all members of this "group" have a common objective (buying all the supplies), are strongly connected and need to work together so every item is bought and nothing is bought twice.

A group is a number of people that have some relationship with another - but are not really connected. A team, in contrast, depicts a group of people that are involved in the same activity with a common goal. Through the coordination of tasks, these team members are strongly connected. Here, team members need to work together to perform successfully. 
Thus, main difference lays along the dimensions of: 
(1) Level of interest (self-interest vs. common vision)
(2) Way of interactions (self-centered vs. collaborative)
(3) Way of communiation and working mode
(4) Leadership

Example 1: Soccer Club fighting for relegation: 
- A team would be a group of players that play soccer with the common goal to stay in the league. Here, they strongly work together on tactics (=coordination of tasks) with their coach to solve problems and achieve common success. 
- A group would be individual players that are mainly interested in their own goals (e.g. maximising market value and salaries) and therefore prioritize activities that are aligned with self-interest. 

Example 2: Two founders of a start-up: 
- A group would consist of founders, who act independently and follow different interests and tasks: They teamed up in their inspiration to be independent of corporate structures. The tech lead would aim at building the best possible technical infrastructure in a given time, while a business lead would aim to bring a working prototype to the market as soon as possible. 
- A team would be two founders who have a common vision (e.g. revolutionising an entire industry). They collaboratively support each other to realize the best possible product. The difference would be closer communication and collaboration than in a group.

Das erste Beispiel für den Unterschied zwischen Gruppe und Team liefert das betrachten einer Gruppe im Sport und einem Team im Sport. Eine Trainingsgruppe, beispielsweise in der Leichtathletik, trainiert zusammen, um von anderen kompetenten Sportlern umgeben zu sein, jedoch steht immer der eigene Erfolg im Fokus. Ebenfalls ist jeder selbstständig für seine eigene Trainingsleistung verantwortlich, um selbst einen Sieg in einem Wettbewerb zu erzielen. Dieser Sportler steht hier in gewisser Weise in Selbstverantwortung.
Anders ist es hier bei Sportteams, wie zum Beispiel beim Rudern. Ein ambitioniertes Ruderteam wird ebenfalls alles dafür geben, um eine Meisterschaft o.ä. zu gewinnen. Der Unterschied ist hier, dass alle 2/4/8 Ruderer ,auch wörtlich gesehen, im selben Boot sitzen. Hier lastet die Verantwortung nicht auf einen einzelnen, sondern auf jedem Glied im Boot. Besonders deswegen ist wichtig, dass jeder für das gemeinsame Ziel arbeitet, da wenn einer der Teampartner nicht in Form ist und deswegen schwächer rudert, dass ganze Team Misserfolg erleidet.
