A group is any collection of things that share a common denominator, such as for example a location. So it would be entirely appropriate to refer to a bunch of pencils lying around together as a group, but one would never call them a team for obvious reasons. A team is something else, a group of individuals working together to achieve a specific goal. Common uses of the word would be in reference to sports, like football or rugby. There in turn, it would feel strange to simply refer to these people as a group, with how close they are and how much they have in common. In other words, "team" is a much more personal specification of the word "group". It's important for the context of Software Engineering as well, because it's optimal to have that kind of connection with the people you're working with, to feel like you're striving for the same thing.
A group is a collection of individuals who coordinate their efforts, while a team is a group of people who share a common goal.

A team is basically a group of people working on the same goal in an organized efficient way.
Exemple 1 :
- The Difference between  people who just met and want to play a basketball game and a professional sports team is wide. The first group of people they devide themselves into two groups but  it's more likely that every individual is there mainly to have fun while on the other hand the individuals of a professional sports team have a common goal which is to win the game following certain strategies : each person  plays his/her assigned role in the team. 
- A group of students who are getting to know eachother and want to work on a project are certainly less organized and goal-oriented as a professional team in a company. They will have more difficulties assigning the tasks or getting along on many project aspects whereas the professional team memebers already know each other well and have a common goal and a strategy in tasks' management and problem solving.

group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another. The connections between the members are not very strong.
team: a group of people work together in order to achieve the same goal. Members are strongly connected.

A group is a bunch of people with similar interests or some kind of relationship.
Teams are also groups but with the addition of having a common goal upon the group members.
So in general a team is less individual and more collective oriented.

For example the 2200 students who are registered for EIST are a group beacuse we have this course in common, but we do not have a common goal. We all want to pass for ourselves and work on our own.
If we would get a collective grade instead of a peronal one, we would be a team. We all would have to work for the grade everyone gets.

Other examples for groups are:
friendship circles, social groups, choir

Other examples for teams are:
soccer team, department at work

Group: 
Some people have some kind of relationship with each others, but each individual is working on their own and not for a mutual target. 
Team:
People are working together on a project to reach a common goal and everyone is participating to reach that goal and is not working for their own

A Team is for example a Formula 1 Team, where everyone is working on performing best with the car. A group for example is a group of people with the same interests (e.g. Soccer)  who are meeting every Friday to watch  the match of their favourite team

Members of a group don't work together but individually, they aren't connected and don't share a common goal.
Members of a team work together and complement each other. They coordinate well and share a purpose.

For example, people who get randomly matched for a group assignment would be a team in the beginning. As time progresses and they work together more and more, they would adapt, get to know each other's strengths and weaknesses, and become a team.

A group of students in the lecture room are loosely connected, because they have not much relationship to other people and work on his own. A team in a department of company are strongly  connected, because they need work together to complete a project with same goal.

In a group, the members of the group are loosely connected and do not have a common purpose or goal.  
(#) 
In a Team the members are strongly connected and focus on a specific outcome. 
Thats why in Teams, members work together but in the group they work individually. 

For Example : In a Football Team, all players have the same purpose to win the game and are strongly connected. 
In a classroom, there is a group of students that attend the lecture together but everyone has his own goal and can learn individually. 

Other example : Band of music ( as a Team ) vs Group of Singers sing one after one in a Party

While the phrase "a group of people" is mainly used to describe the number of a collection of people who have met for a specific reason, such as going to the movies or listening to a tourist guide, the term "team" is used to describe a "group" of people who, however, are also coordinated among themselves and work together towards a common goal. For example, in sports we talk about "teams" because they are coordinated and work together to win.

1.) The most important difference between a group and team is, that a group of people doesn't have a common goal, that they should to achieve. They can work independently. But members in team are working on their tasks together and they are focusing on solving specific problems.
2.) The members of a group can be connected by their interests and they are working independently, but team members have a stong connection and are coordinated by the team leader.

Teams are self organizing and diverse, relying on open communication and transparency. They have a common goal, trust each other and should be able to fully utilize each member's skills by coordinating. They are more than the sum of their parts. In comparison a group is a number of Individuals who may have something in common, but they don't have a common goal. As such they don't exceed the sum of their components.
Example of a Group:
The student body of the department of informatics is a good example for a group. Pretty much everyone has in common wanting to get their degree and liking computer science, but it is not like everyone knows each other student and their weaknesses and strength. The most they can strive towards completing a common goal is maybe organizing a party or complain for more funding (There may exist teams within the group but as a whole it isn't feasible for everyone to be connected in that way).
Example of a Team:
Pretty much any band has to work together as a team during a live performance. Everyone has to be on sync and not just perform at their own tempo. The metaphor of creating something more also works, because the complete musical piece creates harmony which wouldn't be heard by listening to each audio track by itself.

Team is a more effective Group. Since they are more coordinated, have more experience with each other and hence trust in each other. For example the difference between a school group for a project and a professor in university with team is obvious. Not only because of a degree, but the way they work. With the professors instructions and good team work they can educate 2200 students in 3 months. Compared with that, school group would each take a part that they want. Would not discuss it before work. After they would try connect their pieces of work into some bigger, which is in most cases inefficient.

A group is just an accumulation of people who have some sort of connection between them.
A team is a group where the participants work towards a common goal by coordinating tasks to reach it. The teammates need to work together to reach the goal and are more strongly connected than the members of a group.

For example, a group of kids playing football wants to win, of course, but they do not train with each other for a long time just for that one game.
A football team, however, trains a long time for the next game and has a common goal: to win that game. While training, they focus on the outcome of the next game and need to work together, because if everybody just does what he wants, they will surely lose against the other team.

Another example of a group would be a travel group: They have a loose connection between them, as they booked the same trip, but everybody is there for their own entertainment, takes their own pictures, and the travelers generally do not even know each other.
An example for a team would be scientists that explore Antarctica. They focus on the outcome of their trip (new scientific discoveries) and need to work together, as it is freezing there, and they have to build their own remote research station with their own supply of water, food, and electricity. They have to coordinate, as it would be harder if everyone has to look for their own supplies.

group:
1. everyone works only individually, e.g. every student solves the Eist-Homework in Group self.
2. people have no tight connection, e.g. every student only listen together but do not work together.


team:
1. everyone works together, e.g. 5 students in a team solves the problem of Eist teamwork together.
2. people have no tight connection, e.g. every students in team chats and write the code together, they trust each other.
A group is just a bunch of people who have something in common, like beeing in the same train. A team works together to achieve a specific goal, like winning a football match together.

Groups: 
Some people who dont have a close relationship and no specific goal which has to be achieved. For example a group of students who are sitting and listening to the lecturar.

Teams: 
People, who have a strong relationship between each other with the target to achieve a goal which is given.
For example a developement team building an app.

Group: Set of people that can be distinguished from other people (who are not in the group) by a specific property. Example of a group: All people who have ever studied at TUM. 

Teams are special groups (principle of inheritance plays a role here...). All members have a common project / common aims and collaborate.
Example of a team: Technik-AG (students responsible for event technology) at school

Group is a loosely connected amount of people. They do not have a unite goal and there is, so there us no need to work together. For example people just joined a toutor group. Each participant has his or her own goal(e.g. different expectations for grades), reasons and working methods. Some people join the tutoriumjust to ask specific questions, others to learn more extras about the subject, others to communicate with other students. Everyone decides for himself if he want to join and what level of participation will he have. Each participant can learn and work by himself without influencing others.

Team is amount of people working for the same goal, who can only achieve it by working together. The people are strongly connected since there is no chance achieve the goal withou the team. For example a football team cannot win without playing together and "giving" the ball one another

Team:  some strongly connected People aiming for a shared goal, through cooperatuon and communication with each other. 

Group: a bunch of loosly connected individuals following their own goal, without really cooperating or communicating much with each other.

Example 1:
	- Doctors performing a surgery
	-> These doctors are an example for a team, because they work for the same goal of saving the patients life.
 		To accomplish this goal they cooperate on multiple diffrent tasks.

Example 2:
	- Participants of a marathon
	-> They barely know each other (some participants might know one another well,
		 but most are complete Strangers). Even though they each have the simmilar goal of getting first,
		they work only individually to achieve it. These participants are an example of a group

While groups are collections of people, who have some relationship between each other, teams are groups of people who come together for the sake of a common goal or share a common purpose. So one could say that a team is a subclass of a group. 

Within a group, members work on their own and are not connected to each other. They do not share a common purpose. On the other hand, participants in a team work together in coordination to achieve a common goal and thus they are strongly connected to each other. 

An example for a group could be the passengers on a train. A second example could be a group of students sitting in a classroom. In these both examples, the participants act independently from each other and are not connected to each other.

An example for a team could be the musicians in an orchestra, where all the musicians have one common goal to perform the piece successfully. They work together in coordination and strongly depend on each other`s work. A second example could be students in a student`s newsletter club at a school. In this case, the participants have the common purpose to successfully publish the newsletter until the deadline. Each student`s task requires coordination here.

Teams have a common goal in a particular activity. The success of that goal affects everyone on the team. Therefore, people need to work together, for example, on a university project. In contrast, groups are, for example, students studying computer science. They all want to pass the exams successfully. Therefore, they work for themselves and are not so connected with each other.

While the two words "group" and "team" are used interchangeably quite frequently, they actually mean different things: While a group consists of different people who have a loose relationship towards each other and do not share a common goal, a team is built from strongly connected people who work closely together towards achieving a certain outcome. 

If, for example, some people interested in magic meet on vacation to discuss their tricks, they might be considered a group of enthusiasts. If they, on the other hand, decide to perform a show together, they have to work closely together towards achieving their common goal and should be called a team.
Another group would be people worrying about the climate crisis. Each on their own try to work towards a greener future. If they now organize a public event highlighting effects of our lifestyle on the climate together, they coordinate their efforts and should therefore be considered a team.

A group is a number of people coming together because of an occasion or a specific relationship that have to each other. One should not forget that connection that group members have to each other is very loose. Members work on their owns and not for a common purpose. On the other hand a team consist of a group of people work together coordinated for a common purpose. Connection that the participants have to each other is rather strong. The team members have to work synchronized and together in order to fulfill the common task they have. For example a group of students sitting in a lecture hall do not have to work together or stay connected in order to pass their individual exams. Because the endterm is just different for every student and it is one' s own responsibility to work on one's own individually and pass their own exam. In a football team differently from a group of students every player should also train together and be synchronized and connected because their common goal to play in a match successfully requires synchronization.

A group is just a loose connection of people that dont necesseraly have to share the same objectives. 
A team on the other hand disposes of strong connection between the team memebers and they work togehter to achive a common goal. 

Group: A group of colleagues from university, they all study together but every one is generally focues on his own lectures and assignments. 

Team: Some students that come together to prepare for an exam they are all going to have. They all have different strengths so that there exists a mutual requiriement between all of the team members, with the goal of passing the exam they all have the same objective.

A group is defined as people who have some connections and relationship to each other - in differnce to a team, theese connections are loosly and everybody is doing his/her work on his/her own. Also they does not work towards something together - no focus on a common purpose nor on a specific outcome. 

In contrast a team works hand in hand to archive a common goal and are involved together on a project/on the same activity. Working together is a key value to focus on a defined outcome - as a result the team is more connected - also known as team spirit - and has to coordinate it's work and exercises.

Examples where the differences can be spot are the group of citizens of a country vs. the team of party members or a group of students vs. a soccer team.

In the first example a group of citizens only shares the same nationality - they don't nessesary work all together, everyone for his own sake and don't have the same specific goal what they want to archive. Compared to a party, it's members have mostly the same vision and are working together to rule a country and make live in the country better - therefore they have to devide the needed tasks, roles and skills, so that everybody can fokus on his own strength to lead the party to success in the next selection.

Same with students compared to a soccer team- students are students because they visit an university or school - but they  does not have a common goal to archive and everybody goes his/her own way. Mostly they doesn't need to interact and doesn't need to have a strong connection to each other. In difference to that a soccer team win or lose together - they want to win a game and they only could do this together - therefore everybody takes his place in the team through different positions on the field, like defender or  striker and has its own strengthens and weaknesses the others tries bring to light/cancel out. Team spirit is important and everybody has to give everything for the team to win.

A group is a number of people,  who share a loose connection with another. A team essentially is also a group, but they are involved with another and share a goal. This means, a team is way more connected than just a group. 

So for example if you take a tourist group, they are all connected, because they are all most likely on vacation and want to see some sights, but they do not keep in touch with the rest of the tourist group after the tour has finished. 
On the other hand, the team leading the tourist is working with the common goal. To bring traffic to the attractions of their region and try to make the experience for every tourist as good as possible. 
Staying with the tourist example. The tourist group does not have to worry about the organization of the trip. They just have to sign up one by one and be ready at the given time. The team behind the tours needs to work together to prevent things from going south. They need to organize breaks, restaurants, bus drives and plan out the route ahead of time.

A group is an amassment of people. No ulterior motive binds them except at best a common interest or a common activity. They are further not interested in each other. A team however is a group of people that actively work together towards one goal, solving a problem, or objective, are aware of each other's skills in regard to the problem solving (which is an integral property to accomplishing the goal or problem) and establish a deeper personal connection by doing so. A group is e.g. a group in WhatsApp consisting of ~300 students, but a team is a group of 5 students who work on a project together. Another example is : In Munich's Indian community, there are groups of like-minded people such as the gossip aunties, the business uncles, the hikers, the party-goers etc. But a team is formed once those people that come from these groups come together to take charge of the organisation of a cultural festival.

The word group is used for some people that doesn't necessarily have a common goal or have to work together. Teams get together for a purpose, work together and usually divide their tasks that make one project combined. Teams need to work together interactively whereas a group of people can work individually.

For example:

We can call a number of people, who are sitting in a movie theater and watching the same movie, a group.

But the people who make the movie (actors, producers, director etc.) are actually a team and they made one project by working together interactively.

There are three aspects differ group from team:
Firstly, the relationship between participants: team members are tightly connected while group members are loosely connected;
Secondly, purpose and goal; team members share the same goal, whereas group members might have different purpose or goal;
Lastly, the way of work: team members work together to achieve something, while group members work individually.

Examples:
1. Students attend a course who don't have common assignments and they just need to pass the exam on their own is group, but if they need to do some assignments with others to get extra points, those students doing assignments together form teams.

2. people taking swimming courses to learn swimming are in a group; whereas people playing soccer against opponents form teams.

Group is a number of people whose relationship is made by something and hence that are somehow related to each other. For example, audiences of the League of Legends Championship are one group. They sit in a same place and watch the game. They are not actually connected or know each other all.
Team is a group of people that have a same goal and work hard together in order to achieve that goal. All team members work hard and are strongly connected. Furthermore, they all know each other. An example for a team is a League of Legends team who participates in the championship league. The 5 team members have the same goal which is achieving the victory. For that, every individual works hard for their own role.

A group contains of several people with some relationship to each other. All members are loosely connected and there is no focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose. Everyone works on his/ her own.
A team on the other hand is a group of people who are involved in the same activity with a common goal. All members are strongly connected and focus on a specific outcome using a coordination of tasks and activities. Everybody needs to work together.
For example, a football team is a team as they work towards the goal of winning the game and kicking the ball into the goal. They work together and are strongly connected. 
A guided tour through a city is a group as the people do not know each other and are therefore only loosely connected through the same travel destination and tour guide. They have no specific outcome planned and focused on. Everyone does the tour on their own.

Group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another
• Participants are loosely connected
• Do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose
• Every individual works on his own
• Team: any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, 
especially referring to sports and work
• Participants are strongly connected
• Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities 
• Members need to work together

A group is an accumulation of people that are somewhat loosely connected like a friend group in school. You will see each other in class or during breaks and spend time with each other, but there is no specific shared goal you're working together to achieve.
A team on the other hand consists of people aiming for the same goal and cooperating to attain it. For example a soccer team playing together trying to win a game and qualify for playoffs. Usually every team member plays a important and essential role in the success of a team.

A group is a number of people that are weakly related to each other. They do not really share a goal, every group member relies rather on himself. On the other hand, a team consists of firmly connected people, who share a goal and cooperate in order to achieve it. Thus is teamwork mandatory.

General definition:
A group of students may be all of the students currently located in cafeteria.
A team of students is most likely a team working on a project.

Differences in productivity:
Group of coocks may work individually on their own dish on every stage of preparation, without dividing the work.
Team of coocks separate the cooking process of many dishes based on their specialities and/or skill, resulting in faster/better performance.

A group of people is a collection of more then one person with weak or no realtionships to each other. A good example of a group is a gathering of people getting a tour in a museum. The people in the group are in no realtionship to each other but share the characteristic that they are doing the same activity. Participants of a group may interact with eachother slightly, but not on a personal level (trust, expectations) and without any common goals or missions.

A team defines a group of people with a common aim or task, on which they collectively work together. Depending on the maturity of the team, partcipants are connected with each other on personal levels which may include trust or a shared kind of identity.  Another difference between a simple group and a team is that the members of the latter need to coordinate, communicate and cooperate with each other, and do not work for just them selves. Every team member has to contribute with their skills in some way, in order to achive the common goal. A good example of a team would be a football team, in which strongly connected teammates take over certain skills (playing positions) and work together to achieve their goal, which is winning the match.

A group is only a number of people that are loosely connected, like for example the inhabitants of a certain town or students in a class, as they do not have a common goal, that has to be solved together.
A team on the other hand is a group of people that work closely together to achieve a shared vision. Example for a team would be a soccer team or a work group in a company.

A group is a number of persons, who have some kind of connection to each other,
like a group of friends that meet in a park. They don't have some kind of bigger goal in mind and usually don't work together towards something, they are just there to have some fun together.
In contrast to that a team is a number of persons, who want to achieve something, like a group of students who are doing a project for university. They have a goal in mind, finish the project with a good grade, and they are organized in a way, that everybody has a task of some kind. That way they work together to finish the project.

The difference between groups and teams is mainly determined through their relationship, if a common goal exists and if they work together or not.

A group is a gathering of several people who have a looser relationship e.g. several people who are gathered together in an incubator-program of UnternehmerTUM to learn about how to found a start-up. They all work individually on their own start-ups e.g. one works on a start-up in mobility, the others on a start-up in sustainability but do not have a common goal or a shared vision. 

However a start-up team is a group of people that shares the same vision of their start-up e.g. to make a positive impact for a more sustainable world. They want to achieve a common goal together for example to develop the most sustainable clothing, so they share a stronger, and also more personal relationship, work closely together and aim to bring for example their own start-up forward.

Another example for a group are students who study Informatics and watch the same lecture e.g. Software Engineering. They don’t share a common goal, are not closely connected to each other or share a close relationship and everyone is responsible for studying by themselves. However, if some of these students work together on a university project e.g. developing a software application in the course Software Engineering with the common goal of getting the best grade, and thus, share a closer connection, they are a team.

Differences  between Groups and Teams: A group of people are a number of people that have some type of relationship to one another but are only loosely connected. In a group the individual participants don't necessarily work together and don't work towards a common goal. Whereas a team has a common goal/target and it's participants all need to work together to achieve this goal. These individuals also have a stronger connection to one another, which helps them succeed.

A good example for a group of people are students in a class, who all work for their own goals(good grades). Whereas e.g. a football team need to work together in order to win games, which is the common goal of the 
team. If one of the team members is selfish and isn't able to work in the team, he/she can drag the whole team down.
Another difference between a group and a team is that the team will probably meet privately(go to dinner etc.) to further strengthen their bond as a team. A group will most likely not do that as the participants won't have a better chance at achieving their individual goals if they have a stronger relationship to one another.

A group is a number of people who just have a thing or two in common. A member of the group works individually and his work is not dependant on others.
A team is a group of people who share the same goals, members work together and their work is dependant on each other.

Group: Some people that sit in the Galileo and take part in the EIST Vorlesung are a group.
Team: 5 people from this course or from the same tutor group that get together for the team project are a team who share a common goal which is that of presenting and developing a good project in the end and getting those points for the Notenbunus ;).

group: a number of people acting on their own to achive their individual goals

team: a number of people who work together to achieve a shared goal and support each other

example: if i go to a mountain to hike and there are a lot of people who also want to hike we are a group. we all take our individual paths to individual goals

if i go hiking with my friends and we aim to climb to the top of the mountain, split the tasks( one packs water, one food,...) and cheer each other on to reach the top we act like a team because we work together to achieve a shared goal that we likely couldnt reach on our own

A group is only a contextless accumulation of people. For Example people in a company that have the same job or a group of people that is working on something independently.
On the other hand, a group becomes a team, when the members of the group trust each other, get to know each other, know the weaknesses and the capabilities of the other. For Example a Dev-Team that works on one specific problem together or a team that is responsible for maintaining a specific part of Software. Here it is key talking to each other, dividing the problem among the members and find a solution together while keeping in mind every opinion. Results found by a team are more likely to be right. A team normally accomplishes more than one individual ever could, but it takes a while for the members of the team to get really good and productive. 
One can say that every team is a group, but not every group is a team.

A group is just a number of people with a certain relationship, which are not necessarily involved to reach a certain goal by working together. On the other hand, a team is a group, that has a common goal, which should be achieved with the teamwork of its members. 

Examples :
- A person, that is a gym member, could train by himself to reach his own body goals. On the other hand, a person in a sport team could only win ( In this case, this is his goal in a team ), when he works together with the other team members

- A racer, that is a part of a group of racers, win a race during a tournament individually, but his racing team must work together to prepare the race car for such tournament, so he could be the winner

People in a group usually don't have a deep connection to every other member of it and most members rather work alone. In a team every member works together with any other member to achieve a common goal which most likely couldn't be achieved alone.

A group of people waiting at a bus station for example are only there to wait for the bus. Some might know each other but most won't. They don't necessarily need the other people in order to successfully wait for the bus.

On the other hand people playing football form a team. They form a bond with the other members, trust each other and work together in order to win as a team. If they wouldn't work together they would most certainly not win.

A group is merely a number of people that have some relationship with each other, whereas, in a team, every member has the same shared goal and usually engages in the same or similar activities to achieve this goal.

Example for a group:
The German population could be seen as a group since it includes all German citizens. Their citizenship would define their relation to each other. Not all Germans share the same goal though.

Example of a team:
The FB Bayern soccer team. These are all football players that play football together (same activity) and try to win tournaments. (shared goal)

Groups are a collection of people who are loosely connected to one another, in which every individual works on his own. A Team on the other hand is a collection of people who work tightly together for a shared goal in mind, while also being strongly connected to each other.

The difference between team and group is for example firstly that the team is a group of people that have a common goal, strong connection, for example sports team, because the members of the team are training for the same competition as team in order to get a medaille for the whole team and to participate in the next competition. By group there is no common goal and requirements for achieving this goal, no strong connection, every member is separate, for example in the university students learn in order to gain experience and knowledges for themselves, to pass the exam and to come in the next semester.
Second difference is that in the team all people work together, in sports team training together for example, in works team working on a project for business company, in dancing ensembles - rehearsal for a concert, it is coordination, interaction and mutual aid required between the members. In the case of definition of group however everyone work on your own for achieving his own goal, students learn to pass the exam, there is no need of working together, no need of coordination of actions, there are different interests, everyone works separately on his task and complete the work.

While a team focuses on achieving a common goal, a group does not focus on a specific outcome nor a common purpose. Unlike a group, team members are strongly connected, are involved in the same activity and work together on a common goal. A team discusses a problem, how to solve it and fixes it collectively. It requires coordination of tasks and activities for the team to produce their collective work, they need to work together. 
Examples:
A kindergarden group vs. soccer team
The kindergarden group represents a number of loosely connected people who do not aim for achieving a common goal or a specific purpose. Every child is doing whatever he/she wants to do, so they are kind of "working on their own". 
Meanwhile all the members on a soccer team share their activity of playing soccer and the goal to win a game, so they work out a strategy, which requires coordination and each person to have a specific task (e.g goalkeeper, defender). They also need to work together because otherwise they would not be able to win. All members are strongly connected and trust each other.

In a group there are people that have some sort of relationship to one another but there is no close bond between the individuals. Everybody works on his own and for his own specific outcome. 
In a team there are people that work on the same topic with a common goal. Teams are most commonly refered to in sports or at work. The team members are closely connected and work coordinated together to archieve something as a team.
An example for a team is a soccer team. The players have the same goal of winning the game and try to play as good as possible together to win. 
An example for a group are people that are watching a lecture together and might help each other out with some questions but who might never meet again after and who don't necessarily have the same goal with attending this lecture.

A group is a collection of individuals who coordinate their efforts, while a team is a group of people who share a common goal. 
Groups build temporary relationships: Since groups focus on individual members working in parallel to one another, they build temporary working relationships such as short-term external projects or temporary internal consulting. 

Groups are great for efficiency: While teams work to create efficiency for the greater good, groups focus on individual efficiency. This can improve effectiveness when looking at individual work and larger group objectives. 

Groups focus on individual growth: Since groups support individual work, they also focus on individual growth. This can be seen in the form of individual experts rather than a team of experts.

Teams build on collaboration and synergy: Teamwork can increase collaboration and synergy. These help support the overall goal and can aid in communication and organizational transparency. 

Teams encourage group productivity: While groups aid in efficiency, teams have the advantage when it comes to productivity. This is because team members support each other’s work and help solve the overall problem, making the actual work more productive. 

Teams are better for problem solving: It’s true that the more people brainstorm together, the better. This is why teamwork can help solve problems quicker and more effectively the first time around.

In a group, members are loosely connected and work individually while they are not focusing on a common purpose, whereas a team has a common purpose and works together towards it while being connected to each other.

Groups are a collection of people who have some properties in common. In contrast to a team, they are not actively contributing to a common achievement. A team consists of members who work together on tasks that address everyone in that team - participants need to collaborate. 

A group can be found for example at an end term exam: There are lots of students who participated in the same course. Though, everyone has to do the exam on his own and cannot work together with other students.
On the other hand, a software development team who works in a agile scrum method, people would need to collaborate and work together on tasks. A software which consists of a frontend interface and backend system can only fit together if all developers stay in close communication and know how the tasks are distributed across the team.

Group: A group is just a number of people who are doing the same thing or something similar. But without a shared vision or strong communication and connection.  	
Team: A Team is a number of people who share a vision, and they are strongly connected with the same  big goals. And they have a strong communication between them.

Group is a collection of people through some aligned interests, as such they are loosely connected.
Team on the other hand came together because of a common goal, as such they are strongly connected.

Another point derives: a person in a group does not have to work with others to achieve their goal, but a team has to work together, because of their common interest.

While a group is a collection of individuals that have a certain relationship that joins them (work, studying..) but that still functions individually(loosely interconnected), a team is a group of individuals that additionally share the same goal and whose members work interdependently (strongly connected), hence a team is a subclass of a group (a team class inherits from the group class).
Taking into consideration the example of a basketball team, all members in this team share a collective identity and serve the same goal which is achieving the best possible outcome for the whole team (winning a game for example), in the best ones teammates focus especially on working together,communication and coordination.
Oppositely, a group of roomates that indeed share the same living space and coonsequently tasks around the house as well as bills does not necessarily communicate together or even get along well as every individual leads an independent life and only works with the other roomates on certain commun aspects. There's no commun purpouse or a specific outcome that needs a collective participation and attention.

A group is a number of people who happen to know each other but do not share a strong connection. In a group everyone works on their own and the people do not share the same goal.
An example for a group is a school class. There everyone knows each other but still everyone works on their own and has their own goals.

A team is a group of people who are strongly connected. Members of a team are working coordinated on an activity together to archive a common goal.
An example for a team is the national german football team, where the whole team is working together to win the world-championship.

A group is formed by people who have a loose connection to each other. For instance, the people attending the EIST lecture. In contrast, a strong connection within a team is highly important, e.g. the members of a sports-club form a team.

Furthermore, a group doesn't necessarily have a common purpose or goal, which it wants to achieve. The people attending the EIST lecture do not have a common goal, while a sports-club is willing to win the next game or to ascend to the next higher league.

A group can be the people riding a subway together every morning because they work in the same building. They all have a relationship to each other since they work at the same location and use they same transportation to get there but they don't have a common vision or goal they are working on or which they want to achieve. They are "all by themselves" so to say, because they each dont care whether the others make it to work or not. They simply care abou their own arrival there. That's what is meant by "working alone".

A team is like a group but the people are "more connected". A team can be a kitchen crew as they are all engaging in the same activity (their work in the kitchen of a big restaurant). Therefore, they are all having the same vision and goal, e.g. to satisfy the customers with tasty meals. To reach that common goal they all have to work together because everyone has his/her own role/responsibilities e.g. desserts or only vegetables or distributing the orders of the customers. They know each other better than the people on the subway because they spend a lot more time together and need to be able to work well together in a coordinated way to be able to achieve their goal.

In a group, people work on individual goals. The group members do not have a close relationship or trust in each other. 
In a team, people pursue a common goal and trust each other. They work closely together and have a strong bond.
If a member of your group has a problem, he or she must solve it alone. Due to the lack of team spirit and different goals, a group does not stick together. In a team, on the other hand, people share the same goal and help each other to achieve it. 
Even with deadlines, a team helps together, even if tasks from others are not finished yet and their own already are. In a group, the others would go home and the other must finish alone. The members do not care about the success of the group as long as they are successful.

work individualy - work together
differents and interest / common goal same interest

A group is a bunch of people, that in theory work together, but in practice they simply don't. It's just like a "group-project" in school where one person does everything and the rest just watches. The "project-group" is weakly bound and everyone follows (if present) their own vague idea of the result (again, if present). A team on the other hand, works together in theory and in practice and they communicate well. Due to the good coordination among the team, they trust each other and don't have to rewatch each other's work at the end of "every day". A team is mostly based upon a trusted environment where all members trust each other. The best example of a team would be a sport-team such as football/soccer-, volleyball-, basketball-clubs...

Group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another. For example, all students attending the lecture.

Team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal.
For example, the members of a project team for software development， they are a team

Both teams and groups consist of multiple people that are some how connected to one another.
There are however a few key differences between these two terms. Individual of a group are more self focused, work on their own and have a loose connection, while in contrast teams are strongly connected and work together in coordination to achieve a common goal or outcome.

A good example for a team would be a soccer team, they will work together both during practice and the match to achieve to goal of winning the game/the league their playing in.

People attending a concert would be an example of a group because they are not coordinating to achieve a common goal, in fact they are quite self oriented while still sharing a loose connection, in this case hearing the same music the band is playing.

One could say that the defining difference between a group and a team is the latter's greater cohesiveness and goal-orientation. A group can be seen as merely a "grouping" of individuals based on a relatively loose connection. The same applies to a team, but there the connection is much stronger and based on a common goal all individuals work together towards achieving. An example to make this clearer would be the students in a classroom. They are a group loosely connected by the fact that they're in the same class, but each one works on their own. If the students were however doing a group project, they could be considered a team since they'd be more strongly connected by the fact they'd need to work together on a common goal. As a maybe more abstract example, the cars in a traffic jam could also be seen as a group. They're loosely connected by the fact that they're sharing the same road, but do not have a common purpose as they each have their own destination. The moment an ambulance shows up they could be seen as a team. The drivers need to coordinate among each other and work together on the common goal of letting the ambulance through.

Group:
A group is a Collection of different people with share interest and/ or same activities. Members of a group share common characteristics but with individual goals.
Example: Group work in a work related field with individual persons from different departments come together for a project. While the common characteristic is to deliver the project, each department member also wants to reach its own goal and represent their departments.

Team:
A team is a collection of interdependent individuals, who come together to reach a common goal while coordinating their goals.
Example: People who row together in a rowing boat all have the same goal. To reach the goal, they need to row together collectively in the same pace. The overall common team goal is more important than the individual goal.

Teams are trying to achieve a common goal by cooperating intensely, whereas group memberes work merely separate from each other although they have some kind of connection.

# Examples:
- Bees and ants are very small animals which try to find food across a comparably big area. In ordermake efficient choices, they have to combine the impressions of many individuals by communicating through dances or odours.  
- Spiders do not rely on each other during their day to day life, since they spend most time waiting for prey. However, the individuals are still connected since they need each other for reproductional purposes.

1. Members in groups have less connected than people in teams. The former do not work on specific goals while the latter work together in order to reach specific outcome.
2. a) all students in course EIST is a group, students working on team projects are teams.

Members of a team are working together to achieve a common goal that one individual can not easily achieve. Also they try to support each other and help to match deficiencies each individual may have.
Contrary to that a group is more like a collection of people that independently of each other try to solve a problem while still being loosely connected to each other (e.g. trying to solve the same porblem or being in a room together). Members of a group are focused on themselves and may even try to sabotage each other.
So in conclusion a team tries to work together to solve a problem while members of a group have something in common but work uncoordinated.

A team consists of a bunch of people with a common goal in mind. They try to work together as best as possible to achieve the desired result. A group on the other hand consists of a bunch of people without a common goal where each member is mainly focused on individual goal and thus works on his own.

Group can be described as people who just share some relationship to each other. Everybody there works on his own, no focus on specific goals and the connections are loose. Team is a group, but has a well-defined goal, members work together on the specific outcome involving the coordination of tasks and activities, connections are strong. Examples are fitness club and football team. In the fitness club people just know each other, occasionally express support, but not more than that. Everybody has individual goals. Football team places the general goal above individual results. Each member has his special tasks and responsibilities. Another example is some kind of sewing hobby club, but another thing is tailor (atelier) studio. From my own experience groups are "just to do something", teams are "to deliver measurable results". Also group has interests (instead of a goal unlike team), low-level empathy (long distance between members), roles are semi-free (office workers, interess club).

A group is defined by several people that have some sort of relationship with each other. Participants of a group do not know each other very well and are more likely to work on their own. For example, the students attending a lecture can be considered a group. They do not know each other very well, at least they do not know many, and if there is a task, then they will most likely do it by themselves first. The only relationship connecting the students as a group is the fact, that they need to listen to the lecture.
A team is defined by people with a common goal and they are therefore more involved with each other. They work together and participants are focusing on specific tasks that are coordinated by the team. Each of the members are complementing each other and contributed to the common goal using their individual strengths. A soccer team is a prime example. The people of that sports team are working together to score the ball and eventually win the game. For that, they need to work together well and each member will know the strengths and weaknesses of the other. They complement each other to strive for their goal.
All in all, the biggest difference is the fact that people in a group do not know each other well and also the fact that they do not have something common to strive for. A group can't make things work out, because not everyone will work together, and nor will they reach a consensus if there is something to work on. Their relationship with each other is too brittle for that. A team will succeed because they know how to work with each other and are familiar with it. They have a strong bond and won't back out because if there is something difficult, then they will solve the problem together.

A group is a collection of individuals who coordinate their efforts, while a team is a group of people who share a common goal. While similar, the two are different when it comes to decision-making (aka leadership) and teamwork.
A team is a collection of people with complimentary skills, that work together, discussing most steps of the work together, sharing the role of leadership and the vision of the project. Meanwhile, a Group, has a chosen Leader, that organizes everyone Individually, and who all have their own accountability. Their Success or effectiveness is then mostly only valued by the effect it has on the project.

The difference between a group and a team is, that a group is just a loose grouping of people that have some kind of relation to one another. That means, the group members are only loosely connected and don't really have a common goal to reach. Moreover, the group members work on their own and not together.
In contrast, a team is a group of people that are involved in the same activity and share a common goal. That means, that the team members need to work together to reach a specific outcome, which requires coordination.
A team of students working together on a group project would be considered as a team because they have to work together to reach their goal. 
On the other hand, a group of students attending class are just a group because they don't really need to work together and are all just visiting the lecture on their own essentially.

Group: people with a relationship
Team: People with a relationship and a common goal

Examples: 
Group: citizens of a country, family
Team: football team, workers of a bakery

the key difference between groups and teams is, that in teams, the people work together to achieve a goal. Whereas groups are just a bunch of people who are together, maybe work in the same office, go to the same school or are just friends.

for example
the difference between a group of friends and a soccer team is, that the people in the team work together to achieve the goal of winning their next soccer match. Whereas the friend group is just a group of people who have a great time together but they are not working onto something together.

The main difference is in connection between members of group and team. In groups members are loosely connected, they do not work together and do not have common goal. In teams members have strong connections, they trust each other and work together to reach their common objective.

Example 1: Students on lecture (group) - connected only by university course, do not work together. Students working on team project (team) - connected by common goal (completing the project), working together to achive it.
 
Example 2: Group of software engieneers in social network (group) - connected only by their profession, do not work together. Development team - work together to deliver software (common objective), they have good communication and coordination of tasks.

A group is a collection of people who work towards their own goals (e.g. a group of students), a team on the other hand is a group of people who are working towards a shared common goal (e.g. a team of football players).

One area in which we can see the difference between groups and teams is for example school. We can say that the classes in school are groups - students have classes together, they know each other, but everybody has to work for their own grades. The schoolmates can be turned into a team if for example a teacher assigns a school project and now the students don't work only for themselves anymore - they should join forces in order to get a good grade, which gives them a mutual target.

Another example can be a spotted in sports competitions, in this case swimming. A group can be called the people that are competing for the same country, but in different styles - they have similar interests, but every one of them wants to be the one who wins the first place. This changes for example if we have a swimming relay - then all the competitors should work in the same directions and they should together figure out the strengths of the separate teammates, so that they get the best result for all.

Differences between groups and teams:

Groups are mostly more open up for new people and more likely to include new people. A great example for groups can be friend groups where you dont really need a specific qualification to join. In addition participants are loosley connected and mostly work on their own. Groups dont really focus on certain outcomes or common purposes.

Teams are mostly more enclosed and have a focus on something specific. An example could a sportsteam or a team in the IT sector of a company. You need specific qualifications and everyone has certain responsibilities. A team mostly focuses on specific topics and members mostly have a strong relationship between each other. You could say that teams have a specific mission to accomplish where every member is involved. This is why teams are mostly strongly connected. Teams are mostly in need of certain coordination of specific tasks of each member.

A group is a collection of people who don't work for the same purpose. For example, students in  EIST can be referred to as a group. We all studying EIST however we don't know what the other one is exactly doing and ones work doesn't effect or rely on another.

A team is a collection of people who do work for the same purpose and outcome. Each one of them has a role to play and each member knows about it so that they can work together in an organized way. For example, each player of a football team must know what they have to do when defending or attacking and they need rely on each other to win the match (working for the same purpose.

A group has not a lot that connects them. If they had to work together they would have a lot of difficulties.
A team has a common goal and is trying to work together as good as possible because of this. It takes some time and coordination to become an efficient team, but it will be a lot more effective than a loose group, where every one works on their own.

8 random people who don't know each other at all but happen to share a single functioning and not defect elevator can be viewed as a group. They are just loosely connected as they all know they share the same elevator, but presumably they do not much more about each other. They might not focus on specific outcomes as some might want to go up the building and others might want to go down the building. And they probably have their own unique reason for coming in the elevator (e.g. work, tourism, shopping, etc.)
8 random people who don't know each other at all but happen to share a single defect elevator can be viewed as a group. They were initially just loosely connected as they all knew they share the same elevator, but presumably they did not much more about each other. But now that their elevator got stuck after a small crash through the elevator shaft, some might start to panic and cry. Others in the elevator that happen to be dotors or psychiatrists might try and intervene. After all, they need to work together to stay calm, contact the outside world and eventually get rescued. If they started verbally or physically fighting over why panicing and crying was bad for their situation, nothing would get better. So, they need to breath slowly, save and share resources and secure their physical and mental well-being in a tiny and rather uncomfortable space. By coordinating tasks (e.g. the doctor treats the ill or hurt ones; the electrician repairs the broken elevator-lights; etc.), they focus on a specific outcome, and that is coming out the elevator well and alive.

A class of pupils working on an exam are a group. They do not work together. They often do not care too much about other pupils' marks, as they won't really affect their own marks. They are simply connected because they are all taking the same test.
A class of pupils working on a graded science project is a team. They all want a good grade. Their individual grade relies on the success of their coordination of smaller tasks and jobs. So, they are strongly connected. They need to care about each other.

Group is a number of people that have some relationship with each other. There is no shared goal to work together. Usually, participants are loosely connected and do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose. Every individual works on his own.
Example for Group: Patients. When patients go to the hospital to see a doctor, everyone does not emphasize cooperation, but only considers how to recover as soon as possible.

A team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work. Usually, participants are strongly connected, focus on a specific outcome, and require coordination of tasks and activities. Members need to work together.
Example for Team: A start-up company. Everyone in the company has the same goal to promote company development. And every member has a different task to cooperate.

Summary: The team is the subclass of the group. The participants in a team usually have a much stronger connection than that in a group. And everyone in a team shared the same goal rather than person in a group.

A group is loosely connected, individually-minded, and not focused on a specific goal or purpose.
A team is a group working on the same activity for a specific purpose or with a specific goal.

Example 1
Group: The participants taking a standardized test such as the GMAT at a specific time and in a common location.
Team: A GMAT test-taker and her personal tutors who all have a vested interest in the test-taker achieving a 650 on the GMAT.

Example 2
Group: Spectators watching a circus performance.
Team: The circus members performing a specific act together with the goal of jumping through rings of fire.

A group is a collection of people who have something in common. Group members are only loosely connected with each other, for example, by attending the same lecture, or taking the same bus.
Members of such groups do not work closely together and have mostly individual goals, namely to pass the exam or arrive at their destination.

In contrast, a team is a kind of subclass of a group, where all team members still have something in common, but in contrast to a group they are connected to each other very closely, for example by working together on the same task. There is a strong need for collaboration and trust between the team members to work together in an effective and target-oriented way.
An example of such a structure would be a software-development team that strives for a common goal through by coordinating tasks and planning possible solutions to ultimately release a stable product to the customer.

A goup just describes multiple poeople, that have some sort of connection.

They are all connected in visiting the same concert, but apart from that they have no closer connection and dont work together on anything and have no common goal. Everyone is there for themselves.
A team is a group, that is working together on a shared goal.
They are more closely connected.
For example a production crew for a movie is a team.
They all have the same goal of making a movie, and in order to achieve that goal they have to cooperate.

Team: Example: For example on football, the people must work together in order to overcome their opponent. There are also many roles, so it would be impossible for one man to do everything, they need to share the tasks.

A group is a number of people who are at most vaguely familiar to each other, with no real "bonding". They have no common goal they are working for, and they don't really work together.
An example would be a group (yes, I used group here) of kids on their first day in Kindergarten, if you give them the task to play anything they want together.

A team on the other hand are multiple people, who know each other pretty well and/or for a longer period of time. These people work for a common goal and do this together, as they know, they can rely on each other.
One of the best example would be a sports team, as they can only win, advance and compete in higher levels of competition if they have a good synergy, work together and trust each other.

The difference between a group and a team is mostly the connection between the members. The definition of a group and a team differs in three main regards: 
First being the interconnection of each member. Within a group - for example in an ethnic group - people barely know each other. On the contrary a Formula 1 team is closely interwined in a professional job environment. They all work together to achieve their goal which is also the second characteristic that sets them apart of a group. Members of a work group do NOT act in concert of a common target. 
Lastly, due to their lack of communication and absence of a shared objective, a group does not focus on reaching the same outcome. A team strives to achieve an identical end, which requires full communication and coordination between each team member. For example, a team works on a project together (releasing a software project) and a group works at the same company.

To summarize, a team defines itself by a shared objective on which they work together whereas a group is solely defined by their shared traits, such as having the same job (being an engineer in a big company) or alike. This basic definition implies the above mentioned differences, i.e. communication vs. lack of contact; shared goal vs. single target; etc.

Group: collective of people that have some kind of raltionship/connectio to eachother, but they are just vaguely working together. They don't have the exact same goals and don't realy try to work to gether to achieve their goals.

Team: Members work together closely; all people work together towards the same goal; To achieve mentioned goal, tasks get distributed between each member to be as efficient as possible.

The main difference between a group and a team is, that in a group each person has something in common with each other, where else in a team every team member has the same goal.

One example would be a group of people going hiking. Here the group has the same interest which is hiking but each person has a different goal which does not make them a team. But when they all get stuck in a cave, they all share the same goal which is to get out of the cave, that automatically makes them a team.

A very common example would also be a elevator ride with people. Each individual in the elevator shares interests or has something in common with each other since they are in the same elevator which makes them a group. Once the elevator is stuck they all start to share the same goal which is to escape which makes them a team.

A group can be defined as a collection of individuals who instead of focusing on a common/shared goal, work on coordinating their efforts. The members are independent from each other and thus hold individual accountability. 
A team is rather a collection of people, that try to achieve a common objective by working together, which results in interdependency, or a strong connection between the members.
A good example for teams are sport teams. The players work together to achieve the same goal, in this case winning. They depend on each other to reach their objective and if one player fails, the whole team gets held accountable. The result depends on the collective efforts and helping each other out.
It would be wrong to say that a group does not depend on coordination of the members, but they rather focus on the individual tasks than on the collective task. A great example for a group would be an airline flight crew. Each of the members focuses much more on their individual assignments and accomplishments, instead of helping the others out to achieve their goals.

In general there are differences between groups and teams. A group consists of several people where every member of the group will work by himself. A team is any group which is participating in the same activity to achieve a common goal by working together. The general goal of an football team for example is to win the game for what every team member has to work together. Because of the usually weekly training, the bond in this team will be stronger than the bond of people being just in a group as a religion for example. There everybody has its own goals but common interest traits that bring them together. Besides, in a religion you share the same ideology but you only know a few people personally. The majority are just random people with the same interests with almost no significant relationships.

A group is a bunch of people that somehow know each other. They do not have a common Goal that they want to achieve and the people work by themselves. On the other hand a Team has something that they want to achieve by working together. They know each other quite well and effectivly working together is essential.

Example: A Group of People sitting in a Bus and a Formula 1 Team

Example: Random group of people working in a coffee shop and a team working on a projekt in an office

Groups aren't as tightly knit as teams, as they do not share a common goal or purpose.
While team members work and plan together, group members do not.

A bunch of students meeting at the Isar would be classified as a group as they aren't necessarily closely connected and their intention isn't to work towards something.

On the other hand, a bunch of students tasked with preparing a presentation would be classified as a team.
They'll be forced to connect more with one another in order to coordinate and work  through the task at hand (research, formatting the presentation, holding the speech).
During this process, they'll have to work together to succeed.

A group is a bunch of people that are together but nevertheless don't have a sharp strong motivation to complete a certain task. An example could be a group of friends that decide to go eat lunch together at the Mensa. These people do have something slightly in common because they are in the same physical space and doing something in common (eating). But obviously there is no clear goal/vision, and there is not much communication/organization required for this activity. Also, each person may be doing their own individual irrelevant thing e.g. on their phone, talking to someone, etc. 

On the other hand a cricket team would be a team, because there is a very clear vision e.g. to win the world cup. Also, they are tied a lot closer together and there is a significant amount of communication involved to ensure the team operates successfully. Although each person on the team may have their own role, there must still be regular communication to ensure the team performs cohesively.

The difference between groups and teams is that groups can be any number of people which are connected through a common activity / interest whereas teams work together actively and should know each other well. For example everyone attending the lecture EIST is part of a "group" of students, but dont  necessarily have to know or trust each other or work together.

People are together and can suffice as a group. But people come together to form a team. Compared with those in a group, people in a team are far more connected. For example, there can be a group of students attending the same course or swimming in the same pool, but they may not even know each other and when finished they probably won’t see each other anymore. On the other hand, a team of soccer players tend to train together and strive towards the same goal, and a team of band members tend to meet with each other regularly to practice music in preparation for a show.

A group is often a random gathering of people with no common goal, e.g. a group of pupils in a class room do not really have a common goal, they often have to be there and did not even choose to do so. On the other hand a group of pupils that work on a project together forms a team, as they have a common goal and want to figure out how to get there together. 

Another example would be a group of people on a plane going on a holiday, however they do not have the same holiday booked (hotel, etc.) and sometimes not even the same final destination. On the other hand, a football team going on a training camp might also be on this plane, but they have a common goal for this journey and are working on this together, therefore they are a team.

Groups are a collection of people who have something in common. However, this thing that they have in common can be very loose. In most of the cases it is easy to join or leave a group. An example of a group could be a group of people waiting for a bus. By staying at the bus station you join the group and by then deciding to walk the way you can leave the group. Teams are a subset of groups, which means every team is a group but not every group is automatically a team. Teams often share same goals and beliefs, they behave cooperative which means that the success of the individual is in the interest of the whole team. Becoming a team is harder because there has to be some trust between the team members. Often in a team everybody knows his or her role. Joining a team that has already been formed can be hard, due to the fact that some team members might fear that they loose their position. On the other hand, leaving a team can be hard as well, because there could arise a gap within the team which could lead to instability. An example of a team could be a tennis team. All members of a tennis team share the goal of winning and they want each other to play as good as possible in order to do so.

When explaining the differences between a group and a team it would be first relevant to define the two forms. 
A group is a number of people that have a relationship to one another while the participants are loosely connected and the people do not focus on a specific outcome/ a common purpose but are working on their one. 
The team is also a group of people that are (differently from a normal group) additionally involved in the same activity with a common goal especially referring to sports and work. There the participants are strongly connected and all focus on a specific outcome and they require coordination of tasks and activities so the members need to work together.

Considering both definitions the difference is clear: both the group and the team are a group but the team additionally has a common purpose such that all participants are connected, work together and have the same focus on a specific outcome. 

An example for this difference might be a group of friends. While they all like to spend time together they do not need to have a main goal that they work on together as if the same friend group works on a school project. It may still be the same group but the involvement of the project gives them a common purpose that they did not have before and they now need to work together with the common goal of getting a good grade.

Another example might be a travel group. If a friend of mine organises a trip to a resort with 10 people where I do not now either of the 8 additional people we are still a group going to a place where we still can do everything on our own and decide to spend our time alone. If we now decide to participate in a sports event at that resort, let's say a soccer tournament where our group plays against another team we are one team because we share the goal of winning the tournament while working together to that goal.

Team is a group of people who are involved in the same activity and focus on the same goal.
For example a team in badminton tries to win in a competition against another club. The common goal is to achieve victory against another team. Another example of team is in the lecture EIST. People form a team to solve software problems to get bonus points as common goal. Whereas in a group the participants are loosely connnected and every individual works on his own. For instance students at TUM are all part of TUM, but every student works on his own progress. Another example are employees in a company. They form a group of employees of a company but every employee works in a different department and tries to achieve the goals set by the executives of the department.
