Participants in groups are loosely connected, whereas participants in teams are strongly connected.
For example, in a team that follows Scrum the participants in the team communicate more often than ones in groups because they are strongly connected and see the importance of outcome  .
Different to groups, teams focus on a common goal and the outcome values more. 
The tasks in teams need to be coordinated and allocated. 
Members in groups often do their own job. So, there is less teamwork. 
For example, four students as a group are given the task that they should collect news in four different areas reported in the past one week. During the task they hardly ever communicate except that who choose which area.

Difference between groups and teams:

One difference is that all members of a team have the same goal, whereas each member of a group has different goal.
Example: A group joins together to develop a specific program. The program has a common basic function/feature that each member wants to use, but each member wants to implement an individual feature that is useful only to themselves. So those features are only developed by the person, who wants it and added to the program.
In difference, each member of a team wants all features implemented and all members are working together to implement all features, regardless of personal interest.

A second big difference is the communication.
In a group, communication between individual members is usually minimal and significantly worse than in comparison to a team.
Example: A team holds frequent meetings to discuss current status, issues and future planning and as a result can work efficiently with less conflicts, whereby a group may only have loosely contact via a ticket system (for example GitHub issues)  and each individual member does not know what another does, which can lead to  an inefficient way of working, as several members could be working on the same feature, unnecessarily doing the same work multiple times and wasting time and recourses.

explanation:
A group is a collection of individuals with separate priorities united by their shared interests or experiences. Members have individual goals and accountability for their own success or failure. While they work separately, group members have a common interest that binds them together.
Wheras a team is a collection of interdependent people brought together by a shared goal. Members have individual as well as shared accountability for the team’s success or failure.

example: 
a group of students sitting in an EIST tutor group who few common goals like learning and nailing the exam but each one works individially to achieve them VS. a team of students for the project that is part of the homework whose members have to work together and back up each other in order to finish the project and get the bonus. each member of the team depend on the other not only on themself.

Der Unterschied zwischen einem Team und einer Gruppe ist das Verhältnis, in dem die Mitglieder zueinander stehen. Während in einer Gruppe eher keine oder eine geringe Verbindung besteht, da die Teilnehmer z.B. "unfreiwillig" zusammen sind wie in einem Uni-Kurs, gibt es in einem Team ein stärkeres Zusammenhanggefühl, da mehr Gemeinsamkeiten und/oder ein gemeinsames Ziel besteht, z.B. bei einer benoteten Gruppenarbeit. Da dieses Team ein Ziel verfolgt und ein Ergebnis erreichen wollten, müssen sie stark zusammenarbeiten und dadurch entsteht eine Verbindung. in einer Gruppe arbeitet jeder für sich selbst und verfolgt nur ein privates Ziel und kein gemeinsames. Erkennen lässt sich das auch an einem professionellen Sportteam, z.B Volleyball. Dieses Team könnte den Ziel Meisterschaft haben. Eine Freizeitgruppe, die sich nur ab und zu trifft, hat kein wirkliches gemeinsames Ziel.

In a group, the people potentially know one another, however they each strive to fulfill their individual goals, which are typically not directly connected to the goals of the other people. The gym could be a good example for a group. Members of the gym know each other from going there regularly, but everyone has their own preferences in terms of training and outcome. No greater sense of shared purpose can be found. 



In contrary to that, the members of a team do share that common purpose and goal, for which they all contribute a relevant part. In order to coordinate the team, good communication and coordination is necessary. The medical attendees of a surgery are a great example of the dynamics of a team. Their common goal is to do the best job for the patient and everyone knows, exactly, what to do and when to do that. 

They must trust each other and rely on the other team members. At the gym, one does not need to worry about the others and their performance. If the performance of one of the doctors is bad, the others will and have to support or take over his or her work.

Definition: 

A group is a formation of 2 or more people that behave a lot more like individuals that work separately with no common purpose and no particular relationship with one another.

By undergoing a multistaged development process, a group can become a team and so the individuals consisting the team will develop a strong relationship with one another and work together, in a coordinated manner, to fulfill a common goal.


Examples:

1. The student body of a university works a lot like a group of people because they all focus on themselves as individuals and do not necessarily have any kind of relationship with one another nor might work to achieve the same common goal. 

In contrast, a football team has strong connections between the individual member and at the same time all member work together to achieve a common goal, namely winning a certain football match.


2. Inside a company often certain teams develop which consists of individuals that work together to finish certain tasks in a coordinated manner.

Another example of a group is a group of friends, which can be very diverse, and each individual has its own passions and interests and works individually and not necessary for the same goal.

----------------------------------------------L01E03 Group vs Team------------------------------------------------------
*On one hand a group is a specific number of people with some sort of relationship. They are not really connected and work individually. That's why we can say that the focus in a group is not mainly on a common purpose. 
An example can be a group of students sitting in the same lecture hall : we can consider the common Lecture as the relationship between them, but they are mostly working individually to succeed.

*On the other hand a team is any group of people (we can imagine that the Team class is a subclass of the Group class) whose members are strongly connected. They coordinate to work together on a common goal.
Most examples come from sport and work : a football team, a team working on a project, they do clearly have a common object, on which they all perform together.

Differences

1 The connection between group members are looser than team members.
2 Group members don't necessarily focus on a common goal while team members do.
3 Group members work alone while team members work together.


Example 1

All students studying EIST form a group,
- they are loosely connected, because some knows each other while others don't
- they have their own goals for studying EIST: some want earn nice grade in exams, some want to push their skills to a higher level and some just want to make friends
- they work alone on their own homework respectively

while every 5 to 7 of them form a team working on the same goal: die Projektaufgabe
- they are strongly connected and know the character, way of thinking and strengths and weaknesses of each other very well
- they share a common goal, namely finishing the project assignment and demonstrate their work as best as they can
- predictably, they will work (as a scrum) together


Example 2

All professional football players in Munich form a group,
- they are loosely connected, not all of them knows each other very well
- they don't necessarily focus on a common goal: some play football for earning more in professional carriers, some play football so that their body become healthier while some just play for fun.
- they don't necessarily (and it's also impossible for them) play football together

while Bayern München form a team that works on the common outcome: score more goals
- they are stringly connected with a shared vision and full trust in all other teammates
- they focus on the same objective: score more goals!
- they train together so that they become and stay a high performing team

A group is a number of people that have a relationship to one another. And the participants are loosely connected, they do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose and every individual works on his own.
A Team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work. The participants are strongly connected, focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities. Members need to work together.

Groups and Teams are very different, while they both consist of multiple people, the mindset behind them is very different. In a team they all work together to achieve a goal they all share, for example in sports teams like handball, groups, on the other hand, are only loosely connected in which they might have similar interests but they don't all work together to achieve the same goal. Another difference is that teams need to rely on their teammates in order to achieve their common goal, groups on the other hand might help each other out, but they are usually only working by themselves. 

an example of a group would be a fanbase of for example a TV show: they are loosely connected through liking the show, but they don't work together to achieve any goal, but might communicate with each other.

an example of a team would be the already mentioned handball team: they have to work together in coordination to score a goal or defend against the enemy team, otherwise, they will easily be defeated by them.

Teams:
	- Work together on the same Goal
	- help eachother
	- get to know eachother better over time

Groups:
	- Hardly know each other
	- Dont work together on the same Project

Group - Typically slightly more arbitrary and general than a team, can include non-living entities
All teams may be considered groups, however not vice versa
A pure group of people could for example be all students currently attending a lecture in IN0006. To then create teams, we could, for the group projects, break everyone up into smaller groups and give them a common goal. These separate groups could then also be referred to as teams
Examples of groups may be as arbitrary as haphazardly picking out streets on google maps and grouping them based off of the city; the streets have little to do with each other and have no common goal

Team - A group very likely with the expectation that there is a commonly sought-after goal. The team may be broken off into sub teams, however the ultimate target would very likely be similar, if not exactly the same
Examples would be sports teams, or nearly any activity that involves groups of people facing off against each other attempting to win, and in most cases having to work together in unison in order to effectively do so

A group consists of multiple people who may have also been randomly selected. They also might not be willing to communicate and/or solve the given task.

A team is formed to complete a certain task, and the people in it have to constantly interact with each other and provide feedback to make it work.

A group is like a bunch of random ants, crawling in various directions with no common goal. A team is like ants coming together to form a bridge or carry a big insect with their united strength. Teams have a common goal and use their skills to achieve it together, interacting and communicating with each other as they do so. Meanwhile groups are just loose collections of individuals, who do what they want at the moment.

A group consists of people that mostly work on their own to achieve individual goals, which might be very different or even contradictory. They are loosely connected with each other, meaning that they can still be recognized as a group by some shared attribute. However, they might not have a relationship among each other. 

A team is group of people working together to achieve a shared goal or vision. The team members have a personal or professional relationship among each other and usually split the tasks in a way that the skillset of each individual is applied maximally to achieve the best possible result.

4 sprinters are just a group of athletes if they compete on their own. For each sprinter, only their personal success is important to them. However, the groups of athletes becomes a team if they decide to take part in a relay race together, where they have to work "hand-in-hand" to win.

Similarly, doctors working in a hospital are a group and usually have their own patients. They can form a team if they have to work together during an operation to save a patient's life.

Groups:
An example for a group is a newly founded football team. At first, some members of the team might already know each other but also some new people exist in the newly formed team. What you'll often experience is that groups of 2-3 people keep on playing/interacting together. They don't concentrate on a common goal just yet, such as winning the league. That often results in eleven one man shows where everybody tries to perform the best on its own.

Team:
It is up to the trainer to form a team. He needs to create a network of connections between the different groups. In that way, people get to know each other. They see different qualities in people and might consider asking them to perform the free kick for example. If they manage to share the common goal of winning the league, they start to coordinate tasks and by doing so form a team.

The difference between a groups and a teams lies in their performance, goals and the time they spend together. While a teams forms after a extended period of time, has shared goals, and acts to achieve those, a group is more loosely connected and doesn't work together as effectively. Therefore a team automatically contains features of a group but not vice-versa. A team most likely develops out of a group. 
One example would be the difference between a university research team and a highschool presentation team. While the university students will come from different fields for at least one semester and want to achieve some succcess. They will therefore transition into a fuctioning team, where everybody acts towards the shared goal. The pupils are most likely only put together for a few days so they won't even manage to become a working team in that time especially if some pupils don't even want to get a good grade and therefore lack the common goal. 
Another example could be between a football team and a group of people that met on the football field. The first team has already played a lot of matches together and works together to score goals and win. While the other group most likely has the same goal, the individual players are more likely to act in their own interest and they don't have a connection like the football team does.

Group:
A group is a collection of people who are there to just get the work done. They are loosely bound to one another. Such a collection of people is not at all work efficient, and the people in a group may prefer to work alone instead. In times of hardships and adversities, a group may not perform to its full potential and may even collapse. 

Team:
On the other hand, a team is a collection of people who are more interactive with one another. Such a collection of people is very work efficient because such people usually work together and help each other, thus building trust, and understanding between each other. Because the people in a team work together, they are really strong in the face of hardships and adversities.

1)Example:
A good example would be people in a tag hurdle running race. In such a race, a team would outperform a group in many ways. In teams, the members would trust one another and may even know the weaknesses and strong points of one another. For example, one person might be a fast runner but be bad at jumping over obstacles.  In a team, people would communicate and come to a perfect solution and allocation and work hard towards a better result.
In comparison, in a group, people would communicate less with one another and members might even hesitate to showcase their strong and weak points.
Such a group would not be efficient and will not achieve their goal in a perfect way.

2)Example:
Another good example would be a group of firefighter vs a team of firefighters.  In a team of firefighters, the members would trust one another more because this work has a risk to a person's life.

In a team members would trust one another more which would lead to better results. 
In comparison, a group would not perform better.  Because if 2 members in a group do not communicate freely and trust one another it would not bring out the best parts in the both members which would make the members more hesitant in doing their work efficiently because one wrong step would have terrible consequences.

(Some words are used from my own explanation from last year's EIST Course and are my own idea and examples)

The term "Group" stands for a group of people brought together by something in common. Nothing more than that. 
A "Team" instead represents a group of people that have to directly work together and usually have a task in common.

A group of people could be a school class or even a group of people using the same bus. Both of these groups are brought together by something in common, although they don't have to really talk to each other or work together to archive something.
Meanwhile, a team could be a basketball team, directly united to take a common win home, or even a family committed to each other to guarantee each other's wellbeing.

A group is a combination of people that have no common goal that is worked towards in cooperation, but individually.
	- people on the street are random and have individual goals to achieve  
A team in contrast is a closely connected group of people that has a common goal and works tirelessly to achieve it in cooperation.
	-a pit stop crew is a tightly coordinated and cooperative team that works to a single goal

Group:
- loosely connected number of people that have some kind of relationship with each other
- every person is working on their own
-> A Karate group is training together but each person is working independendly towards increasing their own skills and gaining a higher belt rank

Team:
- number of people that work together towards one shared goal, which they benefit all from - coordination is key 
- > A football team that can only succeed and climb up the ranks, if everyone works together as a single unit and supports each other.

As opposed to a group, a team is typically characterized by a specific common goal that all members actively work towards. A team relies heavily on interpersonal communication, coordination and unity.
On the other hand, a group usually does not have a defined objective. Its members are only loosely connected and they do not cooperate.

Possible examples of teams include successful football teams such as FC Bayern München. A football team is comprised of multiple players. They all try to contribute as much as they can towards winning games and championships, either by scoring goals or by preventing opponents from scoring goals. They usually do this in a very organized fashion: Every participant has a clear role in the team (e.g. goalkeeper, midfielder, coach etc.) and they tend to help each other out whenever help is needed/required. Additionally, the coach will normally give the players feedback about their performance (the players might also do this mutually) and about how they could improve.
A different example of a team is a student team working together for a presentation. It is very clear that every member of this team is (or at least should be) very keen on preparing and presenting their topic as good as possible in order to achieve a good grade. In other words, they all have the same goal. They need to coordinate so that everyone knows which part of the presentation they have to prepare and in what order they will present their parts. Since they are supposed to create one full-fledged presentation (not three separate ones merged together), they will undoubtedly need to communicate well so that they can create a sense of fluidity whenever the speaker changes.

The concept of a group is very different from that of a team.
All the people inside a suburban train waggon form a group as they have local proximity in common. However, as opposed to a football team, they do not work together toward a certain objective: The passengers likely have different destinations and most of them probably won't talk to each other since they don't even know each other. Some of them might be heading to their appointment at the barbershop and others might be on their way home from work. Each one of them is responsible for reaching their respective destination and so everybody has a different goal in this scenario.
Similarly, all the customers at a supermarket a part of a group. This group is (obviously) identified by the fact that every single one of its members is a customer of the respective supermarket, but all of these people have varying interests with regard to what they want to purchase and how much money they are willing to pay. Oftentimes people will even enter a store without knowing what they want to buy; they will just browse the shop and decide on the fly. In most cases, customers ignore each other and are not aware of any possible relationship with or connection to any other customer.

As a result of these examples, it (hopefully) became clear that a team is a number of people who actually feel like they are all part of one instance. On the contrary, people in a group will prioritize their own personal interests over those of the crowd.

Team: it is a group of people that can work together in order to deliver any project or goal, where every person adds up some value. Ideally the team is intercultural and they not only have computer science skills but also soft skills.

Group: It is a group of people who work together but not necessary is a high performance team.

The difference between a group and a team is that a team operates using a common set of values in order to realise a specific, agreed upon outcome. A team shares a single vision and works on the premise that the output will be optimal if everyone works with and supports each other. 
In contrast, a group refers to a set of people who can be grouped together using a specific context. For example, all students at tum under 20 can be described as a group of people, which are connected in regards to their age, but nothing more. This means, that a group of people dont necessarily have to work together or strive towards a larger goal. 
Examples: 
3 Friends founding a Start-up and working to realise their dream would be called a team, provided that they work well together and have a shared vision for the company. A class of stundents working on an exam would be a group, since the students are connected based on their activity but work only for themselves.

Der größte Unterschied zwischen einer Gruppe und einem Team ist, dass in einem Team ein allgemeines Ziel festgelegt ist und für das erreichen des Ziels jede Person aus dem Team einen Beitrag leisten muss und in einer Gruppe Personen mit ähnlichen Attributen oder Zielen versammelt sind, aber nicht alle zusammen arbeiten müssen. Somit ist ein Team eine Gruppe, aber nicht jede Gruppe ein Team:

Beispiel:
Group exercise
Wie der Name hergibt, handelt es sich um eine Gruppenaufgabe und somit um eine Gruppe an Menschen, da alle Mitglieder der Gruppe zusammen die Aufgabe erfüllen wollen und ähnliche Fähigkeiten haben. Allerdings ist das Ziel, dass diese Gruppe zu einem Team wird, in dem jedes Mitglied seine eigenen Fähigkeiten einsetzt und alle zusammen es schaffen das Problem zu lösen (Beispiel 1: Gruppe & Team). Wenn allerdings Mitglieder der Gruppe nichts zur Lösung beitragen, handelt es sich nicht mehr um eine Gruppe sondern um ein Team (Beispiel 2: nur Gruppe & nicht Team).

People in a group do not necessarily know each other as well, and most importantly, they do not participate in common tasks. For example, all TUM Informatics students are a group of people generally. However, when they are split into Teams in the tutor lessons, the select few of them work together on an exercise or task and help each other and solve the common task.

Both words are used to describe a number of people. In a group, the relationship of the members with each other is rather vague and they will work individually according to their own goals. In a team, however, the participants share a stronger bond in form of e.g. a mutual purpose and support each other while working towards achieving it together.
In this sense, a team of surgeons that are operating on a patient can be given as an example. Even though all of them are responsible with different missions (i.e. holding the light, carrying the surgical tools, operating on the patient, etc.) they are serving to one common goal, completing the operation. A similar example would be a team of lawyers working on a case. Whereas a crowd of people waiting at a government office to apply for some legal documents of their own or a gathering of strangers waiting at a line to buy food could be given as instances for groups, as they have no shared purpose, but each their own.

The difference between a group and a team, among other things, consists in the way how the different members interact together. While a group doesn't actively cooperate, cooperation is key in teams. Additionally, those team members have a common vision or goal while group members don't have a shared goal. Team members are aligned rather closely while the connection between group members is rather loose. 

While for example all people living in Munich would be considered a group, friends doing a project together would be considered a team. People who live in Munich don't actively seek each others cooperation whereas friends who do a project together need to cooperate in order to achieve a common goal - finishing their project. Munich citizens don't have a common goal - while both infants and seniors are members of the group of the citizens of Munich, they don't have a common goal nor vision. Additionally, the loose connection between members inside a group is seen rather good in the fact people inside a group may not even know each other at all while team members have to know the people they work with in order to succeed.

A group is a collection of people with some sort of connection that links them together. There is usually no shared goal a group works toward and cooperation is kept at a minimum.  An example would be a call center, in which the employees keep to their own cubicles and do their work without having to rely on their coworkers.

A team is a group with both a shared objective as well as the need to cooperate with eachother. The execution of a goal or project has to be discussed and planned out between all members and every individual's work impacts the rest of the team. An example here would be the kitchen staff in a busy restaurant, where different steps of the cooking process will be handled by several people. If one member can't keep the pace the whole meal gets held up.

One of the differences between groups and teams is that the participants of a group are loosely connected whereas the participants of a team are strongly connected. For example: someone gets into an EIST group with 4 strangers and they don't meet up to work together. They just work on their own and don't really want to connect with the other members of the group. A team would meet up every week to work together on the tasks and also have a little fun while doing it together. They form a good connection which helps to produce a good result.

Another difference is that group members work individually/alone, they rarely or never meet up to work together. A team meets up often and work together. The example from above explains it better. (look at line 2-6)

The next difference is that people in a group don't focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose whereas the participants of a team focus on a specific outcome and work towards the same goal. For example: Participants of a group just work for themselves, they just want to do their part or even less and don't care about the outcome of the work. In a team everyone has the same goal/vision and gives their best to produce a good outcome.

1.The participants of group are loosely connected, but in a team, participants are strongly connected. 
2.A group do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose, but a team focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities.
3. In a group ,every individual works on his own.In a team , members need to work together.

Examples: 
All the students of summer semester at TUM are a group, they are loosely connected, maybe have different lectures or different majors. And most students have different purpose, maybe someone just wants to graduate quickly, or someone wants a good grades, etc. What's more , every students works on his own.

Five students form a team in EIST Lecture, this team are strongly connected, they may communicate frequently.  The students in this team focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities: finish EIST projects effectively and perfectly.  And for achieving the common goal, they need to work together.

Eine Gruppe besteht aus Mitgliedern welche keine besonders gute Beziehung zueinander haben, da Gruppen meist groß sind und als einzige Beziehung eine passive Beziehung haben, so wie das Besuchen einer gemeinsamen Vorlesung. Sie arbeiten nicht miteinander, sondern alleine. Im Gegensatz dazu steht ein Team, das einem gemeinsamen Ziel entgegeneifert und daran zusammen arbeitet. Sie haben eine starke Beziehung zueinander, da sie eine gute Kommunikation untereinander brauchen, um ihr Ziel zu erreichen.

Als Beispiel für eine Gruppe, kann man eine Tutorübung nennen. Die Mitglieder dieser haben als Beziehung zusammen zu dieser Tutorübung zu gehen, ihr Ziel ist jedoch nicht das gleiche. Während der eine vielleicht die Übungen nutzt um eine 1,0 zu bekommen, besucht der andere sie nur damit er das Fach besteht. Vor allem aber arbeiten sie nicht zusammen an einem Ziel, bei welchem Kommunikation und Beziehung zueinander entscheidend ist. Anders ist das bei einem Team, wie zum Beispiel eins das zusammen an einem Website Design arbeitet. Sie haben alle das gemeinsame Ziel diese Website zu gestalten. Es ist wichtig das im Team kommuniziert wird, wo welches Element hingesetzt wird. Verschiedene Meinungen und Ideen müssen besprochen werden und eine Entscheidung getroffen werden, das klappt nur wenn die Beziehung unter den Mitgliedern besser ist als bei einer Gruppe.

While in a group the participants are only interested in their own goals and everyone needs to put full effort into achieving them on their own, in a team the goal is for every participant the same and everyone takes a small part to achieve the big goal for the team as a whole. A school class for example for most of the time is a group as anyone is just interested in their grades which they need to achieve on themselves. Of course there are team projects in school classes too, but not nearly as much as the students need to work for themselves. A self-sufficient village on the other hand is a team all the time as it has the aim to survive. Everyone needs to take a part in it and needs to put their share of effort into their community so that there is always enough food, clothes, water and so on.

Group consists of more entities, which can have something in common or nothing at all and they are characterised as one single entity consisting of more entities.

Team is a group of entities, which are desired to have something in common(something which connects them as together) and do something collaboratively to achieve one goal.

Team of players in a sport play together to win against other team.
Team of developers in a company work together to create a program collaboratively by creating modules and connecting them to single program.

+++++Groups+++++
Groups are a collection of individuals with similar characteristics/ ideologies/ interests/ personality traits, thus specific traits distinguishes different groups of people. But each member of the group still function as autonomous individuals, therefore follow (mainly) their own interests/ ideas as their highest priority. In a Work (or similar) setting the individual growth, responsibility, independence and success (of their own mission) is above all else.

Pros: 
+ could be faster, as they are independent
+ individual growth

Cons:
- Loneliness and having not a sense of working for a "greater good"
- not being keen on working on the goals of a company, because everyone "just does their own thing"

Example: An artist collective. Though they each have the same mission of creating art and displaying/ selling it and even may help each other, they are mostly keen on working on their own individual success and are each independently responsible for it. 


++++++Teams+++++
A Team on the other hand is a collection of individuals with similar goals/ visions/ a common purpose. Therefore a team is really the sum of it's parts and every member is not only welcomed, but is essential for the success of their shared vision (at least in a good team of high performers), as the German saying states "Die Kette ist nur so stark wie ihr schwächstes Glied". 
Pros:
+ productivity because it is human nature to work together, because it is more fun
+ clear agreements and group allocation
+ coming together for a greater good
+ better for problem solving

Cons:
- dependency
- slowness because of individual members
- lack of individual growth

Example: The Marketing and Design apartment of the startup I'm working in. Even though we also create art (like the collective stated above), we work together as a team for a greater good -> the success of our company. Because we compliment each other with our individual skills and because everything is clear in our agreements, we are efficient and good at problem solving. But we are dependent on each other, so it takes longer when for example I'm waiting for ideas from our UI/ UX designer for my work.

A group of soldiers with various specializations are stationed in a military base. If a part of that group is deployed to a specific mission, they form a team for that mission.

A group of students attends a lecture. If the lecture requires them to collaborate on a project together (in sub-groups) the respective students form a team.

A group is i.e. a group of students. They are a number of people that have som erelatioship to one another. The Students are loosely connected. They don`t have a common goal and everyone works for his own.

A team on the other side is for example a football team: it consists of a group of people involved in the same acitivity with a common goal. The teammembers  are strongly connected. They have a specific goal and all of them pursue the same goal. That requires coordination of tasks and activities. The most important point is, that all the members need to work together.

Sportteams are probably the best example of teams. They work towards a common goal and combine their individual strengths wether that's being the goalkeeper, the striker or in the defense. Only if they play together, they even stand as much as a chance as winning against another team.
Sticking to the sports theme, a fitness class does most often not work in the same way.
The attendees might share the goal to improve, but primarily themselves and less as a unit. It won't effect them too much if someone else in the group might not be able to keep up and therefore there is little motivation to support each other for the sake of the group's success. The trainer probably won't face any consequences either if a part of the class can't follow their speed.

The lecture mentioned multiple differences between groups and teams.
While groups are a number of people that are somehow connected to each other because of many possible circumstances, a team is connected through a common goal or activity.
Additionally, people in a team will benefit from working with each other, which is not true in a group.

In my opinion, the main difference between the two concepts is the fact that people in a team have some sort of responsibility towards their common goal, while a group is loosely connected and implies no common responsibility at all. For example, a group could be people waiting on a line in a grocery store. They are doing the same thing and might split into another line if the cashiers tell them that another checkout has opened, but they are each on their own and have no common goals. On the other hand, people working on the supermarket are a team: they have some responsibilities and will coordinate themselves (in this case, with the help of a manager) to fulfill all the jobs that need to be done, while having with these tasks as a common goal in mind.
Teams > Groups

The difference between a group and a team is that a group is an association of people, who only share some sort of connection but do not interacting with each other to reach a certain goal. Whereas a team, is a group of people that do work together and assist each other to reach a goal that can only be achieved by interaction.

One example of a group would be football fans for a certain team, together they are not productive or trying to achieve a goal but they share a common preference for a team. The football team itself is (as the name indicates) a team, because it is made out of a group of people sharing the love for football but also working together to reach the goal of winning a game.

Another example for a group are people who listen to the same music genre. As the example above, groups divide people from other people or "categorize" them by their connection. In this example, there might be a group of people who like rock and another group that likes jazz. But again, those groups don't work towards a goal. A band, on the other hand, can be described as a team, because they are linked by their passion for music and work together to produce a song. The outcome itself depends on their exchange and interaction, because the different instruments have to play in sync, for example.

1)Teams rely more than  groups on discussion, debate, and decision making, and on sharing information and exchanging ideas. We can only finish our own work without sharing ideas in a group,but  in a team we have to know each other's idea.
2) Groups take fewer risks than teams. Groups do not seek collective work performance that require concerted effort. When people choose teams over groups, they assume the necessary risks of conflict in order to establish common goals.

For example, people meet each other to learn for an exam. So they are a group because everyone has their own goal and is aiming for a different grade, so they work individually and only discuss if they have any questions. But if they have to do a PowerPoint presentation, they are a team because everyone is working on the same project(they have to work together )  and they want to accomplish a team goal

In a team is more structure than in just a group. 
There are not only member, there is a teamleader and also differnent other kinds of posiotion. 
Also got a memeber in a team responsibility for some things, in a group you often only do work together but it's not really divided.

The concepts of “team” and “groups” refer to similar ideas, but they carry important differences. 

A group is essentially composed of several people which are “grouped” together (hence the name) because they work on similar things. All software developers in a company for example are in a group, they all need to program. However, they don’t work together to achieve a common goal. One works on User Interface, perhaps another’s responsibility is Print Functionality. 
A further example might be different waiters in a restaurant. 

In a team however, the connection between the members is strong; trust and a sense of togetherness exists. Team members must coordinate their efforts in order to achieve a more complex goal which they share. A team of Car Engineers must harness each other’s strengths and weaknesses to optimize their work. Only thus can their labor result with a functioning reliable automobile. 
A further instance of team would probably be a Start-Up. They must mingle efficiently, or face extinction.

Groups are some kind of people that have same interests, but don't involved in working together, for example, students on lectures of EIST.
Teams are the groups of people involved in working together to achieve appointed goals, for example, game developers.

a group is a number of loosely connected persons in the same situation each working individually
a team consists of co-dependent and strongly connected members working together to achieve a shared goal

Groups are people who are in a relationship with each other, although they may have different goals and work alone. Teams, on the other hand, are made up of deeper connected people. They organize themselves together to achieve a common goal and work with each other.

Examples:
1) People in a same university class are a group as they are studying the same subject. In contrast, people working together on an assignment for the course and doing a final presentation together are a team.
2) The employees of a large company form a group because they share the commonality of having the same employer. A set of people working on a project within a company to reduce costs form a team because they all work together to achieve this common goal.

One difference between a grop and a team is, that a team has common goal, which the team members try to archieve. To do so, they split up the whole process and every member does her part. A group has no common goal to achieve and so every member of a group try to archieve individual goals, not necessarily related to the goals of the other members.

Another difference is how the members of teams and groups are connected to each other. To be a member of a group, it does not require commitment or participation by the members. A bunch of people can be assigned to a group for instance to structure a company. But to be part of a team, it requires an active commitment, participation and communication of each member to generate added value.

In a Group the people may not work towards a common goal, may not know each other too well and are probably just connected through a shared interest. Where’s in a Team the people work towards a common goal, know each other well and are associated together in e.g. work. 
For example track & field.  The people train together but want to achieve their personal goal. Thus it is just a group. In soccer people are a team because they work towards a common goal e.g. winning. 

Another example for a team would be if they work in a company together on a company project where they also work towards a common goal and have to know each other well to know strength and weaknesses to divide task efficiently. Another example for group would be if people develop a product where tasks can be very differently like developing the idea, production and marketing where the people have more or less different goals and don’t have to know each other too well.
Bei Gruppen hat jeder eigene Ziele, im Team arbeitet man für ein Ziel. Teams formen sich für einen Zweck, Gruppen meist weil sich die Leute miteinander abhängen wollen

A group members has individual goals
A team members have shared goals

A group is unstructured
A team is strucutred where everyone has assigned roles

In Groups participants are loosely connected, while in teams they are strongly connected. Also, in groups the people do not focus on a specific outcome, but in teams they do and that requires a good coordination of tasks. And lastly, in groups everyone can work on their own, while in teams members need to work together.

My first example: In a lecture, the students are loosely connected because they don’t need to get know each other. Also they don’t need to have a common goal, as every student can set his own goal for the lecture. Also, every student in the end works on his own, as the exam typically is done alone.

My second example: In a work team, which programs an app, the workers are highly connected because everyone needs to exchange and there has to be somewhere a boss, which also gets information. Secondly, everyone clearly works on the same outcome, that the app gets released and works perfectly. And lastly, everyone needs to work together because if not, the app would work because the single pieces of the workers wouldn’t fit together.

A group is a collection of individuals having individual goals, responsibilities, decision making and success or failure. Society for example is a group where each individual has his own goals, accountability and decisions that he only assumes the outcome while a team is collection of people having common goals, individual and mutual responsibilities and collective outcome of the decision making ,that can be mutual or individual but when individual it must be the good of the team since members of the team rely on one another to accomplish the . We can take example of football teams. The team have a plan (tactics) to achieve a common goal (win the game) and all members of the team cooperate to achieve that mutual goal.

Group is a quantity of people, who have relationship with each other. They must not have something in common except their close relationship between the people in the group. Team is a quantity of people, who do not have to be close necessarily, but have a common goal and work together with each other towards this goal.

A group of people is a rather unspecific collection of people based on a superficial or very broad connection between them. You can base groups of people on broad facts like their current place, their origin, or the language they are speaking. These facts can be seen by any person from the outside and people in a group don't have to necessarily share any common characteristics. People in a group have individual goals which are not directly affected by other group members directly.

Unlike that, the team is a group of people who are working on a common task or goal, thus already share stronger specific interests (at least related to a shared task) and often stronger bonds as well. Because all team members share the tasks, goals and thus also the outcome, focussing on individual success is both hindering for both the individual and the team, that is why the team members are forced to work together and focus on the goal of collective success.

While the people within a group hardly know each other, if at all, and pursue their own purely egoistic interests, a team is a group of people who act together as a single entity. In contrast to a loosely connected group, a team pursues a common goal in which everyone works together. In a group, individual interests become secondary and the achievement of the larger goal becomes the priority. It is essential that the individual members of the team communicate, work together, rely on each other and trust each other. This is in stark contrast to a group of people who are similar and perhaps even pursue similar interests, but try to achieve them completely independently of each other.

A group is just a number of people who have a releationship to one another, they are not as connected as a team and work on their individiual goals. They do not focus on a specific outcome or a common purpose.

A team is also a group of people who have all have a goal together and mostly the people in the team are connected.
In order to archieve their goal the have to work together, communicate and coordinate their tasks and activities.
A Group is a collection of people, where there might be connection of the people in between, while a team is a collection of people, with an alligned goal.

A Group is a Collection of people. They are loosely connected and mostly have nothing in Common.

A Team is closely connected and works towards a common goal.

A group is a number of people who are only loosely coupled and do not focus on achieving a goal together but rather work for themselves. A team in comparison is a number of strongly coupled people focussing on achieving a common goal together. 

Example 1: In a big company existing of many small companies have a number of employees, which would be a good example for a group. The employees from company A do rarely know the employees from company B. They do not work together to achieve a common goal, hardly know each other, and are loosely connected. Whereas company A or better a department X in company A is a good example of a team. The employees in department X know each other, work together to achieve a common goal, and are constantly communicating. In some cases, they mutually depend on each other and are strongly coupled. 

Example 2: A sports club offering a lot of different sports activities has a lot of club members that are not playing or interacting with each other, e.g. a jogging team and a football team do not work together on a common goal or do not depend on each other, so they are loosely coupled and therefore the members of a sports club are only a group. But a team within a sports club e.g. a football team works closely together to achieve a goal together. They know each other and depend mutually on each other. A goalkeeper can not defend the ball without having other players in the defense e.g. that try to fend off the ball or stop other players from the opposite team.

Eine Gruppe ist ist erstmal nur eine Anzahl an Menschen, welche grobe und nicht intensive Beziehungen miteinander haben. Mitglieder einer solchen Gruppe arbeiten meist alleine an der Aufgabe und beziehen sich nicht auf Fortschritte oder Ergebnisse, der anderen Mitglieder.

Ein Team hingegen hat starke und intensive Beziehungen über die Zeit aufgebaut und arbeitet zusammen um an das gemeinsame Ziel zu kommen. Die Mitglieder arbeiten in einem organisiertem Umfeld miteinander, um gewünschte Ergebnisse effizient zu liefern. Die Zusammenarbeit und Bezugnahme auf die Mitglieder ist essentiell, um ein Team zu sein.

The main difference between a Group and a Team is the work ethic:
While a the members of a group just know each other loosely and do not embrace community,
team colleagues are tightly connected and know each other well. This connection results in better quality of work because teams work together, while group members  just work on their own, without a common coordination and feedback.
The aim of every Team should be a output oriented. Every team member sticks to this common goal by embracing team spirit by maintaining  good communication and helping the other team members.

Both a team and a group consist of several people who have a certain relationship to each other.

A team is more than that. A team is a group of people engaged in an activity with a common goal and focused on a common purpose. People on a team need to work together, so the members of a team are closely related to each other.

A group of students attending the same course of study can be considered a group. They are connected to each other because they have chosen the same course of study. The participants are often only loosely connected, they are not focused on a specific outcome, and often each individual works on his or her own.

An ice hockey team, on the other hand, can be considered a team because they really need to work together or they will not be able to achieve the desired result, such as winning a tournament. People have the same task and are therefore strongly connected with each other.

In a team everyone knows each other very well. The team's members share the same vision and they organize themselves in order to archieve that vision. A team works together - that's why they communicate a lot. Trust is a key aspect aswell.

For example a group and a team are told to develop a simple calculator.

In the group each invidual starts imaging his or her own vision of the final product. After a short amount of time there might be several competing drafts. One person might want to focus on simplicity another person might want to focus on supporting complex arithmetic calculations. The group fails to agree on the application's features, there are some unproductive arguments but there is no properly organized communication.

The team starts with a kickoff meeting brainstorming ideas together. They begin to establish a shared vision. They want develop a simple calculator. After that they agree on a list of features (addition, subtraction, multiplication, ...)... and simply start working! Each team member has its own job, e.g. Emma is responsible for modeling the application, Tom is the app designer creating a few nice looking drafts and so on.

Eine Gruppe ist ein Verbund von Leuten die über ein gemeinsames Attribut bzw. eine gemeinsame Eigenschaft eine Verbindung haben, beispielsweise bei einer Fan-Gruppe einer Band, bei der jedes Individuum über das "Fansein" miteinander verbunden ist. Wobei die einzelnen Individuen nicht miteinander interagieren um ein gemeinsames Ziel zu erreichen, jeder arbeitet primär für sich alleine ohne ein unbedingtes umfassendes Ziel, wie z.B in einer Vorlesung bei der jeder Student alleine der Vorlesung folgt.

A group is just a bunch of people who are not really bound to another. They tend to work individually and sometimes they do not have the same target.

On the other side, a team has the same target or vision. In order to achieve that, they need to work together. The effectiveness of a team is usually much higher than a normal group because they are bonded, they went through several phases of bonding so that they can get to know one to another and know how to work with each other.

1. People in a village stand around a well to get water.
While they all have a common goal: getting water. Their
relation to each other is still too weak.
They need to get together and form a common plan
on how they will achieve their common goal.
After a short collaboration, they form a line in front of the well.
Now they all share a common goal AND plan upon which they act in
coherence, thus they became a team.

2. People stand in front of a wall, which they want to get over.
They all know that they have to work together.
They also know that they have to use a "Räuberleiter" and hold each other up.
But nobody wants to be the bottom person because
the last person left behind will have to RELY on the others
to lift her up at the end. But since there is no TRUST in this group of people, nobody
wants to go first. After learning more about each other in ice breaker activities, they
might develop more trust for each other and be able to overcome the wall.
Now they became a team.

For example, a university is formed by many groups of students, who found their way to study in the same place. They might be working individually towards their own goals. These students, however, can form a team, which could work on a mutual project. I think a group is more of a social matter, without one specific outcome, while in  a team people have to have trust in each other, for them to create their ultimate target.

A group is made up of independent individuals who meet or share a space together due to having something in common. They are loosely connected and in most cases share no common goal. There is not a specific leader, decisions without much coordination. Trust is not so high in between. Synergy between members is neutral or even negative. There are also no assigned roles to members. 
An example of a group would be people sharing a bus or ubahn together. A further example could be a group of people living in a village/town. An example is also all EIST lecture participants versus teams in eist for the project (explained below).

On the other hand, a team is made up of interdependent individuals who come together and join strengths to achieve/accomplish a common goal. A goal set and shared by all of them. Members are strongly connected with each other and trust has to be very high since they all depend on each other. They must work as one as they all share collective accountability. There is a set, agreed-upon leader who manages the team. Synergy between members is mostly positive (it is in their best interest after all). All members have and fulfill a certain role.
The most obvious example of a team is a football/basketball/.... basically any sports team. 
Another example of a team would be the EIST project that we will have to do later this semester. Teams will be formed and we all will work as one.

A group of people is simply the word for multiple human beings connected by one or more properties. As an example, there could exist many people connected by the property, of their geographical location. In this case, people standing randomly next to each other are a group of people. A team is a more specific kind of group. A group has to fulfill many properties, like working together and achieving the same goal, to count as a team. As an example, a football field with 2 teams playing against each other, is altogether a group of footballers. If you begin to split all these footballers by the interest to play and win with specific other footballers, there would be 2 groups of people. Each of these groups shares, in their group, the interest to win the game by working with the people in the same group. In this case, each of these groups is one team.

A team is a close coupled set of people which communicate and work closely together to achieve a goal. Whereas a group is a loose coupled amount of people somehow interacting with each-other but everybody is just minding their own business, without any goals whatsoever.

Group is a set of people who have some connections but everyone might works on their own. Team is a set of people who are strongly connected with each other, collaborate with each other and have a collective goal to achieve. For instance, fans of a sport team is a group. They might support the same sport team but have their own individual lives. Whereas a sport team is a set of players who show passion and ambition, work as a team and try to achieve their goals.

A group is just a number of people working alongside each other without working with each other much. A team is a group of people that work together a lot and have good communication in order to achieve the goals of the team. An example for a group would be random students put together in a tutor-group to solve problems together. They don't know each other and therefore won't have good communication or coordination. A friend group working on a group homework together would be considered a team, since they know each other well and will be able to communicate freely and not be afraid at all to talk up when something goes wrong.

Group is a number people who are only loosely connected to one another. They have a relationship, yet they lack common goals or coordination, working mostly on their own.

Team, on the other hand, consists of a number of people strongly connected by goal, which they then work on in coordination.

An example of a group are students writing their finals. Sure, they are all in the same room, writing the same thing and some of them may even know each other, but even then everyone works for themselves and there is little to no interaction between them.

An example of a team would be a group of GameJam participants. Breaking up the ice in the beginning, getting to know each other, then developing a shared vision on game before working hard and communicating to deliver it.

A team shares a larger goal toward which they work together. They support and trust each other. To be able to build this bond, they have gone through a joint process of team building.
This is not necessary for a group, where goals are to be achieved individually. Only a loose relationship exists between members.
An excellent example of a team is the german national soccer team at the 2006 world Cup. Before the tournament, goalkeepers kahn and lehmann were rivals for a place. In the decisive penalty shootout, however, kahn accepted his role as a substitute and passed on all his expertise about protecting in a secret note to lehmann. In this case, the common goal of the team was more important to him than his own ambition.
An example of a group is a school class. Some students are friends and also help each other with school assignments. Nevertheless, they do not share a common goal. on the contrary, each individual tries to get the best grades for himself. If the grade average is higher, the individual has disadvantages as a result. For example, the grade key can be adjusted.
In an ideal team, the opposite is true: Together Everyone Achieves More.

A group consists of people with similar interests but individual goals and responsibility for their own success or failure. However, a team members share a common goal and also are responsible for the whole team's success/failure.

Example 1: A group of people on a cruise (with a similar interest of relaxing, sunbathing etc) becomes a team when holes appear on the deck and everyone tries to plug them up and save each other from drowning.

Example 2: A group of hikers (with a similar interest of travelling, being active, sight seeing etc) becomes a team when a part of that group stays at the base camp and others (team) climb to the top of the mountain following each other's step, supporting one another and alternating positions.

While a group are a number of people that are loosely connected to one another, a team really sticks together and interpersonal relationships can be best describes by friendship. A group is connected by a weak common denominator such as a lecture or a common field of study. A Team, for example found in road cycling is in contrast to a group there for each other and have a higher aim (such as winning the Tour de France) that strongly connects them. Every member of the team needs to work together to achieve the goal (Winning one of the Mountain Sprints to gain points for the team for example), no one can do it alone. Within a group everyone works on its own and there is no such thing as this higher common goal that all participants are strongly connected to.
While groups can just be put together, such as a lecture in uni, a team needs to grow together and will most likely not work perfectly from day one. In todays fast changing sports environment, one might even argue, that clubs such as FC BAYERN MUNICH is only a group and not a team, because of how fast players switch clubs nowadays.

In online gaming a group could be some players randomly matched into a group. Even tho every player is keen on winning, that is mostly for selfish reasons, mostly because he doesnt realy know the others.

A team in gaming is formed beforehand and they are ofcourse also keen on winning, but because they know each other and care for each other, they will watch out that everyone enjoys themselves, which requires coordination and teamwork.

In sports a group could be a yoga group. Everyone mostly trys to improve themselves and the only connection between the participants is the location and activity, not so much the other individuals.

A team in sports could be a rowing team, where it is of utmost importance, that every row is synchronized and well coordinated.

The common ground of both are that they are a number of people. The key differences between both of them are that:
1. a group has no real personal connections, the group members only know each others names while the team members know about the personalities and strengths of their colleagues  e.g.
2. The group members only do the things they should do without really working together while the team members work together and support each other to fulfill a goal they want to accomplish together. In that case the group members for example are students and listen all to the same lecture while the team members try to do a project for example a smartphone app.

In a group, we have a number of people that have some relationship to one another (loosely connected). Within the group, there is no focus toward a specific outcome. Every individual works on their own.
The people within a Team on the other hand have a common goal. Participants are strongly connected and focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities. To achieve this, members need to work together

When people share an elevator ride, they are a group; when the elevator gets stuck, they become a team. 
I read this a while ago and it stuck with me, as it perfectly points out the difference. 

You see the same, when riding on the train. You are connected by the space you share, the journey, but there is no common goal, since everyone just has to wait. But once the train runs into delays, you can see a structure emerging from within the group, as they now have a focus; to continue their trip. 

Alternatively, school life. Only once stuck into a group for a project do you start to organize your efforts.

Groups are Not working together on something, They are just loosely connected.

Teams have the Same goal. They work together and are strongly connected.

A group includes people with one or more similarities. But a team includes people who are working together to achieve one common goal. 
For example : 

1. In an airplane Passengers are a group (they are all aboard the same airplane)
But the crew are a team (because they are serving the same cause: a pleasant journey for the passengers)

 2. Customers of a company or a group because they have one thing in common (they are all the customers of the company). But on the other hand and the people which are in the company or team and they go is to provide the best quality for their customers.

The difference between groups and teams comes down to the relationship they have. 

For instance a group might not know each other for long bring forward not a lot of trust and friendship, whereas a team knows each other for a long time building strong trust and a strong friendship.

Furthermore, by having a strong friendship, a team can focus their attention on achieving certain goals and can coordinate themselves better. In Contrast, by not having a strong friendship, a group has no certain goals they want to achieve, instead being not as focused as a team.


Lastly, a team works together to solve certain problems and to improve on them, and in a group mostly individuals are working, with rarely any communication between them.

Example 1: "FC Bayern Munich" is a team that have a strong bond between them, they know each other well and together they help each other by communicating with each other so that they can eventually score a goal, or when a certain player, like a defender, needs assistance on the pitch. Each player knows what their goal is ( Attacker, Defender, Midfielder, Goalkeeper), and so they can achieve a greater synchronization of their achievements 
	
Example 2: A group could be when you are assigned to a project with classmates that you particularly don't know of, as you don't know each other the project might be to superficial and in depth enough. Every group member does their own work and at the end add all of their work in one and present it. Instead of communicating and helping each other when/ if needed.

A group is a collection of people who work, engage, and collaborate with one another to achieve a shared objective within a specific time frame. The identities of the members of the group are taken separately. Members share information and resources with other members of the group.

A team, on the other hand, is a group of individuals that work together to achieve a common objective within a certain time frame while maintaining collective accountability. Aside from providing information, team members are also responsible for the team task. The result is always the responsibility of the team.

1) A group of people came to the job interview. One candidate got the position and now is part of the development team.
2) A group of people had summer vacation on a cruise. The ship crashed and now all members had to become a team to survive on a desert island.

Eine Gruppe, ist eine Menge von verschiedenen Personen, die irgendeine Beziehung zueinander haben.

Ein Team, ist dies auch, jedoch, ist ein Team mehr als das:

Sie sind gut miteinander verbunden, in dem Sinne, dass sie gut miteinander arbeiten können, voneinander profitieren, einander kritisieren können, die Schwächen und Stärken der Teammitglieder kennen, eine gut auf die Stärken ausgerichtete Aufgabenverteilung zur Erreichung eines gemeinsamen Ziels, auf die Beine stellen können. Somit bringt ein Team, die besten Eigenschaften der Teammitglieder hervor.

Dadurch, können ein Team ein gemeinsame Ziel gut erreichen.

Ein gutes Beispiel hierfür wären:  Zahnräder

Ein Zahnrad für sich, kann sehr hochwertig, und stabil sein, und auf viele Probleme Lösungen finden. Jedoch, nicht in einer losen Anhäufung von verschiedenen Zahnrädern. Sie können erst recht hohen und komplexen Anforderungen genügen, wenn sie eng miteinander verzahnt werden, und ihre Ecken und Kanten ordentlich abgestimmt bekommen.
