While a group would emerge from any arbitrary set of people, that would be accordingly loosely related, a team differentiates themselves by a driving force, strong bonds and coordination which allows them to work on common goals in a collaborative manner.
As an example, while traffic participants, which are often loosely related, may not have a common goal and maybe even a diverging goal (driving securely, arriving as fast as possible), in a traffic accident they may or may not form a team (often more so under coordination) and work hand in hand under the common goal of bringing people to safety.
As for another example people on the street, which are often not closely related and don’t work forward a common goal (everyone for themselves), may organize themselves under a common threat (strong bond) such as an invasion to work together toward a common goal.

A team is a group but a group can not be a team. 
A group is just a number of people with something in common or a certain relationship between them. 
Example: 200 students attending a lecture in the lecture hall, are a group of people. each one of them came on their own and for their own benefit, but they have in common that they're registered to the same course. 

A team is a group of people tied together by a relationship based on trust and communication, that work together and depend on each other to reach a common goal. 
Example: 5 developers working on an app in a startup are a team.

The difference between a group and a team lies in cohesion. A team's participants are more closely intertwined and coordinate to achieve a goal. In contrast to this, a group's members work on their own and are only loosely connected. 
An example for this difference can be found in sports. A hobbyist group that meets up once a week in  a certain location may be loosely connected, but isn't working towards a common goal like a sports team that wants to win a championship would. 
Another example can be illustrated through the process in which a group transforms into one or more teams. Classes and lectures are normally visited by a group of students, they don't work together, and their only connection is being in the same class. During projects, students may need to form teams, through which they need to cooperate on projects and build up a final product together,

A group of people have a relationship to one-another but they don't share a common goal, whereas in a team, members are working on a common goal. For example a group of friends is a group, since they might not study the same subject or share a same goal and everyone is working on achieving their own personal goal.
But a team of doctor working on a patient is a team. Doctors in that scenario are connected by the goal of trying to help a patient and each member should do their job in coordination to others to achieve that goal.

Group:
An example for a group is our lecture EIST. All of us are loosely connected because we all want to learn something from this amazing lecture. However we don't focus on a common goal. Everybody learns for themselves and you could even argue that helping your fellow students would make your chance of success slimmer.

Team:
Getting a group task for a module requires a team. You need to coordinate your doings and have to follow a plan. Otherwise the common goal of getting a good grade for the work you deliver wouldn't be matched. The result is a team that is heavily influenced by the products of their mates.

Groups: a number of people working on their own tasks, for example students in the same tutorial group (only connection is the same university course)

Teams: a number of people that work towards the same goal; often with complementary skills/tasks, so some form of organization is needed; for example a football team (different roles, same goal)

A Group is a number of people with a combined goal but no Teamwork. They do not have a similar routine. An example would be a school class, because they have the same goal (passing the A levels) but they are not working together. 
A Team are working together after the four phases of Tuckman. Ideally they trust each other and the work they do. An example would be an Volleyballteam.

A group and team may seem very similar at first, but there are some critical differences. 
Mainly a group is a collection of individuals, who work independently and do not share a common goal with each other. A team however is a collection of individuals, who indeed work together. They have a common goal, therefore soft skills start to play a vital role for the proper and effektive functioning of a team. There is a greater amount of communication in a team than in a group, this is due to the exchange of idea about implementation, planning and also reviewing work. To achieve this there is for example agile software development, but it can also be as simple as exchange of ideas or more importantly working towards a common goal as mentioned earlier. These methods help members of a team achieve coordination in the work/project and strive towards a common goal.
Members in a group are connected but not as closely as in a team and only share a common characteristic, for example students of Informatics at TUM are all striving for a Bachelors of Science. They are however all working independently for their degree.

1.Example
A number of individuals are trying to develop a new website for selling used books. 2 people are assigned to develop on the front end, 4 people on the back end and another 2 people to test and review the functionalities, 1 manager. Their first step is planning everything(assignment of roles, manager, deadlines, etc.), then they develop what they were assigned to develop and everyday they discuss on the progress and give feedback, finally they review it. All this requires close group work and the constant exchange of ideas. The individuals are working together, e.g. back end explains the testing team what exactly is important to test. They are constantly exchanging information and working towards a common goal therefore they are a team.
Few weeks back at TUM we Informatics students were assigned to develop a website with JAVA GUI as homework. We were all trying to get the task done within the deadline and we were all doing the same task, but we were a group because there was minimal to no exchange about the task and most importantly we were all working towards creating and finishing our own website(meaning we had no common purpose). Every website turned out differently(at least in terms of design, since the functions were predetermined by the task) as expected in a group.

2.Example
The idea of team also comes up for example in a band. A rock band generally consists of 4 members(a vocalist, a drummer, a bass player and a guitar player). They all have to inevitably always work together when playing a song(also during practice session, there even verbal communication is used). For the guitar player it is not only important to play the right notes, but to also play in coordination with the other band members and staying in sync basically. In order to achieve this the drummer for instance signals the start of a song with three beats, then all members of the band start playing. Moreover they are working towards a common goal, which is playing a song. Obviously communication and coordination in a band is very different compared to a software team, but they are both teams.
An example for a group that we see every week is the group of people in a supermarket. They are all in the supermarket to buy groceries, however they are all shopping independently with their own grocery list. There is no communication about the coordination of their activities(what they shop) or what their outcome(What is going to be shopped) is. Nobody in the supermarket is aligning goals with others or in any way dividing the shopping list among the others in order to achieve efficient shopping or diving the cost etc.. Therefore people in a supermarket are a group of people shopping not a team.

It may seem like teams are only relevant when working on huge projects. Our EIST-Team-Work which will start very soon, will prove very nicely that the idea of a team is also very relevant when working on a smaller project.
To conclude a number of individuals all working independently are referred to as a group, whereas a number of individuals working towards a common goal and working together are referred to as a team.

The difference between a group of people and a team is, that a group is not closely connected and don't even have to know each other.
For example, we could say that all people with blue hats are now grouped. They are shuffled together at random and there is no chance that they have a common goal that they want to achieve.

A team, on the other hand, knows each other.
For example, a football team knows each other, knows how the other players think, and understands what to do just from little glances. The common goal is also clear: they want to win the upcoming games.

In conclusion the group is nothing more then a few people which are mixed together where a team is closely connected and trained to have a efficient workflow.

Groups have more people and they focus on completing assignments individually, while teams have less people and they work towards a shared goal collectively. 

In groups people are more independent and they are loosely connected, while in teams people are depedent of each other because it all depends on the effort they put in.

Groups divide workload in even amounts among all participants without taking individual workload into account.

Teams work together and discuss all matters at hand and mutually offer ideas.

Eine Gruppe sind eine Anzahl von Personen welche zwar in einer bestimmten Beziehung zueinander stehen jedoch nur spärlich verknüpft sind. Sie nicht unbedingt ein gemeinsames Ziel und streben eventuell ganz andere Dinge an. Jedes Individuum agiert vorrangig allein und arbeitet auf individuelle Art und mit persönlichem Ziel. 
Im Gegensatz dazu stellt ein Team eine Gruppe dar die sich durch eine tiefere Vernetzung der Mitglieder sowie durch geteilte Ziele und Arbeitsweisen auszeichnet. Die Individuen arbeiten zusammen und jeder bringt mit seinen Fähigkeiten das Gesamtprojekt voran.

So stellt zum Beispiel eine Ansammlung von Studenten auf dem Sportplatz eine Gruppe dar, während unter diesen ein Team von Fußballspielern sein kann welche auf einander abgestimmt agieren um ihre Chancen auf den Sieg zu erhöhen. 

Ebenso kann es innerhalb eines Unternehmens Mitarbeiter geben die eine Gruppe bilden, zum Beispiel eine Abteilung. Die Verbindungen sind hier zwar vorhanden, aber eventuell nur spärlich. Innerhalb der Abteilung aber arbeiten Teams daran bestimmte Aufgaben zu erfüllen. Zum Beispiel eine Gruppe von Programmieren die jeder ihre spezielle Expertise einbringen um die Buchhaltungssoftware zu überarbeiten.

groups: a number of people together with loose relationships to each other. 
teams: a number of people co-working on a common purpose and strong relationships to each other.

The members of a group have certain similarities or share a position and are somehow connected to each other, e. g. all the attendees of a university lecture or the members of this certain course form a group of students. However, they do not work towards the same goal (except their own private goal of passing the exam) or do not work on a shared incentive like in a project. Team members fulfill that criteria. Some few students of this course could form a team to launch a new software application. Now they are a lot more connected and have to work together as a "team". In sports for example, all F1 racing drivers could be considered a group of drivers, but they form ten different teams in which they work toward a certain goal, the championship. This example also works in soccer or volleyball or any other team sport.

Group: several people that are loosely connected in some way
- spectators of a sports game
- students at a university
Team: a group of strongly connected people which is working together to achieve the same outcome
- basketball team
- scrum team

In a group people have some relationships with each other but are not connected. In a team people have a common goal and are strongly connected. 

In a group participants work on their works individually, but in a team participants work together. 

A group doesn't focus on specific outcomes or a purpose. Unlike a group, a team focuses on specific outcomes, it requires activities and tasks.

The differences between groups and teams are that a group is only a collection of people who loosely coordinate their efforts, while a team is a group of people who share a common goal. For example, a Cricket team works together to win the game. While a group of passengers on an aeroplane are all on it for their reasons. This means that in a group the members act independently from each other and share no responsibility. Whereas in a team each member shares the responsibility and they need to work closely together to achieve the common goal, they are interdependent. 

When a group encounters a problem, they discuss it, decide on a solution and delegate it to an individual. Whilst a team works on the solution collectively. For example, a company brainstorms for a new product, here each department will have a different perspective and product, whilst the engineering team will work collectively on multiple strategies to archive their common goal of creating the final product.

A group is collection of people who are loosely connected to one another. They do not work toward the same specific goal and do not have extensive communications with one another, Mostly, each person works on their lonesome. However, a team is a collection of people who works together towards a same clearly defined goal. They will motivate and push each other to achieve this goal and will work very closely with each other in collaboration towards this goal
For example a classroom of students is a group, each student mainly focuses on their own studies, but are loosely connected by the fact that they are  studying in the same class, they might help each other occasionally but do not work closely with each other. Their end result's success; achieving good results, depends only on the individual. However a soccer team is a team as the collection of people all works towards the same goal, winning the soccer match. The soccer players work with each other and supports each other closely to defeat the other team. They push eachother during training and are strongly connected by camaraderie and are bound by collective success or failure.

Another example would be a  collection of athletes from the same country participating in the Olympics. A group would be the athletes from the same country participating in a individual match. They are loosely connected by the fact that they are all from the same country, but their goals are to only win the match themselves, they might do certain training or activities together but ultimately each person's victory is their own. However, if these athletes are the ones who would be participating in a relay match, they are then considered a team. This collection of people all work toward the same goal of winning the match for their country and no individual can win the match by their lonesome. The team have to work together in order to win the match. They have to support each other during training closely and have to coordinate with each other closely throughout.

We can not call 11 random football players as a "team", because everyone just play football in his/her way, they do not have the same aim. This is just a "group". In a true football "team", the players will work together to get goals. They will pass the ball between each other for the best goal opportunities.

A team is more cohesive than a group in that they have the same goal(s) that they work towards together whereas a group has certain characteristics in common but not goals they try to achieve together. 
An example for the difference between a group and a team could be students attending the same course. All of the students can be summarized as a group considering that they are in the same course, but a team would only describe students who decide to study together for the exam in an effort to each get a good grade, i.e. people who actively work together to achieve something.
Another example could be a department in a company. All members of the department are a part of a group, but may not work together in a team because they work on different projects, and therefore may not have project-specific goals in common that they could work on together. Although they would have more general goals in common, like wanting the company to succeed, all the members of a department would only become a collective team if they all actively work with each other rather than all working towards the same general goal but in separate teams that have little to no communication or collaboration.

Der Unterschied zwischen einer Gruppe und einem Team ist, dass in einer Gruppe eher der Erfolg des Einzelnen im Vordergrund steht, wohingegen in einem Team der Erfolg aller Mitglieder des Teams im Vordergrund steht.
Ein Beispiel für ein Team, wo das Gemeinziel im Vordergrund steht, kann man in so fast jeder Sportmannschaft sehen, wo das "Team" versucht gemeinsam ein Ziel zu erreichen, bspw. ein Spiel zu gewinnen oder sogar eine Meisterschaft.
Ein Beispiel für eine Gruppe wäre im Gegensatz, dass Spezialisten einzelner Fachgebiete zufällig zusammengefügt werden, um ein Problem zu lösen. 
Dies hat zwar den Vorteil, dass man Menschen hat, die sich auf ihrem Gebiet auskennen, jedoch nicht als Team funktionieren und so es bspw. passieren kann, da der Zusammenhalt, wie es in einem Team ist, wahrscheinlich nicht gegeben ist, sodass Einzelne sich von der Gruppe abkapseln und entweder die Gruppe verlassen oder individuell arbeiten.

A team is a special kind of group, with people that do together a task and have a common goal.

A mass of people in an underground is a group, but not a team. Because they are not working on a common task and have not a common goal.

A soccer team is a team, because all of them are playing soccer and have the common goal to beat the opposing team.

Even if both group and a team describe a set of people, they have a different meaning. People in a group are loosely connected  and don't share a common goal. For example in this course all participants spend time together, but aren't a part of one team - they aren't close acquainted with each other and their goals may differ - for example somebody may just want to pass and somebody else wouild want to achieve a good grade. At the same time groups that we'll form for a project may be called "teams", because we'll have to cooperate wsith each other to achieve a common goal (= project) and during the process we'll became (at least!) acquitances.

Eine Gruppe unterscheidet sich von einem Team in mehreren Gesichtspunkten. Während bei Letzterem die Zusammenarbeit als miteinander harmonierende und stark verknüpfte Gemeinschaft, darauf bedacht eine gemeinsame Intention zu verfolgen, zentriert im Vordergrund steht, so ist eine Gruppe nur ein loses Konstrukt individueller Teilhaber, deren Relation sich aufgrund individueller Progression und Bestrebungen nicht immer durch gemeinsame Ziele widerspiegeln lässt. Als Implikation dieser Begebenheit lässt sich eine bei Teams unverzichtbare Koordination und Kooperation in sämtlichen Belangen des vorgesehenen Aufgabenbereichs ableiten, die bei Gruppen vollständig fehlt. Eine Versinnbildlichung dieser Behauptung wäre der Unterschied eines Sportvereins und eines Sportteams. Während das Sportteam als Mannschaft zusammenarbeiten muss, um Erfolge einzufahren, ist der Verein in mehrere Sektionen und Abteilungen separiert, deren Mitglieder unabhängig voneinander agieren.

A group consists of individuals who work on their own goals and do not depend on each other. 
An example is a school class where the students have to pass the exam on their own. They might communicate with each other in order to prepare for the exam.

In a team, the members work together in order to achieve one goal. Everybody has to contribute to the project.
An example is a software development team where every member has to perform certain tasks in order to finish the project. Communication is very important in order to assign tasks to members.

In groups members may help each other but they are essentially independent, therefore discussions, decisions, actions in groups serve to individual objectives, which is defined as cooperation. However in teams members have the same objective, so the discussions or actions in a team must serve to the common goal, which is called collaboration. In teams people pave the way and get rid of the obstacles together, however in groups people aim to interfere with each other's goals as little as possible. Let's say that some friends went on a hike in the woods, initially they are a group, since they all do the same thing but possibly with different objectives such as enjoying the nature or physical training. Nevertheless they become a team when they get lost, since in such situation they will all share the same goal and work together to achieve it: to get back home safely. Groups can also benefit from working together, as they achieve their individual goals faster but that doesn't make them a team, as long as they don't share a common goal. For instance an athlete cheering for an another athlete from another team may make them a group, ocassionally they might even help and support each other but as their goal is individual success they can't be seen as a team.

Groups are disconnected teams

Teams have a common goal, are strongly connected, and focus on a specific outcome.  In groups, however, every individual works on his own personal goal, participants are loosely connected and do not focus on specific outcomes.
You can say that teams try to be a singular entity and in groups the participants maintain their own identities. 

A team would be the team that I will form in the software engineering class, we all are going to work together to achieve the academic results that we want, we need to coordinate tasks and activities to make a good project and we are connected strongly by being the best team in the software engineering class. 

A group would be the people that go to a skate park, they all are loosely connected by having a skateboard and being in the same space, but everyone is working on their own personal skills and they try to achieve tricks individually. They do not share a common goal and they do not actively try to work together unlike my software engineering team (hopefully).

Teams: work together trying to solve a common Problem| e.g.: Football Team
Groups: work on the same Problem but not necessarily together| e.g.:Formula 1 Team

A Team has a specific goal in mind, which they want to achieve together
A group is just a certain amount of people which can be categorized together because they have some sort of relationship to one another. This even includes their age, which lecture they are visiting and such and such.

One example for a team is the Haas F1 team. This is a Formula 1 Racing Team. The participants are connected through their work. Everybody in this team works with one goal in mind: To be win the constructors championship in Formula 1. Because a Racing Team can have between 200 to 1200 employees this big team gets divided into smaller teams, which have a certain task to work on. If somebody makes a mistake the whole team can suffer from it because it is important to get results. Otherwise the team wont get any sponsorships and cańt continue to race.

But even though we were mostly doing the same thing which is eating we are not a team because to most of the other visitors I didn’t have any connection and I’m not dependent on them because we don’t work on the same tasks or even together.

A group is a bunch of people which are loosely connected. They have not a common goal and do not work together.
A team is a number of people with a clear and common goal. They are strongly connected. They work together.

- Groups: People who work individually and have a slight connection with each other. They don't have a 		  common purpose.

- Teams: A group of people, who are working together on a specific goal. In order to achieve that goal, they need to coordinate themselves. Additionally, they have a strong connection with each other.


Examples:

- Group: 
Library group

Individuals work on their own, e.g. somebody is learning, the other one is reading, etc. They may know each other but the purpose and outcome can differ. 

Learning group

People work on their own, e.g. somebody is learning, the other one is helping a friend with a specific topic. They may know each other but the purpose can also differ, e.g. among the people everybody can be studying for a different exam or just being there.

- Team: 
A soccer team

They are strongly connected and have the same goal, e.g. scoring goals and eventually winning the game. Tactics also represent strong teamwork.

A project team

People in a project team must be connected in order to achieve the goal, which could be for example scientific research or designing a new product. They, of course, need to work together and coordinate themselves.

A group is just a collection of people, which don't require any connection to be in the same group.
A team is a group of people who have come to know each other well enough to be a productive collective.
For example: while sightseeing in a different country, you can come across tourist groups who pay to get shown the most memorable things about that place. These are mere groups and not teams, since the members do often times not even know each other.
In soccer for example, the groups really are teams. They trust each other and work together to reach their mutual goal.

A group consists of several people that don't share any common ground. In other words, they don't share beliefs, values, goals, and visions. No one is interested in the success of other people and everyone works on his own. There is little to no collaboration. 
On the other hand, a team consists of people that share the same goals and values. In contrast to a group, a team is focused on the success of the entire team as opposed to the success of an individual. To guarantee the focus of the entire team, all members are connected and work together strongly. 

One example of a team will be the team that we form for the group project in EIST. In this team we all share the same goal, namely creating a useful and meaningful REST application. All 5 team members have to work together to achieve this common goal. 
A group is for example all the students listening to a lecture in one lecture hall. All the students are loosely connected and have some relationship with each other. After all, we all are interested in that particular lecture. Nevertheless, every individual in that lecture hall works on his own and only for his own grades

A group is a number of people that have some relationship between each other. Teams are also a number of people, but they have a common goal and work together to achieve it. 
An example for a team is a soccer teams that trains together and works hard to win games and a group is for example a group of sprint athletes that do not work together but work on their own to achieve their goals but are connected because they participate in the same competitions.

Whereas a group are people that are only loosely connected, do not have a shared vision and rather work on their own, a team, being a subclass from group, are people involved in the same activity because they have shared interests and motivations regarding their shared vision. People in a team are strongly connected by character, motivation, discipline and vision. 

One example is a football team, being 11 players that share the interest of playing well and winning games. Along with this ultimate goal comes the discipline and motivation required to reach it. So it is team of strongly connected personalities  which is self-reinforcing as they motivate each other and continuously improve in performance. If one decides to not be a team player, the idea of a team is disrupted as they cannot benefit from stong shared will. 

As second example is a start-up company. In the beginning, there might be a group of 5 people that have the same idea so they want to create a start-up, but eventually, members of the group might lose the spark the initally had, so they lose motivation to continue. With time, the group of people that initially started automatically filter out people that do not have shared interests and the correct mind-set, so it becomes a team of hard-working individuals that are strongly connected thanks to their shared vision.

People in groups have some relationship/connection between each other, but everyone in the group acts as their own independent individual, working towards their own goals that don't necessarily align with the goals of other group members. In teams, the people are more connected and work together in a coordinated and organized way towards a common goal of the whole team. 
Example 1: 
A group of high school students in sports class playing dodgeball is in most cases a group. Everyone just plays more or less for themselves (tries to not be hit by a ball) despite being in the same sports team. The members do not have a strategy or specific roles. A professional sports team on the other hand is a team. For example in football, the players have their assigned role that they play instead of just everyone chaotically trying to kick the ball into the tor - they are coordinated and also have a clear strategy for the game. They work towards the common goal of winning and have a strong connection between each other because of it.
Example 2:
A group of people learning in studitum during exam season could be a group. Even though the students may help each other occasionally, everyone is studying for their own exam. The students goal is to pass their own exam don't care about the other ones as much. They are also not coordinated, because everyone is typically working on a completely diffrent thing. An ERA-Praktikum group on the other hand is a team. The members are working together systematically to create a single project. They are organizing their working so that two people are not doing the same thing and so that they can hand in their project on time.

In a team of people, everyone is working to achieve one specific goal, where as in a group of people that is not necessarily the case. For example a sport team is trying to win a match. A group of friends however does not need to have any common goal.
In a team of people, everyone is working together to achieve a specific goal, where in a group of people individuals are working on their own. For example a software developing team is trying to come up with solutions together for the given problem statement. In a group of students however everyone is trying to solve a task on their own.

A group is a selection of people that may have a common purpose or intent but don't necessarily know each other personally and are not focusing on specific outcomes. Individuals may share traits with other group members but work independently. There is no sense of commonality or purpose.

Example: 
- A randomly assigned selection of people during an assessment center for a job in a bank: here it doesn't matter much which group a person belongs to; it is still about individiual performance and there's typically no common goal as there's only 1 job to fill. 
- A class at school: this is a group of people that may share the same goal (to learn subject XYZ) but eventually everyone works on his/her own to achieve a good grade in the class. Teamwork is not needed as it's about individual performance.

A team is a group of people that has a common purpose/goal and is involved in the same activity to achieve a target that each team member is aligned with. Typically, team memebers are more personally connected with each other and incentivized to work together. They require coordination and cooperation to achieve a goal.

Examples:
- A football team: each player trains to work together with other players to win games
- A sales team: each team member helps each other out, shares knowledge and supports each other to hit sales targets for a company
- A software development team: each member needs to communicate with each other to divide work, update each other on progress, negotiate on ideas and trade-offs to deliver a project in time and in budget as a team

A team can be seen as a subcategory of a group. While a group is just a loose conglomerate of people, a team has additional features.
A group for example, could be the students that attend the same lecture together. While they all attend the same lecture, their intentions for doing so can be vastly different. Some student might attend the lecture, because it is part of his curriculum and he doesn't really have any other choice than to take the lecture and pass the exam, while another student might have chosen to attend the lecture because he is actually interested and invested in the topic of the lecture. Each student has an individual goal in mind when attending the lecture.
A team on the other hand could be a group of friends that want to build a start-up business together. They are all friends, and they share a common goal. Their goal is to build a successful business. This goal motivates them to work together in order to make their wish come true. In order to achieve that goal they are required to split different parts of running the business among all the members and rely on the fact that each member fulfills their role in building the business.

A group of people don't need to share a goal, a team is connected by a goal or project.
A team is working together, while in a group of people everybody might be doing his own project.

Teams work together, succeed together and fail together. Groups have individual goals and some kind of relationship to each other, whereas teams share common goals and have a much stronger bond.

Examples:

• An individual in a group could feel isolated, whereas a team would involve every member into planning and decision taking.

• Matching tasks would be more difficult in a group as the members won't know who has which strengths and weaknesses, whereas a team would know those things.

One difference between groups and teams is the cooperation and communication between the members. Lets take a project that has to be completed within two weeks. If it's for example a school project we will have a group of people that have to organize themselves, without really having any bigger previous connections or deeper relationships, whereas a team (probably in a work enviroment) are already organized and have already established a solid, fast and clear communication network nefore the project even starts. Another difference might be the working ethos: in a group everyone will think about their own advantage out of the project, for example a good grade or better reputation, while in a team the whole team is working towards finishing the project and the team is following a common goal, like delivering a game or a product on time.

There are differences between groups and teams, the main difference being the purpose of both. A group is simply put a collection of individuals who all work by themselves and have somewhat of a connection to each other. In a team on the other hand, every member shares the same purpose or goal and therefore work together.
An example for a group would be: " ... a group of men. " This is just a classifcation for multiple individuals, who share the same male gender, yet otherwise do not necessarily know each other, work together or even have the same goals. 
On the contrary an example for a team would be: " ... a team of football players" . These players train together and are closely connected. They also share the common goal of improving their football skills, as well as realizing their full potential as a team by communicating better and harmonizing on the playing field.

Group contains of some people, who do not have mutual target/aim, "every man for himself" so to say. For example pupils in school class. Team contains of people, who have some mutual target/ reason to cooperate. For example if pupil were divided in teams to make projects in lesson by teacher.

Group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another.
In group, participants are loosely connected; they do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose; and every individual works on his own.

Team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work.
In team, participants are strongly connected; they focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities; members need to work together.

For example, the students participating in the lecture hall can be a group, because each student work on their own. They gather together just for the lecture.

Students working together for a group project or a team work can be a team, because they work together for a common goal and they need coordinate to have a good outcome.

A popular example of the team is the project team for the Software Engineering course. Team members have a common goal and they should work together to get a better grade. It needs coordination between team members so that they can work in harmony.

A group of friends can be given as an example for the group. Members are independent of each other. Each member works on his/her own and doesn't serve a mutual purpose.

A number of persons are considered a group when they have somehow a relation to each other, however, they are not closely connected. The people do not work collaboratively as they do not follow a common objective. They are individually accountable for their performance, e.g. a group of students in a lecture with only an individual exam and no team project.
A team, on the other hand, is a group of people that follow the same objective and therefore have a strong connection to each other. As they work collaboratively, there is a need for work division and coordinating tasks among the members. An example would be a marketing team in start-up, that works together to run the marketing responsibilities of the company.

A group is a collection of people affilliated in whatever manner. A team would be the same "group" of people working towards a collective goal. 

Example 1: 
If a group of people had to climb over a wall, everyone would try according to their ability, whereas a team would tackle the challenge together, combining their strengths to make up for their weaknesses

Example 2:
In software development a group could have an imbalanced workload with one person carrying the bulk of the process. In a team there wouldn't just be a balanced workload, but the tasks themselves would be divided according to the heterogenic strengths of the members.

A group can be defined as a number of people, that hardly have a connection with each other. They also work individually and usually have different goals. A team can be described as a group of people who are connected by one goal or one activity. 
For example, students who attend the same class can be collected into a group. They usually do not communicate during lectures. However, if these students will be divided into smaller groups with common tasks or goals, you can call this group a team.

A group describes an arbitrary amount of people that have a common attribute for example TUM students all have in common that they are students at the TU University. A team however is a group of people with a shared goal for example the Brooklyn Nets are a basketball team consisting of a group of basketball players playing for the Nets (common attribute) that all want to win a championship (shared goal). Another example would be a development team. They are all developers working for a company (common attributes) that need to complete certain tasks by a certain deadline (shared goal).

In groups people are individuals that are in some relationship to each other. The relationship is not strongly formel, individuals do not have responsibilities to contribute to the same or basically any goal. An example for a group would be train passengers. They form a group because they are in the same train.

On the other hand, teams are formed by individuals to achieve a goal, they are accountable to each other. In a train travel scenario, everyone who work on the train such  as machinists or ticket controllers are in a team. They make sure that the passengers go to the right destination, safely and on time.

1. In a Group people don't have a common goal, in a Team everyone focus on a same purpose. 
For example, a group of people is studying in the library, every individual works on his own lecture and focus his own objectives. When people build a team and play video games, everyone membership focus on same goal: win the game.
2. In a Group people works on his own, but in a team members need to work together. 
For example, At the Gym people focus on his own program, some use running machine, others use lifting; but in a soccer team, every membership have to work together.

A team is a unit of people which is oriented towards a common task or goal. To achieve this goal, members communicate with each other and work closely together. An (ideal) team is cohesive, organised, structured and efficient.

In contrast, a group is a unit of people which does not have a firm structure. In a group, each person has individual goals which are not aligned with other members' goals. As such, each member acts by themself and in their own self-interest. There is only little communication between members.

An example for a team is a league of legends esport team. In this game, a team of 5 members must fight and defeat another team of 5 members. The common goal is to defeat the enemy team and win. In order to win, all team members must work together, strategise and carry out objectives and tasks in a certain order at a certain time. During the game, all players are communicating all the time. Failure to communicate, deviating from the common goals and not having enough structure and cohesiveness within the team will reduce the team's advantage and give the enemy team an advantage.

An example for a group is a tourist group going sightseeing in London. Such groups usually consist of people who don't know each other, and they have merely met by chance. The group does not have a common goal and the motives may differ significantly. One person in the group might aim to relax on their vacation. Another tourist may have joined the group to study each new sight carefully and learn about its history. Another member of the group wants to spend more time with their family and does not prioritise studying the sights or relaxing at all. Due to the lack of a common goal, the group is only loosely connected by the fact that they all went on a sight-seeing tour in London. There may be communication as people may want to get to know fellow tourists, but communication is usually little and not oriented towards a common goal.

Group: A group consists people, who have a relationship to another, but their relationship is not very close. They are all following their own aims, so they are solely responsible for their actions. So everybody is responsible for their own success and failure. 

Team: A Team consist people, who have very close relations to another. They are all working for a common goal. They are all sharing the same responsibility and are all focused on a defined result, which also requires a good coordination.

The difference is the type of the relationship between members of group or team: The relationship between members of team is based on common goal/purpose that requires coordination between them (example: developers of a start-up that work together so that the start-up succeeds). On the other hand, the relationship between members of group is loose and is not based on common goal (each members can have his own goal/preferences) and does not require coordination. (example: students attending a lecture where each one listens individually and no communication/coordination is needed)

In general a group is multiple people sharing a specific quality, whereas teams are groups formed for a specific purpose/functionality to be performed by the members working together. Overall teams are more tightly connected, have internal dependencies of the members on each other and as a rule of thumb are usually smaller than/subsets of corresponding groups.

Consider the ERA-Praktikum for example. The attending students form a group of students, sharing at least the quality of attending the lecture together. They do however not need to communicate to fulfill this quality and omitting one or several members of the group would have little to no influence on the other members or the group as a whole. In comparison, the student teams formed for the project also have a specific purpose for grouping the students, in which the members depend on each other, i.e. completing the project together, do require communication and the composition of the team matters. Omitting one or several members of the team will influence the other members of the team or even stop the team from functioning. For example, the remaining team members might require much more time to fulfill the task of the missing member(s) or be completely unable to fulfill it, due to having different skillsets.

Take any kind of game as a different example. Consider a group of players, sharing the quality of playing that game. If you now group them in two (or more depending on the game...) subgroups with the purpose of facing off in that game, you will have formed two teams. As the members of the one team will have the common goal of their team winning, whereas the members of the other team will have the common goal of their team winning respectively. Also, the members of the teams will usually work much more tightly together than just the members of the group would, as in this case two members of the group might even work against each other (rather than just not working together), due to being in different teams. Teams naturally don't have to oppose other teams in general, but this just illustrates a possibility for forming a subset with "stronger" requirements, compared to the group.

A group is a collection of people who have a weak connection to one another, on the other hand a team involves people who work in coordination in order to achieve a common goal.

For instance the professors and tutors of this course form a team: they communicate with each other and coordinate in order to offer the best learning experience for their students. On the other hand, students in the same tutorial can usually be considered a group: they meet at the same time in the same place to participate in the tutorial, but they may not interact with each other too much. This can of course vary from one person to another.

Another example are employees in a restaurant: they are a team, because they have to work together in order to serve food to the customers. A poorly coordinated restaurant will not function properly, teamwork is key to its success.

The difference lies in how and towards which goals work is done. While a group is simply connected somehow but doesn`t focus on a common goal or sense, a team has a strong connection, same goals and wants to achieve something together, by working together closely.

For example, a group can be a school class, all connected because they ended up in the same class, but still each doing the maths homework for themselves, or each even having different subjects. 

A team instead, is a couple of people who do sports (for example rugby). There is a strong connection between someone throwing the ball to the next one in the team and then someone else scoring the touch down. This team works together closely and wants to achieve the same common thing: winning!

Team: 5 students have teamed up in a course, because on the one hand they know each other beside studying and on the other hand all the team members want to achieve the same goal and give their best to reach it.

A first difference would be that in groups everyone could work for themselves. In teams you really should work together. In groups groupmembers often don't care about each other and maybe don't trust each other. For example in a football team you are part of a team and not of a group because you can't play without the rest of the team and you have to trust them so everyone can play better. Or in a development team you are typically part of a team as well because you have to work together so the software parts harmonize better at the end and you need less time for the whole project to complete.

Team is a group of people who share a common goal, while a group is a collection of indivuals who coordinate their efforts. 

For example our Team project in Software Engineering, the Team Members have a common goal, they want to get a good grade within joint editing. So they have goal-oriented focus.
Furthermore the communication is formal, becaus it is fixed at which time and how the results will be communicated and the team develops their own requirements how and when they communicate intern.

A informal group for example is a circle of friends, they plan their common holiday without rules from the outside or norms.

The difference between teams and groups is mainly the relationship between them and the goal they are working towards. If the people are in a very good relationship with each other and work together towards a common goal, then it is a team. However, if the people hardly know each other, have no common goal and work individually, then it is a group and not a team.

For example, a startup team is a team that works together towards a common goal: Namely, the startup foundation. Or a tennis team is a team because the team works together to win and it is not about individuals but about team success.

A group, on the other hand, would be the training group in the tennis example: Here, it is primarily about improving oneself in order to achieve one's own tennis goals. In the startup example above,  a group would be e.g. a group of founders at a pitch event who know each other a little and exchange information, but each founder pursues a different goal: namely, the goal of his or her own startup.

Group is a number of people that have to do something together, without common goal. When team is a certain number of people (usually thery have less participants than in group) that have common goal.
Groups example: dance class; german course
Team example: dance competition between 2 teams; working on project for german class

Groups are a number of people that are uncoordinated and without focus on a common goal. Teams on the other hand usually work together to achieve a common goal. In the context of software engineering for example, a team would give each other feedback and attempt to help enable each other's skill's to achieve their common goal, groups would lack these cooperative measures and would therefore be less effective.

A team is a certain number of people working towards the same goals and trying to achieve them together. They try to find solutions together and discuss different approaches. On the other hand, a group consists of many individuals who pursue their own goals, have their own interests and try to achieve them. People in a group are related to other people because of external factors. Team members are connected by external and intrinsic factors.
For example, students in a classroom are a group, while students working on a programming exercise are a team.
Besides, a soccer team is a team. They try together to win a game and reach the goal. The visitors, on the other hand, are a group with the same interests.
team:

A group is just made up of a number of loosely connected people that work towards their own goals individually. E.g. a group of students that all attend the same lecture and learn the same material, but each one is focused on passing the exam themselves, and does that by studying and practicing individually.

A team is a group of people whose participants share a strong connection and work together towards a common goal. E.g. a football team has players who all play for the same club which they want to win, and in order to achieve that they need to play together as a team.

A group are several people who have booked the same vacation and take the same flight and bus, but do not plan to spend the vacation together. They each have their own agenda during their vacation.

A team is several people who play a sport together and book the same vacation to spend time together and work on their preparation for the upcoming season.

A group is loosely personally connected, the goals of individual might not be the same, and members mostly work by themselves. 
On the contrary, a team is strongly connected and focused on a specific outcome or goal. Members of a team work together to achieve that goal.

For example, a group of teachers from different departments form a "group". They are not really connected, as they teach entirely different subjects, they work individually or with other people on their tasks (such as writing exams) and they are focused on different outcomes. Although the vague goal of successful teaching might be the same, one teacher can have the goal to prepare his/her students for the coorporate industry, while another can have the goal of making the student successful researchers.

An example of a team could be a "team" of researchers. All of them work closely together with a close connection and have constant communication as well as interdependancies within work. Also, they have a strong focus on proving/disproving a certain thesis or hypothesis.
the difference between a Groupe and Team is that a team have a closer relationship also more focused on the task the Groupe they have the same interest but not too focused on the task.

Set theory explanation:
You have a set A with the cardinality greater equal 2. 
- A group would be a relation R c A x A. 
- A team would be a relation T c A x A. We take two random elements a,b element A. (a,b) element T if and only if they are working together to solve a problem. |T| >= 1.

Other example:
A team is a collection of living beings, trying to solve a problem, for example a football team or basketball team. 
A group then would be the collection of the teams attending an competition -> A group of football teams

A team consists of members who work well together, are strongly connected and trust each other regarding everyone's abilities and skills. They work together very efficiently. On the other hand the members of a group are only loosely connected and have not yet optimized their working together. They work together poorly, if at all.
An example for a team would be a number of students/friends who created their startup together and learned to work together over time. They likely all want their startup to succeed and optimally they all invest heavily into the project to everyone's benefit. An example for a group would be the average grouping of students to solve homework together (of course only group exercises). These students have not yet learned to efficiently go together and one might be less motivated than others.

team: they work together for a comman goal : for example soccer team
group: people who are not connected to each other in order to achive a comman goal : for example students who are sitting in the same lecture room

Group is a number of people who works together without focusing on a specific outcome. Team is a group of people who works together to reach a common goal which is only possible with joint accountability of all team members. An example for a group could be a collection of workers who need to brainstorm together to bring up new project ideas. And the group of people who will later work on the project with certian requirements would be a team.

A group is just a collection of multiple people, whereas a team is multiple people with different strenghts working together towards the same goal.
An example for a group is a class at school. The students share a classroom and a time scedule and interact with each other, but during classes they usually work on their own.

The group is a collection of people, who are somehow related to each other. In a group there are no goals or roles per se, that's why one could say that the group-relationship is a loose one by nature. A team however is a type of group, where the roles and objectives are clearly defined, and the relationship itself is based around a goal.

A group and a team are both a number of people.

Members of a team work towards the same goal and specific outcome. To achieve that, they have to coordinate their tasks and work together. For example, a basketball team has to work together to be successful. All team members have the same goal which is winning the match.  One player trying to win against the other team on his/her own most likely would not be successful. But by coordinating tasks within the team chances of winning become bigger. 

While people in a group are just loosely connected and work on their own. Participants do not focus on a common goal. For example a student group at the TUM library. They are just connected because they study at the same University. They are all working on homework on their own, and every person has his/her personal study goal.

In a group a number of people only have some kind of relationship to one another, whereas in a team a group of people share a common goal in the same activity. In a team teamwork and cooperation is of much greater importance than in a group. Therefore, a participants of a team are more connected than the ones in a group.

Example: soccer players (group), a soccer team (team) and politicians (group), die Grünen (team)

a group is simply a collection of people who have no common goals to work on together. for example, a group of people on the street.

a team is rather a community that pursues a common goal and tries to achieve it together, like a football team.

A Team and a Group can differ in many Points.
For example a Group can represeant just some friends that maybe play some games for fun and hang out a lot
or a group can be some random people that want to do a task which is not that important.

A Team on the other hand is a well known "group". They work togehther and in the best case they know each other.
They plan and try to be constructive as posible. They may be a friends group but to work as a team is something different. The tasks they work on are planned and everyone knows what to do and in the best case in smaller teams everyone knows what the others do so they do not intervien.

groups:
do not focus on a specific outcome or progress. People just stay in one group e.g. in the classroom all the students belong to the same group.
teams:
have determination to archieve one goal. For an instance, in one seminar several students should form a team in order to make an awesome presentation towards a certain topic, such as quantum computing, at the end of the lecture period.

1. Goals:I think the biggest difference is "the share of a common goal." In a team, they share a common goal, but in a group each individual focus on their own goal.

2. Responsibility: When working in a team everyone is responsible for the work and overall development of a team, however in a group each individual is responsible for themselves.

3. Problem-solving: In a team usually there is an exchange of ideas and plan which leads to solving the existing problems, however in a group there is often a lack of exchange of ideas until a person responsible for the whole group asks for one like a tutor or a professor.

4. Selection: A team often goes through stages like selection and storming to be formed, however a group is formed mostly on random basis, if not on a general basis like all people with name starting from letter "A".

5. Dependency: A team often depends on one another, while a group is often individual effort.

6. Commitment and Trust: The level of commitment and trust in a group is very low compared to a team.

Examples 
1: A Labor union and a football team would be another example. In the Labor union, the group of people represent the working people force, they are not interdependent on one another. Neither are they sharing the responsibility. However, a football team depends on one another, share the responsibility and work towards a common team goal.
 
2 my own experience: Group: A group of students in a particular class, e.g. EIST, and a team like the Organization and teaching staffs team in EIST. The Organization and teaching staffs have a goal to complete the lecture materials which is divided into different parts like tutor teams and lectures. They have a final goal to reach as a team, however each student has his own goal, is responsible for his own.

The difference between a group and a team resides in the pursue of a common goal. While both a group and a team are partially defined as being a collective of people with relationships, teams generally work interactively together with the hopes of achieving a shared goal, while the individuals of a group are more self-involved with their own activities.

Examples for teams can be seen in the worlds of sports: Here a football team such as Bayern Munich works as a collective to win the national league. Each member of the team has the same ambitions and same goals to achieve said goal. Teams can also be found in the work place, where individuals must work together to reach certain deadlines and create a feasible outcome.

Examples for groups can also be found in social settings, for example when taking a group of friends, they interact with each other, but in their free time everyone has their own interests and hobbies. If we widen our range to the world of sports and take a short track group for example we can also see the pursue of own interests. Even if they are training together, each athlete while being part of the same club still has their own goals of claiming victory for themselves (single athlete competitions). In this case they might even compete with each other.

Groups focus on individual objectives and needs.
Teams persue a common goal together.

Group members work alone.
Team members need to cooperate.

Group members are in no close relation to each other.
Teams are closely bound together.

A group describes a gathering of people based on their ethnic, religion, residence, age, sex, education, nationality or job. Those people might not share any other similarities nor have ever made contact to each other. They only share for sure at least this particular point. So that they get summed up in a set.
For example: We as the participants of this course are in a specific group. 

A team depicts an interwoven construct which tackles problems together to solve them and work together to achieve their common goal.
For example: As a team we want to achieve our goal in successfully implementing our project by working together

Groups and teams are two somewhat related concepts in the sense of both describing a number of people (more than one) linked together through some characteristics. BUT there are serious differences that have to be pointed out:
A group describes a certain number of people vaguely connected with each other through some random similarity, for example, in a tutor group for an university course unrelated students come together via random matching only having a loose connection in visiting the same course. In contrast, the members of a team are tightly associated in sharing a common interest in the fulfillment of a certain task, like for a handball team the enthusiasm for the sport ties the members together and close collaboration on the field in a match is a prerequisite in pursuing the common goal of winning together. Contrary, members of a group do not share interest in collaboration or a joint goal, instead each individual is focused on its own agenda. For example, the people of a guided group visiting a museum share the relationship of using the same service at the same time and place, but each individual follows its own purpose for the visit being it education, research or a simple holiday activity. Consequently, unlike for a team, no further coordination or collaboration is required among the members of the visitor group. In contrast, for the success of a team - being the acheivement of the jointly pursued goal or outcome a transparent information exchange, mutual regard and the clear assigment and organisation of tasks is absolutely necessary. For example, like for a coworker team assigned with a software development project, clear roles like project leader, software developer, customer contact person etc. need to be defined in order to mark the responsibilities and required work contributions, which need to be harmonized. Otherwise the final solution might not work due to incompatibilities.

No one can deny that the huge difference between a group and a team  is that a group is a matter of a number and nothing more. Its main role is to collect and process some data,  no matter their origin or their characteristics, without any well-defined plan. Maybe one of the  real examples is our societies, each one of us has his own goals and dreams, and he is struggling to achieve them. That is why the society is a group because each one needs just to leave the place to be out of the group. But what individuals cannot do under the cover of the group is to be an active  member inside  a cooperative team. That can give you a chance to improve your skills and to boost them by  giving and receiving information.  Inside the team, you're trying to reach the same goal which your partner is trying to achieve. Last but not least, a team is the place where you will take your first steps on the road to your own goals. As a simple example, I am genially believing in teams of eist that we will create because they will  help us to share knowledge which we will use in the future.
