GROUP vs. TEAM, an essay (jk)

Group is a gathering of people who might find themselves in the same room or place purely at random or perhaps for a reason/ with a goal. They may be strangers to each other, acquainted or even be friends; that however doesn’t influence their status as a group.
Whereas a team is a tightly knit and well coordinated group of people, that is usually driven by a purpose or has to work towards a common goal. They are capable of working well together, each one providing a crucial skill necessary for the progress of the work.

We might have a group of friends just hanging out together during their free time, having no other goal though, than just to have fun and spend time together; they are not working towards anything.
A team on the other hand is for example a film crew: they all work hard on a big project – a film, each person bringing their expertise to the table (actors, directors, writers, cameramen, costume designers, orchestra, props people, stuntmen…); every person’s work is crucial for the film and they have to all be well coordinated because otherwise ... it just won't be a good film. :)

A group is a collection of people that are at least loosely connected. 
A team is also a collection of people. A team, however, can work together effectively on a basis of trust and experience.

A meeting for musicians organized on facebook will result in a group of musicians. An orcestra is a team: they train together and know each others abilities.

In school, when you had to write an article with others, there was a group dynamic where noone really wanted to do the work. A team of editors working on a newspaper is a team, where everyone can focus on their strenghts and produce a great result.

A group for example would be the people i go party with on a friday night. 
Some of us are strongly connected but most of us are a friend of a friend so we are not strongly connected.
Some of us want to go to a nightclub some of us want to go to a bar and within those subgroups there are even more different objectives.
Normally everyone works on his own as there is no common purpose else than having fun.

An example for a team would be my Hockey team.
We are very strongly connected as we are working together to stay in the first league. We have a coach and a team coordinator who help us with that.

So the differences are:
loose connection in group vs. strong connection in team
no specific outcome or purpose vs. specific outcome and purpose
group members work on their own vs. team members work together

Groups are collections of people who have similarities, for example similar interests or who do the same things. An example of groups would be all the people who all drive BMWs, the group members share characteristics (driving the same brand of car) with each other, however, they do not work together to achieve a shared goal but are instead barely connected and work alone. In a team - a specialisation of a group - however, the members join forces to achieve a shared goal. Exemplary teams can often be found in sports where several individuals work together to beat other teams, the FC Bayern, consisting of individual football players, is a prime example for that. They play together to win in the Bundesliga and other championships by coordinating the strengths of each individual player to achieve their goal.

Even though both groups and teams define a number of people who share a certain characteristic, teams and groups have a different meaning. A group of people suggests they are not necessarily strongly connected, whereas individuals within teams should have a strong relationship. This relationship is often a result of a common purpose, or close cooperation. For example one can call a group people who travel together in a sightseeing tour, or call a team 5 people working together in a company on a product feature.

In a group there are people who have some relationship between each other but they don't share a common goal where the group has to work together to achieve that goal. An example for a group could be friends watching a movie in a cinema or students who watch a lecture.

In a team there are people with a strong connection to each other who work towards achieving that common goal, and if they don't work together in the best possible way they might not achieve it. A good example is any sports team or teams at work.

The main difference is that in a team everyone works together to achieve the same goal, while in a group there isn't a shared goal and everyone works on their own.

Group is a collection of people or things that have something in common and they may or may not want to do anything with others.  
Team is a group of people who work together to achieve a common goal or ideal and they put the benefit of the group above their own benefit. 

Example 1 : There is a group of young players comming to the playground to practice. 
                   A team of soccer players is comming to the playground to practice for the next match against their opponents. 

Example 2 : I just join a group on Facebook of people who love cat. 
                   I just join a debating team and this week we will have a meeting to prepare for the upcoming competitions.

Group is people being together for some reasons, relations but without specific task.
Team is a group of people in which they have a certain purpose or idea to pursue.

Students in a classroom waiting for lectures is a group of people and a team of students would be some of students/people together solving a given task or presenting something.

Travellers in a train is a group of people toward a same destination and staffs on the train are a team whom worked on the train to provide services to travellers.

Eine Gruppe sowie ein Team bestehen aus mehreren Personen. Während aber die Personen einer Gruppe zwar unterschiedlich vage Beziehungen zueinander haben können, weswegen diese Personen eher alleine arbeiten und kein gemeinsames Ziel mit den jeweiligen anderen Teilnehmer dieser Gruppe haben. In einem Team gibt es eine starke Verbundenheit und alle Teilnehmer arbeiten stark miteinander zusammen, um ein gemeinsames Ziel zu erreichen, wodurch sie sich bemühen Aufgabenbereiche untereinander aufzuteilen, um effizient das gewünschte Ergebnis zu erreichen. So sind Studenten in einer Lerngruppe eine Gruppe, wo jeder letztendlich ein eigenes Ziel hat, selbst eine gute Note in der Klausur zu schaffen. Wenn diese Studenten aber als Team eine Präsentation halten müssen, arbeiten alle zusammen, um diese zu erstellen und gemeinsam eine gute Note darauf zu bekommen. Menschen in einer WG leben zwar unter dem gleichen Dach, aber haben letztlich ihr eigenes Leben und sind evtl. nur Mitbewohner, also eine Gruppe. Dagegen ist ein Volleyball Team ein Team, welches in einem Spiel mit verschiedenen Positionen auf dem Feld zusammenarbeitet, um das Spiel zu gewinnen.

While a group is just a number of people combined under certain criteria or a purpose, a team is a number of people combined for a certain purpose to achieve a common goal. A team is a subset of a group (Every team is a group, not every group is a team).


A group of people at the Olympics could be spectators, who are united by the fact that they watch but not working towards a common goal. A relay race at said Olympics however, is done by teams whose members are united by their common goal of winning the race.

Travellers going on a flight are a group of people, they want to get on a plane but don't necessarily care about the other passengers, while the flight crew work as a team with the goal of getting everyone on board safely and without delay.

Between a group and a team, there are certain significant differences whereas both consist of a number of people. 
While people within a group only have a minimal relationship - thus working independently towards their own goals and not towards a common goal, people within a team are strongly connected, working towards the same goal while actively participating in a certain activity.

Examples:
1) Let's look at team-sport. You are at a scouting event and want to make it into the football-team. At the scouting event, you compete a group of 10 other players who want to make it to the team. You don't feel connected to them and you only concentrate on your own work/performance. Your goal is to make it, not sharing a common purpose to also help the others for example. 
As soon as you have made it, you can find yourself in a real team. You don't have your own goal anymore, rather you work together with your team to win the championship. To reach your common goal, you spend a lot of time together and train together - (share same activities) - to get better. After some time, you know the routes of your teammates, everything gets more precise, tactics evolve.

2) Let's look at work: A good team is coordinating their tasks, every employee within the team has a certain task to achieve the greater common goal - e.g. growing the overall productivity/profitability of the company. All employees work together on this goal, help each other and also celebrate achievements with a common dinner to further strengthen their team spirit. 
On the other hand, you may also find departments, where goals of single employees differ a lot. This may range from not having to stress out at work over minimal working hours, to outperforming all colleagues. They don't share a common goal, don't communicate that much and only work for theirselves. Thus, as they don't have a strong connection - this department may only be considered as a group of people, rather than a team.

A group of people can exist without knowing each other, students for example, this doesn't apply for teams.
A group also is not necessarily trying to achieve something specific together, in contrast to a basketball team.

A group is a number of people, who work together to achieve individual goals and have individual responsibility of their work, whereas a team is a group of people who work collectively towards a shared goal.
Groups are brought together by shared interest or qualities of the members.
In teams on the other hand, the members have a shared goal or purpose and they work together and rely on each other throughout the journey.

Examples:
Team: A great example of a team is a football team. All members have the same goal, which is to win for example a championship. They work together cohesively and depend on each other to achieve that goal.
Group: A study group is one of the most common examples one can mention. Students are brought together by a common interest, which is to get a good grade in the exam. But they all are independent of each other. One's performance does not affect the others'.

Groups are usually tightened together losely, they work on a subject on a surface base and everyone works for himself, like a group of students in middle school for a presentation (yes they have a common goal but most times they are just forced to do so), whereas team members are dependant on eachother, connected by a common goal like soccer players, where every member of the team works coherently to achieve it. Second, the team members are also strongly connected, e.g. football players train continously to have a good chemistry on the field and outside of it.

A group is a undefined number of people which may have a connection to one another and most of the time work individually to achieve their own goals. 

On the other hand a team focuses on one (could be more) goal and work together to achieve it. Normally team members are strongly connected and this connection helps by bringing motivation among team member and stablish discipline.

If we look at a class of students in University for example, it can be classified as a group as there is little to no connection between them and the students mostly focus on getting a good grade for themselves and that's the main goal. If we look at a soccer team, the dynamic is completely different. Teammates tend to have a strong bong and they work together towards the same goal which could be winning the tournament for example. If one team member does not perform it harms everyone , not just them as contrary to the student.

- While the people in a team work together, the members of a group concentrate on their own work, neglecting the importance of communicating with the members and do not attempt to tackle problems together.

e.g: A group of people might try to solve a problem by comparing solutions with which each member has come up on their own and not discussing them in order to make them better. A team can tackle the problem through discussing different ideas, making them better and coming up with a solution together.

- The people in a group are strangers or they do not share the same ideas and are not close to each other contrary to the members of a team.

e.g: A group of people can consist of random people who have never seen each other and do not have anything in common. A team consists of people who can work together as they are close or have a common goals and ideas.

A team is a group, that wants to achieve a certain goal. For example, a soccer team is a group of players with the goal to win a game. Contrary, a group is just a collection of people. Therefore, the group doesn't need a common goal. For example, the people in a bus form a group and not all have the same goal, because some want to go to work and some want to go shopping.
A group is a just a set of people who have something in common. A team is a group united by one objective and working together to achieve it.

eine gruppe ist eine ansammlung an menschen die nur leicht miteinander verbunden sind und keine gemeinsamen ziele verfolgen, außerdem arbeitet jeder für sich selbst. z.b. die besucher Eines Clubs. eineige werden sich untereinander kennen, insgesamt wird aber kein gemeinsames Ziel verfolgt o.ä.

ein Team ist eine Gruppe von leuten die durch ein gemeinsames ziel miteinander verbunden sind. sie müssen koordiert werden damit ihre gemeinsame arbeit möglichst effizient ist. beispiel hierfür ist ein E-Sports Team. sie versuchen gemeinsam das nächste spiel zu gewinnen und es gibt sowohl einen Coach als auch meistens einen Ingame Leader der das team koordiniert. sie sind außerdem voneinander abhängig da sie nur durch zusammenarbeit eine wirkliche chance haben das Spiel zu gewinnen.

The group can be defined broadly. It means a number of people who gathered for a certain activity, interest, location, service or products. They may have the same features but with different individual goals. On the other hands, the team consists of the people who work to achieve the goals in common. Each member has responsibilities for their work and impacts each other. 

For example, we can see a large group of athletes who participate in Olympics. They have similar characteristic which is good at sports. But they can be divided into nations and even smaller disciplines such as shooting, soccer, swimming,, etc. The German team of swimming has different goal for the medals than the German swimming team and the score of individuals impacts the outcome of team score as well as total score of Germany. 

Another example can be seen in the company. Each department of the company (Software engineering, Marketing, Finance, Product Management, etc.) can be said a group but the group of people who gather for the certain project from each department is the team. (1 PM, 1 developer, 1 marketer, etc. build the team to launch the new product/service.)

The most important characteristic of a team is the intention to achieve the best result together and on the basis of cooperation. In a group, on the other hand, the focus is only on mastering a task, but individually and independently of the other participants. A group of archaeologists searches for fossils completely independently of each other. A team of archaeologists, on the other hand, searches together and divides up the tasks, for example.

In a well-functioning team, the available resources such as manpower, time or money are also divided up in order to use them ideally. This is not the case in a group, because here everyone works alone and thus no overarching distribution of resources is possible. In a group, valuable time is lost when trying to solve the same tasks, as everyone has to work out the solution themselves. In a team, such knowledge is quickly passed on or exchanged and thus processed more efficiently.

Group:

Encounters don't have a goal that has to be achieved together. It rather occurs on a random basis or is necessary to be attended to achieve personal goals or complete individual goals.

Team:

Tasks towards the common goal are decided between group members so work doesn't have to be done multiple times. Teams form in a professional as well as a free time context (eg sports Teams).

Example 2: corporation vs. small start up
A certain department in a large corporation for example the sales department can be considered as a group rather than a team. There is 3 main differences between a group and a team to point out. We describe every difference by using examples of a software team and a learning group of students (e.g., EIST course)

1. Same / Different target (goal)
- A software team has a same goal for every member to achieve, and its namely creating a quality software. Everyone is involved in this process
- A learning group of students could have different goals: ECTS, understanding of a subject, good note or having fun (there is no certain goal which should be the same for every single one of this group)

2. Synchronous / Unsynchronous work
- A software team always has a determined schedule to work. They have a plan, usually have a scrum meetings or adaptions of scrum
- A learning group decide on their own when, where and how they want to learn, which methodologies and techniques they utilize to achive their own goals. Scrum meetings are not possible to implement under this conditions

3. Strong / Weak (or no) connection
- A software team knows every member of its team (usually), their names and other facts about each other. They have a certain relations between each other (serious buisness partnership, friendship or or even love)
- A learning group could have some relationships, but only ocasionally. People possibly don't know each other or just not made a certain opinion of others in their mind. The relations could be defined or undefined

As an example to that I want to compare a chess team to a soccer team. In chess every game is played as a 1 vs. 1, however there are groups like the german national chess team. A group is a number of people that have something in common but do not necessarily share a common vision. A group may be a class of students or the audience in a theater.

The Oxford Dictionary defines a team, among other things, as a „group of people who work together at a particular job“. It is important to note here that the word „group“ is actually used within the definition of „team“, thus indicating a hierarchical relationship. While there are various definitions of the term „group“, a generally accepted understanding is that it is „a number of people or things that are together in the same place or that are connected in some way“ (Oxford Dictionary). 
While the word „group“ does imply a certain interrelationship between members, any accumulation of people could be defined as a group – such as a group of people standing on a platform, waiting for the same train, but having no true relationship to speak of. A team, on the other hand, requires a group to have a common goal that requires effort to be achieved. Hence, in sports for example, we speak of „teams“, and not „groups“ – these people did not coincidentally find themselves in the same place, but instead all share a goal: to win. Another example is a project team.  Colleagues who spend time together but do not share tasks or projects may simply be referred to as a „group of employees“. However, those who work together to, for example, provide a service to a client, are commonly named a „project team“.

Der Unterschied zwischen einer Gruppe und einem Team wird bei der Sportart Fußball sehr deutlich. Wenn eine Saison neu startet kommen neue Spieler aus den jüngeren Jahrgängen neu in die Mannschaft. Alle sind da um Fußball zu spielen, aber die verschiedenen Jahrgänge kennen sich anfangs nicht sehr gut. Es herrscht kein Vertrauen und man weiß auch nicht wie gut der neue Mitspieler ist. Deshalb wird oftmals der Ball zu seinen vertrauten Mitspielern gepasst anstatt zu seinem neuen Mitspieler, der eigentlich eine viel bessere Option wäre. Das führt dazu, dass der Fokus gemeinsam das Spiel zu gewinnen in den Hintergrund gerät. Sowas ist kein Team sondern eine Gruppe. Erst wenn die Jahrgänge sich mit der Zeit kennenlernen, wissen wie gut jemand ist und man Vertrauen zueinander aufbaut wird die Mannschaft ein Team. Nun haben sie alle zusammen ein Ziel und zwar die kommenden Fußballspiele zu gewinnen. Das erzielen sie durch gemeinsame Zusammenarbeit und Zusammenhalt.
Ein zweites Beispiel ist die Bundeswehr. Dort fangen viele Männer und Frauen an für ihr Land zu dienen. Anfangs sind sie eine Gruppe von Leuten die ihrem Land dienen möchten. Wenn man sie direkt in den Einsatz schicken würde, würde wahrscheinlich jeder versuchen zu überleben und sie würden nicht zusammen am richtigen Ziel der Mission arbeiten. Deshalb absolvieren sie zusammen ein hartes Training, was sie zusammenschweißt und sie ein Team werden lässt. Jetzt haben sie den nötigen Teamgeist um zusammen ihren Einsatz erfolgreich zu meistern.

Eine Gruppe ist eine Anzahl von Menschen, die über eine schwache Verbindung miteinander verbunden sind.
Die Gruppe arbeitet nicht an gemeinsamen Zielen bzw. arbeitet nicht miteinander.

 Beispiel: Eine Freundesgruppe unter Schülern, sie besuchen den Unterricht gemeinsam und teilen somit diese
Aktivität, aber sie arbeiten an den Hausaufgaben alleine und fokussieren sich nicht gemeinsam darauf, das Fach zu bestehen.

Team:
Eine Gruppe von Menschen, in der jedes Mitglied stark mit den anderen Mitgliedern verbunden ist. Jeder kennt die Stärken und Schwächen seiner Kameraden und übernimmt Arbeit so, dass die Stärken der anderen besonders
Produktiv für die Arbeit am gemeinsamen Ziel hervortreten.

Beispiel:
Eine Projektarbeit von Studenten, alle arbeiten daran eine gewisse Software zu entwickeln, die Arbeit wird
nach den entsprechenden Stärken aufgeteilt.

Groups are simply a band of people. People in a group are appointed to it by specific attribute(s). They don't have to have same goals or work on the same thing, nor must they coorperate. This is however mandatory for people in a same team. People in a team work together to achieve something and do this as a whole instead of individuals. For instance, all software engineers working at Microsoft can be defined as a group of software engineers. However, some of them work on the Windows OS, some of them on the Office suite, others on other software projects that could have very few to do with the first two products, therefore they cannot be called a team. All developers working on the Windows OS however can be called a team as thet have a common goal and all contribute to the same product, and they must cooperate to complete this whole operating system, each individual is only responsible for a small feature. 
Such example also exist in our EIST course, during which a whole group of people can be seen on stage. Aside from our lecturers, there're exercise instructors and also many tutors behind the scene, who all do their own part to assist we students in our study of EIST. There's even the tech support who fixed the cable when our professor accidentally tipped the wire breaking the projector signal. Each one does his or her part in this gigantic course and cooperate to make the course possible, this is a great example of team work, and the reason why this group can be called a team.

- group: students attending a lecture
- team: multiple people working together on the shared goal of building a social network

Team : shared goals / shared success or failure
group : individual goals / individual success or failure

Group:
A number of people that have some relationship to each other so they are loosely connected. They do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose.

For example a learn group of five people. Everyone is focusing on their own outcomes .  Every individual works on his own and for their goals.

Team:
Any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal. Everyone is strongly connected and they focus on specific outcome. They are doing the same activity.

For example:
Many sports require team work like dragon boat paddling. Everyone is focusing on the speed therefore their movement have to be synchron.

Group: people that have some relationship to one another
            they are loosely connected to work together to finish a task
            each person works on his own in his independence
            they are in an organisation, to satisfy the social or psychological human needs
            e.g. trade unions, friendship circles, airline flight crew

Team: group of people who have the same activity and dedication with a common goal/achievement
          e.g. in order to win a competition people in a sports team have to work/play closely together to win 
          matches

Group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another
• Participants are loosely connected
• Do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose
• Every individual works on his own
Example: all students of EIST
Team: any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal,
especially referring to sports and work
• Participants are strongly connected
• Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities
• Members need to work together
Example: students of a project team

A group is a loosely coupled amount of people who most likely don't share a common goal.  
After the meeting the members of a group tend to work alone following their individual goals.
On the other hand, a team is any group of people whose members are strongly connected to each other through a common dream or goal and they run together towards the best outcome.

My example for a team would be an established volleyball team whose members have played for quite some time with each other. The players may take different roles during the game but all of them aim to win for their team or to become the best team (bigger goal).

An insufficient example would be just 6 kids who came across each other on a playground and who spontaneously decided to play volleyball out of boredom. It may seem like they have a common purpose (to win) but they don‘t focus on it as a team - instead they play individually to show off themselves. This would be an example for a group.

The difference between a group and a team lies in the member's relationship. A group is a only loose collection of people with no specific goal in mind. In contrast to that, a team consists of several members that, through working together and supporting each other, try to achieve common tasks and objectives. 
Moreover, a team is much more structured than a group. Team members have different roles and tasks, whereas a group has no such structure.

For the example, let's look at a football stadium. Here, you can find two groups: 1) the crowd and 2) the players. 

1) The crowd is just a group, since most of the people aren't connected in a significant way. Additionally, there can be several reasons as to why they came to watch. Some want to support their club, others just want to enjoy a game of basketball. Therefore, there is no common goal.

2) The players of a club are a team. They work together, rely on each other and all try to win the game. In comparison to the crowd, these people are more organized, because they are assigned specific positions, roles and tasks in order to achieve their objectives more effectively.

The differences between groups and teams is that in groups, there are many people that don't necessarily know each other or work towards the same purpose unlike teams, who put their effort into completing one task and working together more closely to finish said task.

One of the differences can be seen how decisions are made; a group collectively agrees and makes decisions together, while a team usually has a team leader that holds the authority over decision making, the leadership is more structured.

And as already pointed out, working in a group usually means that there isn't the same level of trust between each individual because the working environment lacks the connections that a team has, as working towards one common goal usually means that there is a high degree of synergy (for lack of a better word) and thus collaboration is a lot easier.

A group of people is for example a view students who are friends with each other. They are all doing their PGDP homework, everybody is working individually, and everyone is solving individual tasks. On the other hand, a team is a bunch of people working together on one common project, for example programming a new calendar software, they are all strongly connected by the same bigger task and goal to find solutions how to implement the calendar. Everyone solves tasks that are needed to achieve the common goal. They divide the tasks among each other and work together towards the goal of programming a better calendar application.

The main difference which seperates a group from a team is that in a team the members work towards a common goal whereas in a group everyone works on his own. Moreover, what sets apart a team from a group is also the much closer relationship between the members of said team in contrast to the loose connection between members of a group. An example for a group would be your typical classroom, with for instance 30 people. All of them are loosely connected, bearing in mind only their own goals and working towards a good grade only for themselves, whereas if you take a study group (not a fitting name considering it is actually a team :)) which meets every week or so, the members of that study team work towards a common goal, improving their grades in a specific subject and helping one another achieve said goal. Furthermore due to the frequent contact and the ups and downs throughout the school year the members of the study team have a much closer connection opposed to your regular classmate.

People in a group are loosely connected and related to one another, every individual works on his own and they do not share a common purpose. For example, people attending workshops only want to finish their own works without considering others' views.
While a group of people in a team shares a common goal within the same activity, participants are strongly connected and need to work together to achieve a specific outcome and it requires coordination of tasks and activities. For example, within a football team every football player has its own role (goalkeeper, striker, linebacker etc.), by cooperating with each other they tend to make more goals together.

A team is a group of people trying to work on the same problem and help or complement each other. 

A group is a number of people which may have a relationship with each other, but don't work on the same problem/ activity together. 

First example-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The people in a group of cooking people only cook for themselves independently.
A team of cooking people will assist each other so the food gets as good as possible.

If u give a group of people a problem to solve, everyone surely will try to solve it the best way they can imagine it and noone is going to interrupt them doing so.
Giving a team a problem to solve, they can't necessarily work without limitations since their work has to be compatible with the work of the others.

Second example-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In teams you always should have a distribution of work. To maximize the quality of the final product everyone is doing their own bit of work.

If a team is making ice cream for example one would produce the ice and another one the waffles to hold the ice.

A group e.g. a number of students enrolled in the same course have a loose connection to each other whereas a team e.g. an engineering team has much more in common. They work together to reach one goal.

Also the students work on their own, while the engineering team has to work together.

In a group everyone is focused on themselves and works mostly alone. The members might have different goals and expectations that do not align with each other. An example would be a school class where despite the students having relations with each other, they are mostly expected to work alone and focus on their own grades.

In a team there is a common goal connecting and driving the members to do better. It is necessary to work together and help each other to achieve this goal. An example would be a sports team that trains together to do better in competitions usually led by a trainer that coordinates exercises for all the members. Teamwork of all members and frequent trainings together are required to reach their goals and expectations.

A group is a number of people, who have a relationship or connetction between each other. The group participants are mainly independend from each other and their connection or ´relationship is often weakly. A team is a stronger connected group. They share a common goal, this requires planning and organisiation, thus they can work together effectively.

A simple explanation of that difference would be at a football match. The two football clubs are teams and the fans are groups. Each player of a club trains with the other, and with their trainer and captain they organize and plan. The players are dependend on each other, because to achieve victory the keeper has to protect the gate and the attackers have to try to shoot goals. Only by working together they can win the match. By the contrary the fans can only be regarded as a group. They may have a common goal, to see their club win, but they are not closely connected. They are not dependend on each other, if one of them goes home during the match or switches sides, the endresult stays the same. After the match they won´t share a goal and loose their connection.

Group: a number of people who share certain characteristics working individually. 

Team: a group of people working together to achieve a common goal.
A team is a group of people with a common objective, that come together and join efforts to produce an outcome. A group is a number of people with no special connection and no common motive.

Groups are simply a loose association of people based on a common attribute (like a set in Maths). All redheads, for example, make up a group. Not every member of the group has to know every other redhead. Even though all redheads might fight for a common cause (eradication of stereotypes about redheads (?)), everyone does this on an individual level. 

A team would be a close-knit collection of people that share a common goal and understanding of how to reach that goal and are aware of team structures. Accountability is shared, continuous communication is vital and all people have consented to being in this team. Decisions are usually made as a group after discussions.
In this example, a team might be a group of redheads that organise an annual meeting. They discuss the agenda, plan events etc., which binds them together more closely than just their hair colour or individual activism.

An example for a group is the number of all people who’s parents are living in the United Kingdom. They have a lowely connection and no common focus.

A group is a number of independent individuals with separate goals while a team is an interdependent group of individuals who share responsibility and work towards a common goal. In other words the difference between both lays in how dependant they are from one another and wether or not they share a common goal.
 
 Ex1: Semiconductor industry experts meeting in a conference about H2O2 concentrators can be referred to as a group since these independant people are gathered in the same place for the mere reason of having the same interests/ career not because they're working together to achieve something.

 Ex2: Two parents bringing up their baby and trying to give him/ her/ they the best childhood possible is a team since these two individuals have a same goal and are working interdependently to reach it while communicating with one another.

Every team is a group but not every group is a team. A group is just a collection of people that have the same interests but don't necessarily work on the same interests. This means that they have problems in pursuing one identical goal. One example is a football team. A group of people that just want to play football but don't have the same goals wohnt function as well as a team that plays together for several years and function as one identical force. Groups consist of people who don't have a strong bond to each other and in a general manner consist of more people than teams. They are somewhat connected to each other but this connection is not enough to make them participate in a single goal and to commit specific tasks together. Teams, on the other hand, are actually groups of people that act together and devote themselves together to a specific goal.

1- A group of people participated in a handball course doesn't have a strong bond to each other. They are participating but there is not a specific goal that this group of people has in common. It can be argued that the goal can be "learning handball" but nobody works together to achieve this goal, also this goal is also superficial and can vary since some people may want to play handball to gain muscle or create endurance. Whereas if a team from this group of people is created, there is a goal that bonds this team and it is "winning handball games". Hence, this team works together to achieve this goal and devotes their concentration to this specific goal.

2- Another example would be the group of people participating in the EIST course. This group of people doesn't share a common goal: Some people may just be concentrated on passing the EIST course whereas some people may be concentrated more on how to implement these techniques into real-life projects, thus creating projects and not interested in whether or not they will pass the course. If there is a team from this group of people created, though, they will have the same goal, for example implementing these newly learned techniques in an application. Thus, they will be bonded to each other which they will demonstrate with their devotion to the goal by working together.

There are several differences between groups and teams. Participants in the group have something in common and are roughly associated. However, they do not have a common goal for a specific outcome and everyone is working on his own.  

On the other hand, a team is the collection of people, who are strongly linked together to achieve a common objective / goal and coordinate tasks and activities. It is important here that everyone is working as a team. 

Examples: 

Debate Club Munich is a group - a collection of individuals; 
When a group of employees has to create a new company website for the firm, they become a team to work together on this project until its completion.


If people share an elevator ride, they are a group; 
However, if the elevator gets stuck, they become a team.

A group is a collection of people with some shared interest.

A team is a group of people working together to achieve a shared goal through collaboration.

A group is simply a mass of people that are not closely related to one another. Each member of the group is focused and striving towards their personal goals and the group isn’t focused on achieving a common goal.
For example, the people taking the train to work in the morning could be considered a group. Everyone is focused on getting to their workplace on time and they have little regard for other passenger’s goals. 
In a team, the people are closer connected and instead of striving towards their own achievements, they focus on a common goal. In order to reach this goal the team members have to cooperate and coordinate their efforts.
An example of a team would be the crew of a sailing ship. The people on the ship share the goal of sailing to a specific destination. Therefore they have to work together and split up the tasks. Only through teamwork and coordination can they achieve their common goal.

A group is a number of people who are bound mostly by organisational reasons with limited common purpose, for example a group of students, grouped by the teacher to assess together, or a group of people leaving a bus. A team is bound not only by organisation but also a common purpose, following a common goal or vision, with stronger connection and collaboration among members, for example a sports team or a team at work.

Teams, especially successful ones, consist of people who are counting on each other with a common goal in mind, whereas members of a group don't necessarily have this. For example, as students, we don't all know each other, and we don't necessarily share a common distinct goal.
But a family of penguins need to work together to survive, they are a team. Thought groups of students can work on their own, this isn't the case for a team.

A group has a relationship to each other maybe because of some interests they share with each other, but don't have a common goal they try to reach. For example: Meeting with friends for a night out or some people which go on a hike and the only goal is to have a nice day in the mountains.
A Team has a goal where everyone of the members is highly involved to fulfill it. They're highly connected and everyone has to participate to get the best possible outcome. For example a soccer team. 1. A group is simply individuals classed together who bear common traits, e.g. employees working at the same company.
A team also bears characteristics of a group, though, in terms of functionality, is more purposeful and structured. It contains individuals classed together who have specific skill sets who are then assigned different objectives and working as a unit to achieve a common goal in mind, e.g. the marketing team working on promoting a product publicly for the company, working on strategies, e.g. social media campaign, product placement in films and tv shows, market research, which all requires different skill sets from individuals in the team.

2. In a group, the degree of communication between its members may vary a lot due to the low degree of interdependence, e.g. in the aforementioned group of employees, the marketing team and the security team may not interact much at all with each other despite working at the same company.
Whereas in a team, its members are more aware of each other, as they need to work with each other to complete goals and are more interdependent, e.g. whether the marketing team successfully promotes the product depends on whether each task in the team was performed well enough to achieve that goal, which requires regular communication between its members.

A group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another. And a team is anz group or people involved in the same activity with a common goal especially referring to sports and work.
One difference between a group and a team is that in a group participants are only loosely connected while in a team they are strongly connected what is very important for team work.
Another difference is the focus. Teams focus on a specific outcome, which  requires coordination of tasks. So in other words they need to work and pull together. Groups don’t focus on specific outcomes. In a group every individual works on his own. So they are really independent.

Differrence:
1. Paticipants in group have loose connection while team members have tight connection.
2.Participants in group do not focus on a specific outcome or purpose while team participants do.
3.Group members work individually while team members work together.
e.g.:
A reading group holds meetings every Saturday, but it doesn't require all its members show up every week. As a group member, you don't have to know each other very well. Participants may have various reasons to join this group: some of them want to share their comments about a book, some of them want to relate to people, some might just want to relax in this way. Group members don't cooperate, they do the readings on their own.
In a football team, team members share a same goal - they want to achieve more champions with joint efforts. Their roles are divided - there are keeper, back, midfield and forward. In general they also share strong emotion ties with each other.

In a group the individuals work independently of each other, sometimes their interests touch. But they do not focus on achieving a common goal. Team members, on the other hand, are well aware of their independence, but know that personal goals or, more importantly, the common goal of the team are best achieved with mutual support. Also, in contrast to groups, a common goal is paramount.
Another aspect regarding the differences between groups and teams is that individual members of a group tend to focus on themselves because they are not sufficiently involved in planning the group's goals (“Everyone for him/herself”). In contrast to that, members of a team feel ownership of their job or unit because they identify with the goals they (partially) helped develop ("All for one and one for all").

Example group: Students who take certain subject/ study the same (for example all students of the lecture "Introduction to Software Engineering"). They each work for themselves because they want to pass their studies. 

In a team – example:  soccer team like FCBayern, etc. – one person alone can't really achieve anything. The common goal is to win as a team. Other example: project teams in e.g. consulting firms.

A group is a number of individuals who have a common interest, but no common goals. For example, a group of students attending to the same course share interest on the topic. Some of them may want to improve their knowledge and get a good note, while others may only want to obtain the credits granted for passing the exam. They have different goals.

Another difference is about the independent work and the interdependent work. For example, in a team project all members want to get an academic project done. The team has a discussion and agrees on the way to address assignments and distribute the workload to achieve the team's goals. The work of each member depends on the others work, and if someone is not able to finish the tasks on time should communicate this to the rest to remove blockers. On the other hand, in a group, one's work is independent of the others' work, since there are not shared goals.

In the following I am going to explain the difference between a group and a team. 
A group is an assemble of people, who are forced or voluntarily put together in order to wants to complete a task. A team is a group of people who have a common goal they want to achieve. They are both very similar to each other, but can not be seen as the same. A group of people is an assemble of individuals who are, forced or voluntarily put together. They use each others individual strengths in order to function as a social group and to get along with each other. Their assembly is often caused by social needs or organisation. They have individual goals and their personal success or failure does not depend on the group. The members of the group are independent and often tend to have a leader who is in charge of organising the group so that the task can be finished. A team on the other hand tend to have several leaders, respectively tend to work as a unit which decides as one leader. They share the same goals, which causes them to work efficiently with each other. For example: In school teachers would often put students in groups in order to complete a task, like a presentation or something similar. The people in the group do not have to have much in common. Their main reason to work with each other is because they have to complete the task and get a grade for it. Every student decides itself which seems as a success to itself. So Student A could be aiming for an A, but student B would be satisfied with an C. They have different goals and are independent. Due to the different goals, the group is not pressured to work efficiently as they have different views on what would be a satisfying way of completing the task. That is why those kind of groups often have a leader who organises and distributes the task to everyone, so that the task can be completed. A team on the other hand share the same goal, for example a basketball team. They have a common goal and want to win the game. In order to do so they have to work together and they have to be equal to each other. Due to the reason that they share the same goals, they are interdependent to each other. They have to act as a unit and can't exclude or look down on the other members of the team as it would be damaging to them achieving their goal.

Group:

A group refers to a collection of individuals who are loosely connected in some way. Each individual operates independently and works towards their own goals.

An example would be a group of students who attend a lecture. While all students would have registered for the course and enrolled at the university, most of the similarities end there. Some students attend to learn the material, others may be more inclined to meet new people or have a chat. On rare occasions some people may choose to ignore the lesson entirely and pursue unrelated activities in the lecture hall.

A second example could be investors or shareholders of a company. Each person acts solely to benefit their own wealth or influence, and there is little coordination involved. The decision to invest, trade, or sell is made purely by considering the advantages to the individual.


Team:

A team refers to a collection of individuals united by a common goal. To this end teams require mutual cooperation, and they strive to work together harmoniously and efficiently on various tasks.

A military division could be recognised as a team, as it is composed of multiple people acting in coordination to achieve a common objective. Each member recognises their role and performs their duty for mutual benefit. The same could be said of a police force, firefighting squad etc.

A sports team is a good example, all members involved strive towards the same goal i.e. to win the game. In order to achieve this goal each person must prioritise the team's best interest and work together, as individual outstanding performances are ultimately less valuable and may even hinder success.

Task: Explain the differences between groups and teams. Point out the differences using two examples in your own words.

Solution: 
(1a) Explanation group: A group consists of a number of people working together. They have individual goals that they work towards together. Although group members work towards separate goals, they have a common interest or common identity characteristics that brings them together.

(1b) Explanation teams: A team also consists of a number of people working together to achieve a common purpose or goal. Each members of the team depends on each other to achieve the goal.

(2a) Example 1 to point out the difference: The first difference is that in a team everyone has the same goals, and in a group members can work towards separate goal, although they have a common interest.

(2b) Example 2 to point out the difference: Teams promote group productivity, while groups promote efficiency: Teams have an advantage when it comes to productivity as team members support each other's work and contribute to solving the overall problem, which makes work more productive.

A group consists of multiple, loosly connected individuals (some of them may know each other, while others don't) without a commen purpose or goal, as such they usually work alone.
In comparison the members of a team share a common goal, which they try to achieve by coordinating (e.g. distributing tasks, reviewing each others work ...) and working together. 
We often find teams in sports like basketball, soccer, football and ice hockey. In such a team, the members need to work together to achieve a certain goal for example winning the champion ship. As such an ice hockey team needs a goal keeper, whose sole job is to keep the puck out of the goal. But that isn't enough for him to win the champion ship. He needs the other players to score goals. For this they need to coordinate and pass the puck between themselves, while also keeping the opponents away. In conclusion every individual of a team also needs to trust the others to do their part. 
An example for a group would be a class of students. They are loosly (and randomly) connected by the school. They may have individual bonds of friendship or other kinds of relationships with each other, however they do not share a common goal but work individualy to pass the class and (long term goal) graduate from school.

Example 1: Soccer
A soccer group wouldn’t play well as they wouldn’t work together/pass the ball to each other, but rather everyone would want to score the goal on his/her own. Everyone might have their own goals (e.g., one wants to impress someone). The performance wouldn’t contain the necessary trust to pass the ball to another person, the skill allocation (knowing the strengths/weaknesses of the other players, e.g., one player fast runner). The people in a soccer team, however, have a strong bound to each other, they work together and coordinate their strengths and weaknesses in order to achieve their shared and focused goal (e.g. win the tournament). 

Example 2: Software project
A software group would contain people who wouldn’t work well together. Everyone would have his/her own goals, e.g., on how to tackle the project. The development of the software would be slow due to missing trust (e.g., view commits of other members to check the correctness). Therefore, software development needs diverse teams with soft skills (communication, collaboration, teamwork, negotiation, presentation). A group can be transformed into a team by 4 stages: 1) Forming (Getting to know each other and establishing a shared vision) 2) Storming (clarifying expectations and establishing client relationships; if there are strong personalities with different standpoints of how to tackle the project, sabotaging behavior can occur) 3) Norming (the team meets and discusses and removes the redundancies which occurred in the previous step) 4) Performing (Build of trust, empowerment, skill allocation)  A software team knows how to contribute tasks to each member as they know the strengths and weaknesses of each other. They trust each other (e.g. don’t check commits of other members of the team) and focus on the same project goal.

A group is basically describes a specific number of people that for some reason have some kind of connection, which does not necessarily have to voluntary. As a consequence of this a group does not share common values or anything related to that and in addition to that individual work is still very common.

Now taking a look at a team, a very strong connection can be recognised, which is due to a shared value / a shared goal, that every single member wants to achieve. Because of this, a team tries everything to achieve the highest possible outcome, which also means to overcome the focus on individual outcome and rather focus on team-work. In order to achieve this, some sort of management must be applied.

An example for a group would be a bunch of students that share the same course. They are a group, because the only connection holding them together is the same choice they made to visit this specific course, but in regards to their work it will still be very individualistic.

On the other hand, taking a look at a startup and their founders, a team can be recognised. This is due to the fact, that every single founder shares the goal of a successful company and therefore they will split the work, so that everyone can contribute in the area of their strengths.

The difference is that in a team everyone shares the same vision and goal. To achieve this goal everyone in a team has to work together in order to realize the expected outcome.

Example for a group:
 A school class. Everyone has a relationship to his classmates, but they have different goals and want to work at different places.

Example for a team:
Workers at a refugee aid association. They share the same vision, because they want to help other people and have to work together in order to be able to help more persons.

A group of people are standing around the tour guide, listening some interesting facts about Munich. The people are barely know each other and some of them are not actually interested in what is being said. 
Nearby in a cafe there is a team of a famous startup: all developers are sharing their ideas and discussing the existing trouble with the parsing data. All members are involved and eager to come with a solution.

A group of students are sitting in a praxis room. Each of them is busy: someone is watching EIST lecture, another guy is learning a new algorithm from GAD, the young student from 1 semester is dealing with PgDP... The silence is there.
Just in the next room a team of students of 3 semester is also busy: they are creating a model for their new EIST project. Every student is listening to and contributing his ideas.

While a group solely refers to several people put together without any further commonalities, a team on the other hand is much more than that. In contrast to a group, a team acts as a united entity and shares a common goal they all strive to achieve.

For example, consider a hackathon: In this case members of a group would merely work on the tasks they personally enjoy. This would lead to a situation where there are a lots of tasks done redundantly (e.g. coding two websites with two technologies because they have different opinions). Also, no common objective is being discussed, or it cannot be agreed upon, so that the tasks also might not even necessary. They are just people working in their own zone that just happen to sit together.

A team on the other hand would work effectively on a goal that was specified before which is being accepted by everyone in that team as a common goal. Furthermore, all the different tasks are distributed evenly among everyone. Best case scenario would even be that every member has a set area of competence that they are responsible for.

Another example could be a basketball team. It is even called a team because players have to act in a united way such that they are understanding if someone else makes a mistake or they do not act arrogantly when they scored a point.

If they were only a group every member would only chase after their personal goals (e.g. scoring as many points themselves as possible) which is often times very distinct from the goal of the entire team (scoring as many points together). This would cause selfish behavior and the team would be doomed.

The difference between a Team and a Group is That the Team is a more specific type of group in which all members work together towards a common goal and have stronger bonds with one another.
One example could be a sports Team for example a soccer Team in which each player has the same goal, beat the enemy Team together. To achieve this goal they each have to know their strengths and weaknesses and work together to earn their victory.Another example for a Team could be a Team of cooks that each work together to create a dish in the kitchen, each having a role that befits their strengths. A Group is more loosely connected and people usually work for themselves. As an example we could have a group of students that each study for their own benefit and do not really need to know each other or a Group of teachers at schools which teach different subjects.

Eine Gruppe ist erst einmal nur eine Menge an Personen die irgendwie zueinander in Beziehung stehen. Die Gruppe fokussiert sich nicht auf ein gemeinsames Ziel und jeder arbeitet eigenständig. Ein Team hingegen hat ein gemeinsames Ziel und ist eine kommunikative, gut strukturierte, zielstrebige und sich gegenseitig unterstützende Gruppe. 

Während jetzt in einer schlichten Gruppe jeder einfach alleine loslegen würde, tauscht sich ein Team zuerst aus und teilt sich die Aufgabe ein. Eben weil sich eine Gruppe nicht auf ein gemeinsames Ziel fokussiert, kann sie ihre Mitglieder nicht effizient einsetzen. Ein Team wird die selbe Arbeit *gemeinsam* besser und schneller erledigen können.

Ein gut eingespieltes Team ist sich außerdem den Stärken und Schwächen der jeweils anderen bewusst und hat Vertrauen in deren Fähigkeiten. Das wiederum kann man von einer schlichten Gruppe nicht behaupten und das wird dann zu Problemen bei der Aufgabe führen. Das Team wird hier wieder das Qualitativ hochwertigere Produkt abliefern können.

A group is a number of people that are loosely connected and have some relationship to one another. The people in a group do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose. In a group, every individual works on his own.
An example of a group is the people in a lecture. They are a group, but they do not really work to a shared goal as they work individually in order to pass the course. A second example is members of a gym. They are all members of the same gym, yet they do not work towards a shared goal, but rather every individual has their own specific goal.

A team on the other hand is any group of people with a common goal that work in the same activity. Team members are strongly connected and all focus on a specific common outcome. All team members must work together to achieve the common goal.
An example of a team is a football team. The team members are strongly connected as they work towards winning the game and the championship and they must do it together. A second example would be the team members in the tutor groups for this very course. All members must participate in order to achieve the shared goal of solving a specific software design problem and presenting it by the end of the semester.

Groups are just some people with a relationship. Example: Students

Each member of a group focuses on achieving its individual goals while in a team there is a shared team goal. It is similar in terms of responsability: In a group every member is responsible for his own success or failure while in a team there is a collective responsability. So overall in a group the members are independent to each other where in contrary a team works as one entity.

Whereas, a team would be people that  are working in the same field in a company or even working on a project together. As these people are more closely connected and need to directly work together, communicate and coordinate to reach the same outcome.

Group:
A group is a bunch of people, where you have a kind of relationship to the others, but in fact you don't know each other very well (loosely connected). There is no clear common goal and each one works more on hin own. E.g. So to say it's like at the beginning of the EIST group work, but where you develop over time (with the 4 stages - forming, storming, norming and performing) to build a team.

Team: 
In comparison a team consist of people having a common goal, doing the same activity and are strongly connected. Example 1:
In a football stadium, all spectators together are a group, because they are loosely connected, since they watch the game together in a stadium, but they are not a team, since there are different aims among the spectators, since not every spectator is a fan of the same football team. Thus, some spectators pursue different goals and do not have a common will.

Example 2: 
In a cinema, the audience is a group. They are loosely connected because they all have the goal of watching the same film, but the viewers do not know each other and also want to "achieve" their goal (watching the film) in peace for themselves. The viewers also do not have to work together to achieve the goal. A team in the cinema would be the staff at the snack bar. They all know each other well, have the same tasks and also one goal, to sell as much as possible, satisfy the customers and keep everything clean. To achieve this goal, they all have to stick together.

A group is a set of multiple people, that share some attributes, but they don't really know a lot about each other and they don't really work together or have the same goals.

A team is a set of people, that know each other and have common goals (e.g. finishing a project). They have to work together and are more connected to each other.

All the programmers of a company are a group for example. They don't really know each other and work on different projects or do their own research.

The programmers, that work together on an app (e.g. a new banking app) are a team, as they share a common goal and know each other better.

A group is a collection of people with a loose relationship who do not have a common goal and who mainly focus on themselves.

Groups are an accumulation of people, whereas teams are groups of people working together towards a common goal. This also represents in their attitude towards their mates. A groups' intention(s) can be much more individual than that one of a team, since they might not cooperate as much as you would expect from a team. A team should also be more permanent than a group so that the people in it can adjust to each other in order to help each other out the most. 

You can look at professional sports teams as opposed to casual ones in volleyball for example. You will most likely find that the latter will struggle to find success in it respective sport on a large scale, no matter how good the individuals are. Each person has its own strengths and preferences in regard to how they play. Some might need the ball to be higher, so that they have enough time to hit the ball. Some might want the ball to be in a position to hit it faster, so that it's harder to block. If the second player was to be given a rather slow ball, he might even be in a position to miss it altogether and vice versa. So to speak, in order to work like a well oiled machine, it is best for a group of people to understand and know each other so that one can cooperate with them in the best manner as well as compensate for some weaknesses of their respective mates. Precisely this makes a team a team.

A group is a number of people, which gathered together without a common target. A Team is a number of people which gathered together working towards a common target. Members of a team usually are more united than a group.

A football team is a example for Team, in which there are people playing in different position, cooperating closely with each other towards a common target "Winning the game".
