Generally said, a group is "a number of people that have a relationship to one another", while a team is a "group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work". (Krusche, Stefan (2022): Introduction to Software L01. S.104). While any team is a group, not every group is automatically a team. A team arguably is a more emotionally motivated or connected group, that distincts itself from a group, because the team actively tries to work towards a common goal. The members of a team did not meet out of pure coincidence, but for a common purpose. There are two great examples for a group and a team. A soccer team as the team, and a group of tourists, being lead by a guide.

The soccer team has a common goal. Every person in the team wants their own team to succeed and tries their personal best, in order to win, or at least not to let the opposing team win. In a group of tourists, there is no common goal. While tourists arguably all want to see a certain region or city, they are just together, because of their individual goals of listening to the tour guide, or getting to know the place of interest better. They do not work together, and they do not need to work together in order to achieve their goals. In a soccer team however, all of the players work together with their different and unique strengths and skills in order to succeed in something, that they could not succeed in alone, winning agains the other team. The members of a team have a strong team sense, they believe in each other and know that they can only win together. All of this makes a soccer TEAM very different from a GROUP of tourists.

A group are certain people that have some sort of relationship to another but which aren't as involved in the same activity as a team. That means that members of a team are much more connected with each other then in a group and they focuse more on a specific problem/task in comparison to a group.

An example for a team for example would be a soccer team that together strive for victory and with that share a common goal. An example for a group on the other hand would be a travel group. The only reason these people are together is because they either want to have less travel expenses or they wanted to have some sort of communal atmosphere which isn't anywhere the experience you would have with a team.

The core difference between a group and a team is that a team has a strong bond that is reflected in the way the people in a team interact with each other and work towards a common goal. In order to achieve that goal, a team has to work closely together and therefore has to manage tasks and divide them between the members of the team. A group on the other hand does not have that specific target that everyone wants to achieve. For achieving a goal that a person in a member in a group has as its target, one has to work towards that goal individually and cannot expect others to works together.

An example for a group would be the citizens in Germany. They do not have a common target that all of them strive towards. They are not tightly connected and every person in the mentioned group has to work towards their goal individually. Therefore, it meets every criteria for a group.

An example for a team would be a football team. They do have a common target (winning the football match) that all of them want to achieve. They have a very close bond due to their common goal and their shared interest (football). In order to attain that certain achievement they have in common, they have to divide and conquer their tasks and the team needs to work together and do things as a community. Therefore, it meets every criteria for a team.

A group is a "group" of people who are connected to each other in some relationship (maybe because they are friends or study the same subject).
A team is a "group" of people who work on the same work and have a goal they want to achieve together (e.g. work they complete together or sports teams).

A group is made up of a number of people, related to each other, whereas a team is a made up of people working together towards a common goal, reaching its best potential with communication.

A group could be the students in the mensa - they all eat together, but by themselves.
A team could be the MVV staff, syncronizing their work together to keep the U Bahn running

A group is a loosely coupled amount of people. The members are not working together, but on theri own. An example is an online languarge course: every member has the goal to improve the languarge skills, but the extend can differ. 

A team is a group of people with a common goal. The members need each other to achive the goal. An example is a football tam. The goal keeper alone can't win the game, he also needs the other players and the other players need the goal keeper.

Der erste Unterschied ist die Beziehung zwischen den Mitgliedern. In einem Team vertrauen und schätzen sich die Leute gegenseitig, während in einer Gruppe man sich eher fremd ist. Ein Team hat den Vorteil, dass man sich besser einschätzen kann und die Fähigkeiten des Anderen kennt. Zum Beispiel müssen in einer Fußball Mannschaft die Spieler ein Team bilden, da sie ansonsten nicht die Stärken und Schwächen der Anderen kennen würden. Die Harmonie untereinander wäre gestört und die Mannschaft würde öfters verlieren.

Der nächste Unterschied besteht darin, dass ein Team ein Ziel hat. Eine Gruppe hat an sich kein Ziel. Die Mitglieder einer Gruppe haben vielleicht zwar die gleiche Aufgabe, haben aber zum Beispiel unterschiedliche Vorstellungen der Umsetzung und der Erfüllung der Aufgabe. In einem Team hat man sich auf ein Vorgehen geeinigt. Zum Beispiel mehrere Leute sollen eine Software entwickeln, die in Subsysteme zerlegt werden konnte, sodass jeder nur noch für ein Subsystem verantwortlich ist. Dann führen unterschiedliche Vorgehensweisen dazu, dass jeder drauf los programmiert mit der Programmiersprache seiner Wahl, sodass die Schnittstellen zwischen den Subsystemen nur noch mit sehr uneleganten und schlecht erweiterbaren Lösungen gestaltet werden können. In einem Team hätte man vermutlich mit dem Entwurf der Schnittstellen begonnen, damit solche Probleme gar nicht erst entstehen können.

A group is several people that doesn't have to know each other, it simply means, that there are similarities between them, like the place where they are at the moment or the subject they are studying. They are independent of each other and have no common goal.

A team describes a group of people who trust and understand each other so they can work together efficiently to achieve goals faster. They have the same goals , a similar mindset and they know that they can rely on other team members.

In a lecture hall is a big group of students, that study the same subject, but they often don't even know each other and mostly work alone.
A football team is a good example for a team, because they need to trust each other and play as a team, to complete the common task which is winning the game.

A group is a number of people which have some kind of relationship to each other, whereas a team is a number of people which engage in the same activity with the same goal. Logically a team is a group, but a group is not necesarry a team.
The difference of engaging in the same activity can be explained by looking at a soccer team like the FC Bayern München. All the players in the team are playing soccer, whereas a people in a friendgroup for example can engage in different types of sport like handball, volleyball, ...
By looking at a development team for a new PC game the common goal is the production of a new game, which forces the developers to work together. On the other hand a group like a friend group are working in different companies across many industries.

Group is a bunch of independent individuals. They do not share common goals and they are not tightly connected. They don't work together. Example: People working out in a gym individually

Team on the other hand, is a bunch of individuals who share common goals. They are connected with each other. Teems need to be coordinated. The individuals in a team work together. Example: Basketball team

There are 3 big differences between groups and teams. The first is the connection between the members of the group or team. In a group the members don't have strong relationships and are not connected very strong. In a team on the other hand they are closely linked. The focus of a group and a team is also very different. While there is no common goal for a group, a team has a common desired outcome the team is working towards. The last big difference is that a team requires teamwork, meaning everybody works together for the same goal, whereas in a group every member works independently for their own goal. An example for a group is a family. All members are connected but there is no common desired outcome everybody works for, instead everybody tries to achieve their own goals and doesnt have to work together with other members. An example for a team is the fire brigade where members are connected much stronger. There is the obvious common goal of extinguishing a fire and everybody has to work together to make this happen and there's a good communication and coordination required.

The people in a group are only loosely connected, whereas in a team they have closer relationships because they share a common goal or vision. People in groups normally just work on their own, but in teams the members rely heavily on collaboration to reach their common goal.
The people in a bus are just a group and not a team, because even though they literally have a common destination, they are not working together to get there nor are they closely related.
The cooks in a restaurant kitchen are a team because they all work towards the common goal of preparing the dishes for the customers. Even if not all cooks work on every single dish, they are still collaborating to reach a bigger, shared goal.

A group is just a bunch of people, without any specific roles or even without knowing each other. A team is a bunch of people who have some shared interest and specific roles so that everybody in that team can focus on only a few things and do them really great instead of focusing on everything.

For example if a group of three people wants to go on a hike everybody books their own ticket to the destination, their own Hotel and have made a plan on the route of the hike and make compromises so everybody is pleased. On the other hand if a team of three plans to go on a hike there could be one of them booking the train, one of them booking the hotel and the third one planning the route. This could for example mean that everybody in the team has some benefits like a cheaper journey (e.g. due to Bayernticket/ shared hotel room) or a better planned route since this was the only thing someone had to focus on.

Another example where working as a team is very important are special forces in the police. They all have their specific roles like breaching or defusing bombs and even their life might be depending on the work of the rest of the team but that makes them more efficient and successful than for example a more unstructured and unorganized group of terrorists.

team: Like a sports team. Working together on a shared goal, sharing work/tasks. There is trust in your teammates and there skills, (hopefully) a good relationship between the people (nearly friends). 

group: Like a tutorial group. No common goals/expectations. Working on your own. Maybe don't know each participant.

A group is a loosely connected group of people with no common ambition, while participants of a team work closely together. Two Examples in sports would be a random group of people in the gym and a team in soccer. A Person in the gym has no personal relationship with the other people there and pursues their own goals. The work of the others doesn't really affect them and there is no common goal. In soccer teamwork, tactics, coordination, and communication are needed to win against the opponent. The players need to have trust in each other's abilities and fulfill their roles for the team.

A group consists of three or more persons, who don't necesseraly have to know each other and have a loose connection. Each person has his own goal and works on his own to achive it.
A team is a group of people, who share a common goal and work together to achieve said goal. The members of the group know each other and trust each other in order work together.

For example a class of students is a group in which each student wants to pass the course, but doesn't have to work with another student to pass the final test. A student probably knows some other students, but not the whole class.
A footballteam is an example of a group. They have the common goal to win their football games and they train together to get better players and to get to know the other players in order to work better together.

The teams are more about sharing responsibilities, complementing each other and joining efforts. In the groups, members are free to process and follow their goals focusing on individual tasks. An example of the team can be the group of employees(Scrum team, Marketing team for the same product) working together for the same goal with mutual efforts, whereas a group example might be, for instance, a set of professionals hired temporarily to tackle some kind of problem( a group of freelancers to build different pipelines, developing web application for the Data Analytics team).

Group: e.g. People working together in the same company
 	- Participants are loosely connected: Working together in the same department

	- Do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose: Everyone has his own goal (that may of course be set by the boss)

	- Every individual works on his own: Everyone has his own field he/she works in and money comes in at the end of the month anyway


Team: e.g. People working together on the same project
 	- Participants are strongly connected: Working on the same or very similar task (e.g. in a project)

 	- Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities: All group partners have the same goal -> a successful project

 	- Members need to work together: All people need to work together for the project to be a success and monetary compensation may depend on the success

Eine Gruppe, sind Personen, welche man miteinander in Verbindung bringt, welche jedoch nicht Zusammenarbeiten oder Kooperieren. Zum Beispiel eine WG, in der die Aufgabe des Geschirr Abwasches immer weitergegeben wird. Ein Team hingegen, sind Personen, welche Kommunizieren, Kooperieren und Zusammenarbeiten. Im Hinblick auf die WG, könnte man ein Team formen, indem eine Person Abwäscht und die andere Person abtrocknet. Somit arbeiten beide auf das selbe Ziel hinaus, die Wohnung sauber zu halten.

a Group is basically composed of people that are bound by the same categorization or circumstances that brought them together possibly with no common interests and without the need of each other to accomplish or reach their goals because everyone can work on hisown and still achieve his purpose. 

EX : group of Informatik Students, group of teachers

a Team is a group of people that have a common goal to reach and are considered like pieces of a puzzle. That means they complete each other and that the work can only be done with the participation of all the team members and everyone is envolved and concerned or at least that's what they believe. 

EX : team of Informatik Students building a program, team of scientists trying to find the COVID-19's vaccine

The difference between a group and a team is that people in a group work for their own and are part of the group due to a certain group-creating criteria while in a team people have a shared goal they try to reach together and therefore they usually have a stronger bond to one and another. For example we as a course are a group of students, that usually work individually and are seen as a group because we all sit in the same lecture. In a software company for example however we speak of teams, because they work together as a team on the next sprint, their shared goal, and therefore have a stronger bond.

An example of a team would be playing a sport like football or cricket. It requires trust and collaboration. The players work together to win the game. There is no scope to pick up the slack of another player. 

An example of a group would be, for example, our varsity/cohort (BSc MMT 2025, MSc MMT 2023 etc). Everyone works individually on their own sets of goals and aspirations. One of the only connections we have is the fact that we belong to the same varsity.

When some people are loosely connected, that assortment of people is called a group. When such a group has a common goal and members have to work together to achieve that goal, stronger connections arise and the group is now called a team.
 

Example 1: 

All students enrolled in a course form a group, because they all are registered for the same course they are loosely connected. But they don't have a common and specific goal for which they have to work closely together to be successful.  Everybody studies more or less on their own.

Now a small subgroup of participants gets assigned to work on a project together. They now have a common and distinct goal (completing the project) for which they have to work closely together and split up the task among themselves. So now they are called a team.


Example 2:
Another good example comes from sports. All the people who have a membership for the same gym are only loosely connected and mainly work out on their own without a common goal, for which they have to work together or divide the task among themselves. Therefore they form a group.

In contrast, a racing team as the name implies is a team, because they have a common and defined goal (winning the race). But in order to achieve that all the people have to work closely together and also need to assign specific tasks (driver, engineer, pit crew....) among themselves.

Group means a group of people who have share the same effort in particular area. 
For example, in tutorial group of EIST, students are sitting together to join tutor's class.

Team means a group of people share same goal.
For example, football team of FC Bayern, the goal of the team : win the game.

A group is just a bunch of people loosely connected but they dont feel like they can trust or count on each other.
A team is a group of people who trust each other, work towards the same goals and in a good team the members have a good synergy which makes them even more productive than if everyone would just work on their own.

A group differs from a team in the sense that their members are working towards a common goal and use teamwork to reach their goal(s). 

Example 1: A couple of friends playing recreational soccer during their free time vs. a couple of friends in the same team with a common goal of winning their local championship.

Example 2: Five students that meet on a regular basis for their Tutor Sessions at University vs. these same five students working on a project together that they'll have to present at the end of the semester.

When talking about groups, the relationship between the people of a group is not specified. They might have just met, maybe they know each other already, like/dislike each other, etc. E.g. when students are divided into tutor groups they don't know each other, but are a part of the group.

Teams on the other hand are groups with well established relationships between the members. Every member of the team is well integrated unless they are new to the team. The members of a team can work together very well, understand and respect each other. When disagreeing with each other they can find common ground and a solution. They have grown together through all kinds of experiences they had together. A football team for example has to work together smoothly to win games. They started out as a group of people and eventually became a team by going through losses, victories and by training together.

When defining the terms group and team it is not so much about finding the differences than it is pinpointing what sets apart a team from just any regular group. A group is simply any unit of people or things. This means that apart from the fact that the members have been selected or chosen to form said group, they do not need to have any other common characteristics, goals or properties, although of course they could. It's just not a necessary requirement. 
A selection of people who have chosen or have been chosen to take part in a survey for example can be considered a group. Though they are connected through the fact of having taken part in the survey, they all did so on their own accord and following their personal motivation. One person might have participated for monetary reward, another out of boredom, etc. The person in it for the money might not even be interested in the outcome or effects of the survey, whilst someone else might be looking to make an impact through his contribution.  
On the other hand, a team, being a special kind of group, has some additional qualities, these being its members effectively working together towards a shared objective. This means that members of a well-functioning teams must possess certain skills such as communication, awareness for others, open-mindedness and cooperation. Musicians in an orchestra for example form a team. All together they must coordinate their performance, watching out for the teammates around them and all of them playing their part in order to achieve their shared goal: harmony.

The difference between a group and a team is that a group is just a bunch of people who are related to each other but not in a close way, for example they are in the same school class. They got lessons together but are not closely connected. But a team is a group, which has the same goal, and for that goal they have to work together, otherwise they dont achieve it. A team is for example a football team, they have to play together with the same strategy to win the match.

A group consists of more than one person in which people have some kind of relationship with one another. They are formed e.g., through our participation in a specific tutorial. Through our participation, we share the characteristic that we participate in the same tutorial at the same time every week. People participating are part of the tutor GROUP of Max Mustermann.
However, a team is a group that works towards a specific goal and therefore organizes itself accordingly. For example, if 4 students from our aforementioned tutor group decide to work together on the project assigned to us you would get a team. Now we have a group of people who has the goal to deliver the best result and achieve a good grade together. This requires that they organize the work that needs to be done and maybe split it work accordingly. With everyone's individual engagement, they are all in total coming closer to their wished outcome.

One of the differences between groups and teams is that the team collaborates together to reach one common goal on the other side a group has more individualities and the purpose may differ from one member to another , for example a software development team has a goal to deliver a product but each member of a group of the same company have their own ambitions and work on it individually  . In addition a team members are more close to each other as confidence and trust are the main ingrediants to form a team wheras group members are not close and trust isn't one od the aspects present in a group .

A group of people can be together often ( during Lectures for example) but without them actually knowing each other, usually because there are too many people or no excuses/activity that make them interact.
A team is usually limited in terms of people being part of it, so that everyone in the team can know about one another, team members need to interact to be able to do their work. 
A group usually might have a common goal ( like passing a class ) that is pretty vague, whereas a team would have a more precise and concrete goal (developping a product for a certain use) to attain together, one team member can't possibly attain such a goal alone (unless...) unlike a member of a group.

The connection between the people of a team is very strong. The people in a team have a very similar mindset and work towars a commen goal together in a coordinated way and also achieve their goals together.  For example a football team (note that it's called a team ;) ultimatly has to work together to win. If every player just does what he wants to do, they will never Win. But if they put the players into different playing positions, they can all do their part and play in a way that helps the whole team to win.

In a group, the people dont have that strong bound that you get in a team. They work towards their goals alone. But they still are connected in some way. For example a school class is a group of students, because they dont need to work together to graduate. They mostly focus on themselves.

Groups are a amount of people who stay together without a same goal and teamwork, so that the conection of  people in a group do not really as closely as people in a team. For example a groupe of students or a groupe of women. On the other hand, as a team, all people in the team should work together for the mission of the team. They should comunicate and cooperate with each other , so that they can reach their goal efficently. For example a soccer team or a LOL team.

//Here I'm using my answer from ss2021

A group consists of people with some similar characteristics. They might set the same goal, but usually use different strategies to reach this goal. They also don't work on a goal together. Group participants are not connected that strong as the team participants. An example for a group could be students who study informatics.
They are doing the same thing, but use different strategies for learning and also have different goals (Some might want to have 1.0 note, for others is important to finish their bachelors in 3 years).

A team consists of people who have the same goal and the same strategy.  Each member of a team makes an effort to reach the common goal. The strategy is discussed by the members of a team and the tasks are shared.  A good example is a team in ERA-Praktikum.

Team members are more closely connected than Group members. For example, Team members need to be more in touch and communicate their progress. team members have a unified goal, such as developing a piece of software together.

A team has strong connections between members, with a shared, focused goal or target
A group has no such strong connections, and no shared or focused target.

For example, if a group and a team were attempting to win a football match, the group would be comprised of people who did not know each other, their strength's or intentions. They would have no strong bonds upon which to build communication, and as such, would be unable to share the common goal of winning the match because some may only be there for some exercise, other's for fun. There is no specific combined target shared within them, nor an easily designated leader or captain.

The team on the other hand knows each other well, have bonds such as friendship or shared experience upon which to build, and as such can communicate with each other the combined target of victory. They can then more easily achieve this by organising amongst themselves, with their dedicated team captain to delegate and organise their attempts.

A Group is a loose collection of multiple persons, not having a structured and connected workflow mostly working individually.

A Team on contrary has to work closely together to function and members know each others strengths and weaknesses better.

Groups consist of a number of people who are loosely connected. They do not share a common goal and do not work together to accomplish certain tasks. For example people riding together in the same bus are a group.

Teams consist of a number of people who share a common goal and who work together to accomplish this goal. 
For example a volleyball team training and playing together to win the championship is considered as a team.

Group ist eine Relation zwischen die Personen, die gleiche Ziel haben. Sie können nur ihr bestes Selbst sein und vielleicht auch verschiedene Ergebnisse bekommen. Aber ein Team bedeutet, dass  sie die gleichen Ergebnisse erzielen werden, im Guten oder Schlechten. Sie müssen miteinander kommunizieren, und manchmal sind Sie nicht die beste Selbst, um diese Team zum Besten zu werden.

Communication:
In a group, there might be people who only know each other very loosely, this can lead to communication problems. They might struggle to connect or criticize each other. In a good working team, everybody feels confident to state his opinion, can work with criticism and such a team has no problems communicating and coordinating the project they are working on.

Goal:
While a team focuses on achieving a certain goal, e.g. publishing a software update they work together to connect designers and coders to coordinate a successful launch. 
A group might not focus on getting the update ready but more on finishing their own work even if it is not the highest priority right now. Their goals don't align to create one project together, but more to e.g. get paid.

A group is a collection of people that stand in some sort of relation to each other. An example of a group would be patients in a waiting room at the dentist's. All of these people are related in the sense that they're all waiting for their appointment. A team on the other hand can also be considered a group. The key differences are for example a common goal. A group turns into a team as soon as the people work together to reach a shared goal. The employees at the dentist's office can be considered a team. They are a group of people who share the goal of treating their patients. They communicate and work together to ensure their patients are treated well and stay healthy.

A group consists of two or more people, with no direct connection and no common goals at the first sight.
The members mainly focus on themselves and their individual work and outcome more than on the general outcome and goal of the group. 
On the contrary all members of a Team have the same goal and everyone is working together and giving their best to reach it. A Team fails and succeeds together.

"Team" is used in a positive sense, representing a "well-functioning group", so that every Team is a group but not every group is a team.

Examples:
Team: A sports team, e.g handball (their goal is to win the game and they all need to work together to make it come true...no one can run through the field and the opponents defence and throw a goal without passing the ball to another player)
Group: A lecture, e.g in a German "Gymnasium" (a group of students is listening to the teacher but they are all studying and fulfilling their tasks on their own...in the end everyone is responsible for their own success or failure (in this case everyone is responsible for their own grade and graduation))

A Team is in contrast to a group well organized and everyone knows what the other ones are capable of and they can trust each other with tasks to do. In a group you only know what you are personally capable of and the goals between your group members can differ drastically. For example a Team can decide which tasks could be done best by which team member, because everyone has some strengths and weaknesses and in a group this would not be possible, because no one knows if the individual is really good at something, maybe you are even better at this than the other but in a group it is hard to compare yourself with your group members. In a Team you know your Teammates and can judge their skills. Because of this everyone more or less works on his own in a group, but in a Team the tasks are distributed between each member and they have to work together to achieve the right outcome for the project. All of this is just possible because in a Team you already have personal experience together for example you were together hiking sometimes and built up this personal relation.

Group 	: an assembly of people which interact with each other, but have their own purpose and act mostly independently. Each person aim for their success and their failure will not have an impact on others
- example : a group of students learning

Team	: a group of people who have a shared goal, working together with a common interest in mind. Unlike a regular group, a team would share the collective success and/or failure
- example : a team of software developer creating a useful website for a customer, a basketball team competing in the finals, etc.

As the word "group" define any number of people having any sort of relationship, such as a group of students in a lecture, a team, however, is considered as a group, but with more properties: it is a number of people cooperating with each other within the framework of a common activity to reach a common goal, for example a football team.

The chief difference between a group and a team is that members of the team share the same vision or goal, while those of a group do not. Often, having the shared goal or vision is the sole reason for why people of a team are interconnected at all. In a group, members are not required to work together and generally follow different goals, while in a team the common goal requires members to work together on tasks to achieve success.

If we look at the tutors and students in this course (disregarding the future scrum exercise formations), we could for example classify the tutors as a team and the students as a group. While the students are generally interested in passing the exam, which - for the most part can be done by studying alone (this is maybe more so the case for different university courses), the tutors and lecturers are sharing the common goal of providing a great learning experience for us. They thus work closely together to achieve this goal, like we could see with their nice video introduction. The students, of course, still share loose relationships in varying intensities as there are close friends among them, or people they have talked to a couple of times.

Another example: Research groups and co-authors in a project. People in a research group generally share common interests but are focused on specific questions that are only shared by smaller collections of individuals of the group. These could be co-authors, who closely work together to (in most cases) produce a paper with valuable content.

Groups are like a flock of pandas, they live close by to each other but don`t have a major impact on one other's lives nor work toward a common goal.
An ant colony on the other hand coordinates everything with one another and work together to reach their goals, e.g. build a home, defend from attackers or bring up a new generation.
Ein Team ist eine Gruppe von Leuten mit denen man gut saufen kann, nach dem man sich auf sie verlassen kann. Zudem, hat man ähnliche Ziele innerhalb eines Teams anders als in einer Gruppe.

A group consists out of a number of persons that are in a relationship to each other. While they eventually need to have some contact or interact with each other they are not aiming for the same goal. One example for a group could be car drivers. While they all want to use the streets and they need to follow some rules they ultimately have different goals (often destinations) to reach. Most of the time they don't know each other and also don't want to know each other. Another example for a group are people living in the same house. They usually don't have too much contact. Of course, everyone needs to attend to some norms and behave appropriately. However, everyone of them wants his individuals needs to meet and usually they do not match.

On the other hand, a team also consists out of multiple persons. However, they are in a strong relationship to each other. They aim for the same goal and thus need to work together in order to achieve it. One example for a team is definitely a sports team, e.g. a football team. 11 players want to win the game and thus need to train and play together. When people get into a dangerous situation, they also need to form a team. For instance, if people are hiking in the mountains and there is a storm which cuts any connection to the world, they need to ration their food, save electrical energy and so on.

The difference between a group and a team is, that in a team all of the members try to work together and create something together, while in a group people might work parallel to one another and don't even need to comunicate, because they just dont't iteract with one another.
One Example for a group are schoolclasses. Pupils often don't help one another and sometimes may not even have a common goal. Some might merely want to pass the class while others atually want to have good grades. On contrast there are group projects, which contrary to their name might atually lead to teams, because suddenly there is some sort of common goal for everyone that can only or more easily be achieved through collabaration. These two are the prerequisites for a team.
Another example for the difference between groups and teams is law enforcement. The police force more often than not acts like teams, although they now have a more abstract goal in mind than previously, e.g. upholding the law. Criminals on the other hand often work in groups, where everyone only does as little as possiple and more importantly, takes as little risk as possible. These work beliefs can quite often be the downfall for these criminal groups.

Wenn mehrere Personen gebeten werden an einem Projekt zu arbeiten, bezeichnet man diese Menge an Personen zunächst als Gruppe. Hierbei sind die Personen noch nicht aneinander gewöhnt, nicht ausreichend eingearbeitet und die Arbeitsweise ist noch nicht perfektioniert. In einer Gruppe kommt es leichter und schneller zu Konflikten und die Problemlösung nimmt mehr Zeit in Anspruch. Von einer Gruppe würde man zum Beispiel sprechen, wenn 4 einander nahezu unbekannte Personen aus einem Jahrgang einer Schule im Deutschkurs gemeinsam in 10 Minuten eine Kurzpräsentation zur aktuellen Lektüre gestalten sollen.

In einem Team dagegen herrscht bereits starker Zusammenhalt und die Mitglieder vertrauen einander. Die Kommunikation ist ausgereift, Probleme können einfach angesprochen und gelöst werden, ohne dass es zu größeren Konflikten kommt. Das Team hat bereits verschiedene Phasen durchlaufen und befindet sich dadurch im optimalen Zustand um gemeinsam zu arbeiten. Jeder kennt seine Rolle im Team und lässt sich von den anderen Mitgliedern ergänzen. Von einem Team könnte man zum Beispiel sprechen, wenn eine Gruppe von 5 guten Freunden bereits seit einigen Wochen an einem eigenen Kurzfilm arbeitet, zwei als Schauspieler vor der Kamera, einer als Kameramann und einer als Tonmann, der fünfte als Regisseur.

In group, there is common interest but in team there is core purpose. Group members generally work individually and has little interaction with other members but in the team every member interact with each other to succeed core purpose.

Groups are a bunch of people who don't really know each other and work predominantely on their own. There is no real goal which requires all of them to work together. Groups of people do not have to have the same goal as everyone else. For example students are a group of people but don't work as a team, they rather work for themselves to pass the exams.

Teams however are a group of people who work together as a solid unit. For example in Software Development, a team consists of people who specialise in different aspects to complement each other and have the same goal to work for.

The difference between a group and a team is that groups are just loose collections of people that each follow their own goals through their own means. Meanwhile, a team is a kind of group where all members are closely working together towards a common goal.

Example 1:
A football team is a team and not just a "group" because all players need to coordinate their playstyle in order to win against the competing team. If one player fails, all players will fail.

Example 2:
An example for a "loose group" would be a friend group. While all members are friends with each other, their actions like their private life or academic goals or work goals do not affect other members in the group. This is because each member follows their own goals and has an individual and unique strategy to accomplish those goals.

A group of people usually have a loose relationsship to one another, or at least one thing in common which qualifies them as a group. For example you can define all the people who take the course "Introduction to Software engineering" as one big group. The participants are have a loose connection to one another as they all watch the same lectures and learn the same contents. However everyone works for the most part alone and any individual doesn't really care whether another person they don't even know passes the course or not. Even though one might argue that we have the same goal, in a sense that we all want to pass the course, we are not collaborating in order to achieve said goal thus not really reinforcing any connection we might have.

A Team on the other hand is also a group of people that in contrast to the group presented above collaborates in order to achieve a common goal. Any sports team works as an example, take a football team. The common goal might be to win the championship, however this can not be achieved by any individual player alone thus forcing them to effectively collaborate. They need to work together in order to achieve the goal. This requires them to coordinate and plan their activities so everybody can do what they are best at.For example one person might only play defense while another only plays offense. Now as a team they make sensible decisions as to who might fill what role best This distinguishes a group from a team. Often times this results in friendships also off the field. As you have to have synergy in order to work together as a team, you have to know each other well in order to know what your teammates might do or not to.  In general strong interpersonal connections help with this, spending more time together training you get to know the style of different people or how they operate. All of the behaviour described above is typical for teams and helps with their major goal of effective collaboration. In groups you often times do not have these things and if you do you have them only with parts of a group maybe a few people but not with a majority.

Groups are a collection of individuals who might know each other. These individuals are more loosely connected and don’t have team cohesion.

Teams on the other hand have what is called “team cohesion”. They have good communication, a deep understanding of what it is they are doing, and comprehensive knowledge of their individual roles/tasks.

For example, a group of individuals who don’t know each other will have trouble communicating to develop a project. A team will know how they work, and can efficiently and coherently develop a program.

A group of individuals who want to develop a website for example will have to decide on the language to use. They might debate about using html or webassembly or js. A team would already have a preferred language

Groups consist of people who are independent from each other and act accordingly, while teams consist of people who work together on the same task with the same goal in mind.
E.g. a group of friends doesn't exist to work on a certain task and therefore everyone has individual interests and ambitions, unlike a football team, in which every player works together to reach the same goal, and therefore shares their work with everyone else to reach the best possible outcome.

A team are people working together while sharing the same goals . The team members talk to each other about their progress so they are always connected and have to adjust their work to the other participants.
Whereas in a group the people are not really connected and they work mainly on their own. 

For example a soccer team is a team. The player have to pay attention to the others movements. Moreover they have to fully trust each other and they need to know each others skills. Here you can see that they clearly work together and have the same goal (win the game).

An example for a group is a schoolclass. There are many pupils focusing on their own success because everyone have to write a own exam. Every parpicipant have to learn by himself to pass the class.

Team members are linked together with each other to archive a common goal. 
A group can be built up with different people or different teams, but each team or people is only responsible for their own work.

For example, in EIST we need to build up different teams to work on a project and the whole EIST students are a group. EIST group might have a common goal that is to pass the exam, but every student doesn't have so much relation with each other.

Another example is departments in a company. For example, a company has research deparment and editoral department. This two department are a group of workers, they work for the whole company, and the worker in the same department might be a team(but not always). They have a leader, and they have a same goal.

A group is a gathering of people that do not really have a strong connection to each other and more or less coordinate their actions but don't really work together or follow a common goal,  rather each participant works for himself (herself)/on his (her) own and follows his (her) individual goals.
This often happens if people who don't really know each other are thrown together to work on a problem (e.g. presentations in school where the group members are randomly picked).

A good example fora team is a sports team, especially one which managed to turnaround the score after falling behind, this is because a sports team is also a gathering of people but with strong connections to each other team mate and the willing to work together and coordinate the steps in order to achive the best possible results for the team as fast as possible. They work on a common goal.

While in a group it is not necessary to work together and everyone can work by himself, a team requires closely working together ("teamwork"). For example: A group of Designers working in the same Company are all connected to each other, they don't rely on each other though because they most likely work on different projects that have no connection. 
A second example:
A group of friends who go swimming casually form a group of swimmers; they have no goal other than just swimming while a professional team of swimmers usually trains and cooperates in competitions, striving for the win.

A group is a certain number of people loosly connected by a certain common thing. 
A team is a certain number of people working together towards the same goal.
In a group everybody has their on goals and works for themself. In a team you have the same goals, work together more closely and share the responsibility

When we talk about a group, the people in question do not have to be related to each other in regards to having a common goal and neither do they need to work together. On the other hand, it is expected from a team's members to actively involve in the teamwork, support each other etc. The passengers of a random train could be described as a group of people but they are not a team. A team could be some friends of the birthday kid, who are together, trying to prepare the cake at the kitchen before the kid arrives home as well as a group of engineers trying to solve a problem together.

The mutuality of a group and a team is that it consist of a certain number of people. The big difference although is that the participants of a group don't have a certain goal which they want to achieve. They do not really care for other people (in a way to achieve a mutual goal) and are actually more for their own. A team on the other hand has a common goal which should be reached. To work together is crucial to achieve this goal effectively. 
Examples for this are:
Group: a school class - here the people just want to achieve their own goal (for example getting a good grade) and they don't have a common goal which they want to reach. It is not a problem when the people among themselves are not really connected.  
Team: a football team - here is it the common target to win a match, it can only be reached well when the team is working together. In order to fulfil that the members of the team should be really strong connected.

Team:
-arbeitet zusammen
-haben ein gemeinsames Ziel
-stark miteinander verbunden

Gruppe:
-keine Zusammenarbeit
-kein gemeinsames Ziel
-loose miteinander verbunden


In einem Wettbewerb sind die Teilnehmer zwar eine Gruppe (der Wettbewerb verbindet sie), aber sie arbeiten nicht zusammen, sondern jeder für sich.

Ein Entwicklerteam hingegen arbeitet zusammen auf den Erfolg des Teams hin.

The word Group is a very collective word. Example- Group of people with black hair or a group of people waiting outside in the Queue,
 but whereas team is a formal word ,which points out a group of people with same Target. Team work together ,playing their individual role with coordination so that the target of the Team is achieved. 
Example- Football Team ,every player has different role but same objective(that is to win).They perform their individual Roles in Coordination with each other to achieve their common Objective, which is to win the match.
In Group everyone holds his/her own responsibility, but in team everyone is responsible for each other.

The members in a group may not necessarily be aligned in their personal or professional Objectives whereas for a Team this kind of Alignment or Cohesion is a prerequisite. (For Example- Designers working in an Organisation might be considered a group by virtue of their professional background. However the kind of coordination that exist within a Design Team won't necessarily exist between two designers based solely on their background. )

In a group, members cannot necessarily expect assistance from other members. Whereas in a team, each member's responsibilities are predefined. Every member complements the other members in terms of their strengths. For example, in a squad (team) of soldiers, every soldier has a predetermined and precise role, be it the squad leader, the radio operator, or the rifleman. However, a group of soldiers put together on an ad hoc basis will not complement each other's skills the same way.

Group is a loosely connected union of people working on solving a problem in a individualistic way. There is no synergy between members. 

Team is a tightly-knit group of cooperating and connected of people, with commonly set goals.

One difference would be that groups do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose while a team does in fact focus on that specific outcome and they require coordination of tasks and activities. When you're in a team working on an app for example, you have to coordinate everyones tasks and responsibilities and obviously you want the outcome to be the app that you've been working on. While a group of friends for example doesnt have a specific purpose or outcome planned.
Another difference would be that the participants in a group are connected differently than the participants in a team. In a group, they are loosely connected. They might have same interests for example or another reason for why they have some relationship to one another, while in a team participants are strongly connected as they have to share common goals and have to communicate a lot to have a good outcome of their shared goal.
Also a difference is that in a group every individual works on his own while in a team members need to work together. As I've already mentioned, in a team working on an app, you have to communicate a lot with your teammates since you depend on their progress just the way they depend on your progress. While in a group, you don't work together a lot. Everyone has their own goals and there is no responsibility for the other group members to help you achieve your specific goal, which could be anything, for example building a shelf.

A group is a loose collection of people without a common goal or the intrinsic motivation to work together and so mostly don't work together, but fully independent. A simple example for a group of people are our tutor groups at the beginning of the semester. Even though we all do pretty much the same work we don't really collaborate or care all too much about the performance of the other. And there is just little of communication between the students:
On the other hand a team consists of multiple people sharing a common goal and are (in the best case) united by the motivation to achieve this goal. The most common example for a team is good functioning  a soccer team in which every player wants to support the other to score a goal / win a game / win a championship.

Team: people in a group, doing the same activity and having the same goal. They are stronger connected and teamwork plays an very important factor. An example would be a team of engineers trying to implement a program for the given requests of a client.


Group: Some people have some kind of relationship between each other, e.g a circle of friends just sitting together with no real purpose and a specific goal.

People in a GROUP are in some form of relationship, however they don't pursue the same goal and work individually.
One example I can think of is taxi drivers, they all share the same job and drive taxis, but all of them work for themselves to earn money for them/their families. There is no cooperation between the taxi drivers, everyone "does their own thing".

A TEAM consists of members who can trust each other and work together towards the same goal.
The best example would be a sports team, that plays the game together with one, unified objective: to win the game, tournament, etc.

Difference between group and team

Group: a number of people that have some relationship to one another
• Participants are loosely connected
• Do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose
• Every individual works on his own
For example, all the people that attending a concert (attending this concert is the relationship among them) of Taylor Swift form a group. These people mostly strangers and do not know each other (some may know each other but not all) so they are loosely connected. And they do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose because they might have different favorite songs: Some want listen "Lover" but some other might wanna listen "Welcome to New York". Meanwhile, every individual works on his own in this concert. They do not buy tickets, come or leave together. Some might sing along all the time while some might leave quite early.

Team: any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work
• Participants are strongly connected
• Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities
• Members need to work together
Members of a new upcoming software or game forms a team. Their common goal is to finish the software or game successfully and upload it into the market. They are strongly connected: they get together for the same aim and have complementary capabilities such as programming, marketing, finance, art design and so on, for their different tasks. They work together with separated task of the final goal and coordinate occasionally, such as finance apartment (to deal with the expense through the process and also the financial coordination of different parts of tasks). They also usually work together for several months or even years to finish a project for a gorgeous game or software.

In einer Gruppe haben mehrere Personen eine Art von Beziehung zueinander. 
Ein Team besteht aus Menschen, die an einer gemeinsamen Aktivität mit einem gemeinsamen Ziel beteiligt sind. Ein Team ist zudem stärker vernetzt, benötigt größere Teamarbeit und Koordination.

Beispiel für Gruppe:
Ein Beispiel für eine Gruppe sind Jugendgruppen, die aus gleichaltrigen besteht. 

Beispiel für Team:
Auf der Arbeit können sich Teams bilden die gemeinsam an einem Problem arbeiten und die selben Ziele dabei haben (vgl. Scrum).

(Def)A group consists of individuals with one common feature. Eg. Studying informatics. However, (Def) team is a subgroup consisting individuals, who relies on one another. Eg. Chess team, in a tournament where the scores of every player add up to the team score.
(1)Informatics students are not a team, as they are only part of a much smaller circle within the group, but in a team the relationship between the individuals is tighter, thus everyone knows one another.
(2)In a group there is usually a single objective. For instance passing the EIST exam, whereas in a team people have more than one objectives: Doing their task and help other team members, as they are gathered around a common goal.
(3)A group can also benefit from a common goal, for example a group of climate activists, but group members are not responsible from other group members, whereas team members usually have a social hierarchy, which allows them to take care of other peoples problems and wishes on the way and where supervisors (team leader) are held accountable for their subordinates actions.

Groups are comprised of people that have a mutual relationship, however, they don't rely on each other to achieve their overall personal goals.
Teams share a mutual vision and rely on every member to work together in order to achieve a collective goal, members have therefore a interdependent relationship.

Group exercises with tutors have the goal of providing knowledge for each student to apply their skills on individual homework. Whereas team exercises focus on the collective performance of the members to achieve a overall result for the members of the team. 

In competitive sports based on teams, every member is mutually accountable for the victory of the whole team. However, in a marathon an athlete only wins based on his own performance, regardless of what happens with his group.

Sowohl eine Gruppe als auch eine Team sind ein Kollektiv. Der Unterschied liegt in der Beziehung in der die Mitglieder zueinander stehen. In einer Gruppe sind die Mitglieder nur oberflächlich in Verbindung und jeder Arbeitet für sich. In einem Team hingegen haben alle Mitglieder ein gemeinsames Ziel, auf welches sie in konstruktivem Zusammenspiel hinarbeiten.
Beispiel für eine Gruppe:Reisegruppe
Beispiel für ein Team:	Besatzung eines Schiffes

A group is simply a number of people that are loosley connected not working towards a common goal. The entire 2200 students of EIST are a group, not a team. The group of people holding Tesla shares are a group of people.

A team is a number of people who work towards a common goal that are strongly connected. Our development team would be a team. A consulting team works together to solve a clients' problem and therefore is a team.

Group:
A group can be perceived as a collection of people sharing some relation between each other. Normally in groups, a common objective is noticeably absent, as the people are more into feeding their own personal interests and towards their own betterment, i.e., there isn’t a strong connection between the people.

Team:
On the other hand, a team is a collection (group) of people who share similar interests, when doing the same activity, and work together towards achieving the common goal. Here, the people are strongly connected and coordinate, as well as, cooperate with each other.

Examples:
1. Executive Chefs, other cooks, waiters and waitresses in a restaurant trying to manage all the hungry guests: if they work as a group, then there’d be significant delay in serving the customers and the overall experience of the restaurant wouldn’t be good. Whereas, if they work as a team, everything is well coordinated, and not the chefs/cooks are the main focus, rather the hungry customers (common goal).

2. The game of Cricket: although at the end of the match only one player is declared as the “Man of the Match” or “The Best Player”, all the members of the team must play strategically in order to make the team win as a whole. If they act like a group, and only focus on their individual interests, then the team would never win, resulting in a heavy compromise. Hence, when all the players play as a true team, they care for the victory of the entire team first, then their own respective performances.

Ein Team ist eine Gruppe von mindestens zwei Personen, die ein gemeinsames Ziel verfolgen. Um dieses Ziel zu erreichen arbeiten und koordinieren sich zusammen. 

Eine Gruppe ist eine vaage Beziehung zwischen Personen ohne spezifische oder gemeinsame Ziele. Alle Personen dieser Gruppe arbeiten alleine, um ihre individuellen Probleme zu lösen.

Ein Fußball Team beispielsweise muss zusammen arbeiten, um das gegen das gegnerische Team zu gewinnen. Durch gemeinsame Koordinierung, Strategie, Teamplay und vertrauen zeigt sich ein gutes Team und das Team, dass diese Eigenschaften besser durchsetzen kann gewinnt die Oberhand bei einem Spiel.

Eine religiöse Gruppe auf der anderen Hand hat muss nicht unbedingt zusammen arbeiten, da sie kein bestimmtes Ziel verfolgen, das ein Ende haben könnte. Eventuell treffen sich diese Personen einmal oder mehr, aber abgesehen davon haben sie keine stärkere Verbindung. Ähnlich zu einem Team könnten sie ein Gemeinschaftsgefühl haben, dennoch zeigt sich bei eine Gruppe keine starke Zusammenarbeit für ein bestimmtes Ziel.

A group is a number of people who are related to each other in some way, but a team is a group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal.
In a group:											In a team:
-Participants are closely associated with each other			-Participants are loosely connected to each other
-Each individual works on his/her own goal					-Members must work together
-etc.													-etc.

For example an athletic team works together to win, but a work group does each of their individual work.
A work group doesn't need to be touch all the time but a team shares a common goal therefore they need to be fully aware what the other members of the team do.

Groups are loosely connected people not necessarily sharing a vision and goal. Individuals in a group are often working alone.

Teams are strongly connected people who share a vision and a potentially a goal. Individuals share the workload and work together.


Some people have booked a guided trip in the arctic, they will be out for a week. The people are from different families and group of friends. Their guide instruct them to build a camp together every evening. 
The Teams(the smaller familiar constellations) will put up their part of the camp, and together the group as succeeded in making a camp, but the group as a whole has not worked as a team.

Students attend the software engineering course, they all study and the course is compulsory. They are instructed to solve different tasks during the lecture, some students talk together and discuss the answers, most do not. The students performs as a group, albeit having some smaller teams included  in the group, all the way down to single individuals.

A group is just a number of people that is somewhat related. A team, however, shares the same vision or goal and work together to achieve it. 

An example of a group is all freshmen at TUM, while an example of a team will be members working together on a Team Project for EIST.

An example of a group is all members of the same Crossfit gym. While an example of a team would be members of a team that are working in that gym together to win the Crossfit Games under Teams division.

Groups:
a number of people that are connected via one/few common connections, but are each loosely connected to each other and work individually. The only thing that connects these people is/are these specific connections.

Teams:
a number of people that are not only (strongly) connected via common connections, but are also focused on specific outcomes/activities and coordination between each other. Teams, unlike Groups, work together to achieve their goals and work on their communication to do so.

A group is a accumulation of people who are loosely connected, but do not work together on a shared end result. There is no trust needed between the group members as they exist completely independently from each other and each perform on their own.
For example all the people on one bus form a group, connected by the fact that they are all on the same bus but not otherwise. A group is also formed by students who all visit the same lecture.
They neither share a common goal like a team, nor have to coordinate their work in any way with each other or a strongly connected. 

A team on the other hand is a group of people working on a common end result together. A certain level of trust between each other is required, this is aiding their strong connection as well as coordination of tasks.
Examples for teams are military squads, as safety and life of the team members depend on each other, as well as surgical teams who need to be well coorinated and accustomed to each other to perform their surgeries well. 
Strong connection,  coordinated, interconnected work and a shared goal are necessary for a team but not a group.

People in a group don‘t necessary have the same goals. However a team focus on a specific outcome. 
In some cases a group of athletes don‘t have the same goal. A team of athletes work for the same purpose. 
In groups it is usual that everyone works on his own. In a team all members work together.
In tutor groups all participants work at their own homework. In a team exercise all members work together on one project.

A group is made up of several people who may know each other, they are geographically in the same place but not necessarily for the same reason. They don't share the same goal, which makes them loosely connected. A group is a number of people who work individually on their own.
Example: A village is formed by a group of people, each leading a daily life independent of the others.

A team, on the other hand, is made up of several people who have the same goal in a specific area. They are strongly linked, which makes them work as if they were one. A team focuses on the same end result and to achieve this, all members must work together in coordinating their tasks and activities.
Example: Students working on a project are called a team because they work together to achieve their goal of getting a good grade.

A group consists of people who aim to reach personal goal. They behave independent.
Team is composed of numbers who work for a common goal. They need to interact  closely together and cooperate with each other.

Group is a collection of people which have a loosely connected relationship with one another who works for their own goal without targeting a specific goal.
	eg: A class is a group itself which is consisted of 100 students who haven't strong bonds among them. They work by themselves for their own sake and own goals.

Team is a collection of people who work in the same activity together to achieve a common goal. They are closely bonded.
	eg: When the Lecturer of the above mentioned class told the students to work on a project where each team must have 10 students, then these 100 students get divided themselves into 10 teams and work closely in the same project to make it successful. The above group which doesn't have a common goal, is now working strongly together to achieve their goal which makes a team.

A team is a number of individuals that are united for a common purpose. What differs a team from a group is that the people in the group do not have a common goal to work towards. A bunch of builders working together to build a hotel is a good example of a team. Their common goal is to build a house and in order to do that they must focus on coordinating their efforts, which requires good planning, good communication skills and a strong connection between the builders.
On the other hand, the guests who stay at that hotel later, can be described as a group. Every guest staying there have its own motivation or goal. They might meet each other around the hotel, or when dining, but there isn't a strong connection between them.
Calling them a group is solely based on the fact that they're staying at the same hotel. Nothing more.

Groups are just a bunch of people without any strong connection between each other and mostly everyone works on their own, without too much coordination. The  Teams are on the other hand strongly connected people, who strive to complete a certain task using the powers of every team member. And to use every team member efficiently, there much be some sort of coordination.

The difference between a group and a team may be seen quite easily when comparing the members of a tutorial group with those of an EIST team. The members of a tutorial group may have a relationship (via the same group and tutor), but the connection is only loose and one is primarily working for oneself. An EIST team, on the other hand, is graded as a team and thus has an interest in investing  efforts in order to obtain a good grade. Especially in teams consisting of friends with the same attitude towards work and grades, collaboration turns out fruitful.
Another example might be a chess club; when playing as a team, all members have to work hard to enable the team to win a competition. If the members of the team then played in an individual championship, they would still have a relationship to each others due to being in the same chess club, but their goals would not necessarily align.

A group is a loosely coupled amount of people who coordinate their efforts to complete a certain task. The success or failure affects the individual, which is why the members are independent and responsible for themselves.
For example, you are in a "large" group of roughly 2200 students studying penguins at TUM. While most of them want to pass the common task i.e., the test, many will fail. But that doesn't affect those who succeeded.

A team however consists of more closely connected people who work together to accomplish a goal. Unlike in a group, you can’t reach the goal alone. Either everyone succeeds or fails. The members are interdependent. You need the other members to do their part and counter wise. 
In professional Football, you can’t hope to win a match if you let every member play how they like. You need to use strategy and distribute the task to those, who specialize in it. There is the goalkeeper and the defenders, who're responsible to defend the goal, while other team members can strike forward to achieve a goal. In the end the Team will succeed or fail together.

While group members try to achieve their own targets, mebers of a team share them and therefore are connected tighter in their decision making, which often must be accepted by everyone. This of course leads to the point responsibility. Whereas group participants are responsible for themselves, team individuals need to care for the others additionally. That is why in a team everybody is successful or not. Group members may differ speaking of success.
A pupil, for instance, may be grated better in an exam because she learned more than others without caring for their success. 
On the other side a participant in a startup project following scrum needs to adapt to the rest and listen to them. In exchange they need to respect his/her thought. That is because the teams aim is to achieve their target in a hopefully efficient way. Working on your own would be very inefficient and most likely lead to no success for everyone. Furthermore the atmosphere in the team can influence their efficiency.

A group is simply a band of people with vaguely common interests, while a team is built to work together to solve one problem. A team is more efficient and are more strongly connected.

A group and a team can be differentiated as follows:
The first difference between a team and a group is the connection between the members. In a group the members are rather unsteadily connected while the participants of a team feel a strong connection.
The second difference is the purpose of the the foundation of the organisation. A team alsways has a goal and common tasks. On the other hand a group has no purpose of working together.
The third difference is the kind of interaction between the members: while everyone works individually in a group, a team profits from the interaction and the collaboration of its members.

To mark the differences I give two expamples:
A group of people attends a festival. They are not connected personally to each other, they sometimes even do not know each other before the event starts. They have no common goal, but only share their interests in the festival, they are all attending. Last but not least everyone plans their attendance on their own. This definition has all characteristics of a group.
On the other hand we have the following example of a team: selected co-workers of a company form a team in order to sucessfully conduct a project (the implementation of a new IT system) together. They are strongly connected by their goal (the new IT system) and their todos. They work in the same company. The project lead coordinates the team members and controls if all tasks are fulfilled, especially the depending ones. Obviously, exactly these tasks are the ones, on which team members have to work together to get the best possible outcome.

A Team is a group of people who share a common goal while a Group is a collection of people/ multitude who are allocated in the same place.

For example:
Students enrolled at the EIST course are a group because they are a collection of people who are allocated at the same place because of interests or circumstances while an EIST-teamwork (working on a homework)  is  still a group of persons who are in the same place because of interests or circumstances but they follow the same goal, to work and perform specific processes together for the benefit of all the team members.

In a company, there are different departments that follow a hierarchical structure, each of these departments perform a specific task. People at the IT department are a group of persons who share professional interests together, because they work together at the same place while software development engineers are still working on IT but they are a team because they work together, are specialised in software development and follow the same goal in benefit of all the team members and environment (IT department).

In a group, members only have a weak connection, while the connection in a team has to be strong. This strong connection helps the team to work together towards a specific outcome with, while tasks and activities are distributed, whereas in a group the weak connection leads to every individual working on their own without a specific common goal. 

For example a team can be often found in sports where the common goal is usually to win games or score as many points as possible, to achieve said goal the whole team has to work together, because an individual can not compete with the opposing team, if the opposing team functions better as a team.
 
On the other hand a class in high school can be seen as a group, especially if the different students have very different goals and their only connection is that they share a classroom. Everyone studies/ learns as much as they want and they think is necessary and everyone has to write their exam on their own. Within a class there can be teams, for example "study groups" can be seen as a kind of team, since they often agree on a grade they want to reach or how much they want to improve from the last exam and work together to reach that goal.

Group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another often through coomen interests.
They are often only loosly connected and individuals work on their own.
Also, there is no focus on a common purpose or specific outcome.

In a team, people are conntected as a "collection" of peiple that shares a common goal and they are involved in the same activity. The members of a team are strngly connected and they need to work together.
Also, a team needs to focus on a specific outcome which thus requires the coordination of tasks and activities.

EXAMPLES:
A group and a team have both the same goal (e.g. successfully finishing a task).
The main difference is that a  team works together and support each other.
A group may also give support but its more focused on yourself and getting your exercises done. 

In a group people don't trust each other that much and thus there is more suspicion and almost no criticism is allowed (which iis bad because you are not getting the best possible result)

While teams and groups could be seen as similar things at first, there are a few distinct differences between the two. While both terms describe a collection of people, the way these people interacte, their goals and the interpersonal relationships are barely comparable. In groups, the people who are part of it are connected by some common denominator, but they do not necessarily interact much. In teams, on the other hand, there is a common goal shared by all members. To reach said goal, interaction and organisation within the team are required. One practical example to show the differences can be found within hospitals. The doctors from different fields could certainly be seen as a group, as they are connected by their occupation, as well as the fact that they all work for the same hospital. Besides that, though, the doctors do not work together or collaborate, as they are all from different fields. Doctors from the same department and doctors and their assistants on the other hand are a team, as they share their common goal of helping their patients, and their common patients at that. Moreover, they have to collaborate, interact and organize within their team to be able to reach their goal of helping their patients. A more common example could be that of a sport team, who all have to work together to be succesfull, and are therefore a team. A different example for the people of a group could be the people visiting that sports team at the game, as they are all fans of that team but do not need to collaborate.

A group can be defined as a collection of people that work together in a coordinated type of way, each having their own goal, while a team is a group of people that share a common goal that they strive to achieve together. A team acts as one towards their objective, meaning that failure for the team also means failure for each individual team member, which does not have to be the case for groups, where each group member can still celebrate their own successes for the task. Moreover, the the outcome of a team project can be attributed to a the whole team while groups hold individual group members accountable for the success/failure of their project.
