As an example, the lecture hall can be seen as a group of students, every single student working to complement each other's studies, but nevertheless having different goals they want to attain for that course.
The teams formed for the EIST Project can be cosiderend teams because they not only consist of students that work together in a coordinated way (for example with SCRUM) but also have a common standard they want their software project to reach.
A second example would be a cruise ship. Vacationers on the cruise ships form a group, they are all in a sense working together to enjoy their time. When the ships starts sinking, the group becomes a team as they now all share the common goal of getting off the ship as quickly as possible.

Es gibt da nicht wirklich Unterschiede, da Teams eine Art von Gruppen sind. Was Teams abhebt, ist das sie Gruppen sind, die zusammen auf ein Ziel hinarbeiten. Wenn dieses Ziel erreicht ist oder abgebrochen wird, löst sich das Team meist auf. Um das Ziel zu erreichen, müssen die Mitglieder meist zusammenarbeiten.

A group is an amount of people more than one, that does not necessarily have a common goal. 
A team is also an amount of people more than one, but always has to have a common final goal. 
A group does not necessarily have to be in a good relationship to one another. 
A team have to be good with one another, to achieve all the common goals.

In a group, people mostly feel unattached to their colleagues on a personal as well as professional level, so they mainly rely on their individual skills. In a team, they work organized together and also show interest in each other's progress. An example in software development is that in a group, people barely communicate, so when they make changes to a repository they would not write a commit message, because they might think it is unnecessary, and they do not need to document it properly, because they think their code is completely correct. Because nobody cares about each other's work there are no code reviews, a bug remains undetected and the time it was introduced into the code cannot be traced back because of missing commit messages. Fixing it consequentially requires more time and effort than it normally should. In a team, people would write commit messages to explain their changes to their colleagues and would quickly review other people's code before merging it, to assure its correctness. 
Furthermore, in a team, people work towards a common previously declared goal, by utilizing each one's individual strengths and knowledge, for example, it could be that a test engineer can easily write assertions for someone else, who is writing a critical section of a program that requires multithreading and is unsure how to verify parallelized code. While he would otherwise need to read a lot about the topic himself and waste a lot of time, which he could use more productively, in a team he could ask a test engineer for help, who might be an expert in this field. In a group, he might not trust the competence of the test engineer enough or is too proud to ask him for help, so that he can slow down the entire development process. In a team, people are not too shy to ask for help and maybe offer help to their colleagues, if they know their colleagues well enough, to develop a feeling for when they might be stuck with a task.

The differences between groups and teams is the way the people interact with each other.
In a group it is no problem when a certain person is absent and the other people can continue their work.
A common example for such a group is a call-centre where everybody is just focusing on their own work and doesn't interact with other.
In a team everybody's work depends on another person and can't be completed without communication.
Every person has a specific task that is necessary for completing the main goal of the team.
An example for this scenario can be a formula 1 team. The driver of the car can't complete the race without managers in the background and people in the pit stop. In addition they all share the same goal.

A group is a collection of people who coordinate their work.
A team is a group of people united by a common goal.
So in the team people are  more united and friendly with each other, they have the same goal and try to communicate and cooperate to achieve this goal.

A group is a collection of individuals with something in common, whereas a team is a group of individuals, that are working together to achieve a goal.
Examples :
1. A group of students in a lecture hall.
    A team of students working on a project.
2. A group of people that practice a sport together.
     A team of players of a sport working together to win against another team.

A group describes a few people, which usually have something in common. For example, the people of a school class can be described as a group. Group members don't have to rely on each other and they have their own goals.
While the people in a group don't have to cooperate, the members of a team are dependant on their teammates. The team members have to help each other and work together to reach their goals as a team. The teammates are much closer to each other because they have to work together.

As already mentioned, the IT students can be described as a group, studying the same subject in common.
They got the same tasks, but they are supposed to work on their own. These people don't have to rely on other people and they're not dependant on other students. 
In subjects like GRA, EIST etc., the students form a team, so a team member helping their mates and relies on them. They have to solve the exercises together and while working together, the members grow as a team.
They learn how adapt themselves to work better with their teammates.

In a video game, you can see the difference between single player games and multiplayer games, where you have multiple teams.
In a single player game, you play the game on your own and you're not dependant on other people.
In a multiplayer game, especially in team games, you have to work together, so you can help each other to survive, for example healing them or giving them a boost. You have to work tactically to beat a boss or destroy something as a team. There are problems you can't solve alone and you have to rely on your mates.

The members of groups and teams have different kind of reliance one another. While group members are loosely connected, the team members are strongly connected. 
White team members serve the same purpose the team members do not focus on a common purpose.

In groups you usually don't have a common goal/vision, you and your group members work on.
For example: you and your group members don't have a common goal like an app, indeed you may be gathered for a lecture, but theres no common goal.
In teams you have a common goal/vision, you and your team members work on. For example: if you and your teammates want to programm an app.

A group is a number of people that have some common features. They don't have a common goal, don't have to work together and could be loosly connected. A team is a group of people involved in the same action. They have  a common goal or purpose, are in connection with each other and must work together.
For example, a group of people walking in a park. They don't have to know each other, they can do it alone and can have different goals.
Otherwise, a group of workers building a house has a common goal (a built house) and they can't do it without connecting with each other and working together.

While in a team, there is trust in the other members and everybody does know what to do and what the others do, a group is more unorganized and the members cant trust eachother yet. In a team, the goal also is crystal clear,in a group the people could have other expectations between each other.

A myriad of people get muddled up with the correct usage of the terms "group" and "team". These two terms seem to be similar but one should be aware of the clear difference between both. 
Describing the definition of both words I would like emphasize the importance of distinguishing the difference. 
A "group" can be defined as a number of people that have a loosely connected relationship with each other. Every group member has its own interests and separate achievements. 
Contrary to a "group", a "team" has its values on achieving a specific goal based on a common purpose and interests. This leads to a stronger connection between members of the team. To sustain a team it requires coordination of tasks and activities. 
Regarding these two definitions, the two terms can be clearly distinguished by the working behaviour. Unlike to the individual working behaviour of a group, members of a team need to work together.

In a group, every member works on its own.
In a team, all members work together to achieve something.

For example, in a soccer match, all team members work together to get a goal.
All team members are strongly connected here.

In a group, every member works on its own task alone.
That is why in a group, all team members are not that strongly connected.

Another example:
When you have to so several tasks, in a group every member would do one task by its own.
In a team, all members would do one task together, and then the next task.

Generally you can say that in a group of people the members have some relationship to one another, but work on their own.
Whereas in a team, all members work on the same activity to achieve their goal.

A team is a subset of a "group" of people. To be considered a group, people are only required to have one or a few common traits. 
A team additionally requires a shared task or goal and the cooperation of the members to find a solution to the problem and implement it!

An easy-to-understand example to illustrate the difference between a team and a group would be an ethnicity! An ethnicity means "an ethnic quality or affiliation resulting from racial or cultural ties"* and there are plenty of ethnic groups, such as the "English" or the "Germans" which by no means are teams, as they have no shared task or goal.

Great examples for a team include work teams & sports teams. In fact, even though it has "group" in its name - a "music group" or commonly - band can also be considered a team. They work together on a song which requires great efforts in communication & collaborative training!

* ethnicity. (n.d.) WordNet 3.0, Farlex clipart collection. (2003-2008). Retrieved April 26 2022 from https://www.thefreedictionary.com/ethnicity

Groups consist of in some way correlated people, for example a group of students working towards graduation. Teams consist of people that are working towards the same goal, dependant on one another, an example being a sports team, where individual failure means collective failure.

A team tries to achieve the same (shared) goal by dividing the task and accountability between its members, e. g. a football team is divided into a goalkeeper, forwards and defenders. To win a game everyone has to do their task properly. If the team wins then it was due to the efforts of all teammates (even if some of them were playing better than the others), if the team loses all the players share the failure. Goalkeepers don't lose the game - the whole team does.

In a group everyone has individual goals and the person is accountable only to himself. Group participants may have similar goals, but they do not unite their efforts. When a group of students takes an exam they do not communicate on the topic, but rely on their own strengths and knowledge. If a student fails at the exam he only has himself to blame for the failure.  

To sum up, teams divide the tasks to get to the shared goal, if they fail they share the failure and vice versa. In a group a person sets his individual goal and goes for it, doing all the subtasks by himself.

In a team the people know and trust each other, they can work together. In a group it is usually preferred to work alone.

In a team the people have the same goal, in a group everyone has individual goals.

A group of people does not need to have a shared interest and will thus not want or be able to form personal contacts and reach a common goal.

A team is able to trust each other and can therefore split their task and be more effective.

In groups the participants don't have a strong relation to each other, while in teams the connection/relation between the members is crucial for the success of the project. Also they need to work together for the success, while in groups participants act for mainly for their own best. For an example you can look at a basketball team, which would definitely loose nearly every game if it would act like a group. This means basketball team members would play way more self focused and pass less to the teammates. While a classical team per definition would try to play together as good as they possibly can.

Furthermore participants in groups work for their own goals and aren't necessarily interested in the outcome of the product of an group, while the whole purpose of a team is to achieve success based on a common purpose and goal. Let's take a tutor group for an example, which is mainly meant to make the individuals the best they can get. In contrast the team projects in EIST are primarily focused on the outcome of the project, which is achieved through teamwork and interaction between the team members.

A Group is a Brunch of individuals everyone working for themselves and pursuiting their own goals. A team, are people gathering together, to push each other, trying to achieve a common goal. This goal would hardly be able to reach alone.

A rowing team: If multiple people each try to give their best by rowing very hard but concentrating only on them selves the boat isn’t moving as fast as when they work together. Pushing in sync, giving the right instructions and trusting the others.

Planing a party: A group tries to throw a party. Everyone want to contribute as good as they can. So everybody brings a bottle of champagne to show their good will. At the end the party has a bunch of champagne but their are no glasses, no snacks etc. A team would work and plan together. Everybody brings something different. The champagne , the snacks, the decoration. At the end they split the costs and have a super party.

- Groups are a set of people but they do not necessarily work together on a given project
- Group members are do not know each other very well. Therefore they cannot support each other, given that they dont know their strengths and weaknesses.

Groups are merely given amounts of people, usually not even knowing each other. 
Teams on the other hand are a much more united number of individuals somewhat bonded in sharing the same vision and working towards a common goal - just like a working football team would try to score a goal together.

In a group, every individual focuses in his own work. Participants do not really interact that much with each other. Therefore, a group does not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose.
In a team, participants are strongly connected and talk a lot with each other. Members need to work together, because they are focussing on a specific outcome, which requires coordination of tasks and activities.

A team works together on a common goal and each person in a team is connected through both tasks( maybe not directly but indirectly through the end goal). In that sense, the dials on a watch are a team(specifically the dials for hours and minutes). Both dials can't be used alone and we can assume that in general their purpose is to tell the current time(of course some watches have specific functions excluding this one, such as stopwatches but we will exclude those from the definition). However, if we were to add the dial for seconds into the mix, I would consider that a group. There are clocks and watches that operate without this dial so it's presents is not needed and in a general use, most people aren't interested in the amount of seconds at a current point. It is loosely connected to the other dials because of it's location and that it counts a time interval, however; the dial has another purpose instead of telling the current time.

A team is a construct, in which teammembers work together cohesively, exchange opinions and operate in syntony, in order to reach a certain goal of mutual interest, whereas a group is merely a cluster of people, that is by no means as interconnected, as a team would be, and therefore cannot work as one unit.

Beispiel 1:
Betrachte eine Vorlesung in der Universität. Die Studenten, die in der Vorlesung sitzen bilden eine Gruppe und im Gegensatz dazu gibt es kleine Hausaufgaben-Teams à fünf Personen. Unter den Studenten in der Gruppe / im Vorlesungssaal arbeitet in der Regel jeder alleine auf das Bestehen der Prüfung hin, wohingegen im Hausaufgaben-Team alle das gemeinsame Ziel verfolgen, eine einzelne Abgabe für das gesamte Team fertigzustellen. Im Hausaufgaben-Team arbeiten alle eng miteinander zusammen, wobei die Studenten im Vorlesungssaal weniger eng mit einander verbunden sind.

Beispiel 2:
Eine Gruppe Sightseeing-Touristen ist in gewisser Weise miteinander verbunden, da sie dieselbe Sightseeing Tour zusammen ablaufen. Sie arbeiten jedoch nicht auf ein bestimmtes Ergebnis hin und erzeugen keinen Output im Gegensatz zu einem kleinen Team von Softwareentwicklern in einem IT-Unternehmen, die zusammen ein Softwareprojekt als "Output / Ergebnis" auf die Beine stellen.

While groups are just individuals loosley connected, colleagues in a team have a strong connection. This strong connection is not just build by sharing the same goals und visions but also just by simply spending much time together. For example, students from a "student group" all  have different courses and Tutorien which they attend, while team-members in eg. a professional working enviorment spend their whole day together and thus get to build deeper connections with their colleagues.
Another great difference between the typical 'group-structure' and a real, high-performing team is also their work habits. While for example students all -more or less- work/learn individually, the deeply-rooted team works in perfect coordinated conditions to get the maximum/best results.

Eine Gruppe ist eine Menge an Menschen, die kein gemeinsames Ziel haben, sondern nur die gleiche Sache tun. Ein Team verfolg ein gemeinsames Ziel und erreicht dies gemeinsam mit vereintem Einsatz.

Eine Gruppe Fußballer sind nur eine Menge Menschen die Fußball spielen unabhänig von Liga oder Verein aber ein Fußball Team spielt gemeinsam um ein Fußballspiel zu gewinnen oder in einem Turnier gut abzuschneiden.

In einem Restaurant arbeiten meistens kleine Gruppen an Köchen aber in einem nahmhaften Restaurant arbeitet ein Team aus Köchen, welche die Aufgaben nach den individuellen stärken deligiert und gemeinsam das Ziel haben sehr gutes Essen zuzubereiten.

Group:

cluster of people who know each other and ma be friends.

Team:

cluster of people who work together to complete a task

A group is a collection of people that have a certain intersection like for example a School class. In contrast to a team, a group has no strong relationships and no common goal. An example for a team would be a subgroup of the class, with people who always work together whenever there is a group task and who work together to achieve their common goal.

Groups are a collection of people that are loosely connected and have some sort of relationship with each other. While they are not focusing on a particular common purpose or outcome, every person works individually on his or her own tasks.
A team on the other hand is a grouping of people that are strongly connected and work on the same activity to achieve a common goal. Thus, team members need to work together and coordinate their tasks and activities accordingly.
Here are two examples that illustrate this difference between groups and teams:
One example of a team is a football team that has to work together, coordinate and pursue a common strategy or common tactics (as taught by their trainer). And even though there might be weaker players in the team, a team can still win because the overall team collaborates effectively.
One specific example of a group is a university course, especially when the course is very big and the students in the course are only loosely connected. Even though some students might help each other, every student still works individually on his or her own and mostly cares about his or her own grade in the end.

A group could be described as a collective of individuals, which would need to meet more specific requirements in order to suffice the definition of a team. Cooperation towards a common goal is among necessary requirements for a group to be a team. Some people at a party would form a group, but not generally also a team as they likely have no purpose of cooperation. Just as a crowd, waiting at the railway station to catch their - probably delayed - train, forms no team, even though they would certainly share a common desire.

A group of people is a number of individuals that have something in common and have similar interests, but do not have a particular goal.
They probably barely know each other and/or do not have a strong bond, leading to the group members working individually, instead of together.

For example a group is for example a number of art students sitting together at a table and creating. They are having conversations and interacting with each other, sharing similar individual goals and working on a their own individual pieces, instead of on a big shared creation, making them a group of people.

A team of people is a group of people that have a strong bond and support each other in the process of achieving a shared goal.
They already spent some time together and got to know each other and know how to incorporate each others strengths into a project.
They work towards a shared goal, each of the individuals working together with the others.

For example a sports team is a group of soccer players on a field, where everyone has their position and their tasks to fulfill, in order to win the game, which is the shared goal. They have to work together, by kicking the ball to each other.

As widely used in everyday life, the term team expresses some form of companionship. One example might be a sports team, who strives to win games e.g. A common goal, like winning games, is what these people are after. 

A group on the other hand, is not as connected. For instance, a random agglomeration of people in the shopping mall might be even considered a group, even if they don´t really know each other.

A team shares an activity on which all members have to participate to achieve something, for example in a startup all employees need to work together to build a good software product which can help the company grow. A group does not share this kind of spirit. They do not share this "higher" goal. A group of friends for example has no deep underlying relation in terms of achieving something in contrast to a workforce or a sports team.

Many people think a group and a team are one and the same thing. This is absolutely wrong! And this is why.

While a group consists of a number of people who certainly have a relation to each other, there is no real connection. This is because they may work on a similar task and maybe even help each other, but they are not dependent on each other because of their work. A team NEEDS to work together to achieve a common goal because their work is involved in the same activity.

A good example would be the difference between a soccer TEAM and a school project group. While in the school group every student does his own task and in the end it merged together without, or maybe with a little bit, of the other's knowledge, the soccer team has to work together to win a match. If everybody selfishly does his own job and wants to achieve goals individually, there is no chance for the team to win. And that is for certain!

Another example would be an ant colony. If they just would work as a group, I can assure you that there weren't such things like anthills!

A group is an association of individuals who have their own goals, which may not necessarily coincide with the goals of the other group members. The focus is on the actions and responsibilities of the individual. An example of a group is a group standing in front of a bus stop, they stay together, but may all have a different location where they want to go.

A team, on the other hand, is a group with stronger cohesion and a common goal. They pull together to achieve this goal and the trust between the members is usually higher.
An example of a team is a soccer team whose goal is to win the game.

A group can be defined as a number of people who are poorly connected to each other, they don't share the same goals. For example; in a library, the people who are there can form a group. Each person works on his own.
Contrary to a team in which people are strongly connected to each other. They work together to achieve a common goal. 
Let's take the example of Scrum. This project methodology involves a team in which people (Development team and  Scrum master) are highly connected to each other throw their daily Scrum meetings. They work together for common objectives.

A group are some persons, who got thrown together more or less randomly, while a team is brought together by fate. For example a sport group who want to play competitive will fail because of no common plan on how to achive victory, while a true team will win everything, because they  have a plan and know the playstiles of each other. Or when you wanna solve an complex exercise, in a group in most cases everyone has an own plan which he or she would try to implement, while a team would work together to find the best idea of theirs.

Team: Some people work together to accomplish a certain goal. For example, a team of nurses and doctors work together to cure their patients.

Group: Some people, which have some similarities, but aren't working together for the same goal. For example, people who are in a sports club for an individual sport. They are all connected because they all exercise for the same sport, but they aren't working together on one common goal. Everyone in this group has to work alone to accomplish their own goal.

1. Team members truly value each other’s skills and traits. They identify the different skills and talents of their colleagues and understand how everyone’s strengths and weaknesses can gel together, while group members are more focused on individual task achievement.
2. Team members can tackle their team projects with a shared sense of ambition, trust, and enjoyment. The relationship between group members is very indifferent.

A team is a collection of people that can work together towards a shared goal without hindering each others productivity.

A group is a collection of people that dont share a Goal and/or are not able to work together without hindering each others productivity.

The main difference of groups and teams is in the goals they aim for. In a group, this will be individual goals without common grounds while a team has shared goals, that everyone is working towards. Thus a team is synchronized. Also, a team shares responsibilities without traditional hierarchy, while in a group the responsibility lies in the hands of only one person. This makes a team more efficient and performant. 

Examples
Some people working together at a company with traditional hierarchy, where there is one boss who carries responsibilities and commands the workers, who do the job just to get paid, is a group. 
Some people (11) playing football, where they share the goal to win a championship and have no clear hierarchy is a team.

Groups and teams differ in terms of their degree of familiarity and common purpose. While groups are just the an arbitrary aggregation of people with loose connections to each other, teams have closer connections and a more fleshed-out common purpose.
An example for a group can be festival visitors, who just go to an event at roughly the same time period because they want to listen to different unspecified bands. A team on the other hand would be a band performing at the festival, with members familiar with each other and a goal of playing songs together.
Another example can be classmates in high school. They just happen to be in the same room because of random grouping by the school administration or specific course choices. They hardly had a choice in deciding which people to be grouped with. However, when a teacher assigns a joint presentation of multiple students that requires multiple meetings to complete the presentation preparations, they could be considered a team. They have a joint purpose and are more familiar with how to work with each other.

A group is just a collective of individuals that have some relationship to one another (e. g. they attend the same class). A team, on the other hand, is a group of people that shares a common goal (e. g. football team).

Two examples:
- Sports: Football is a team sport, so all the players are strongly connected and the players have to coordinate and work together in order to score points (common goal). Running is generally a solo sports, so there might be a group of people that participate in the same competition, but every individual works on their own and there is no common goal.
- Teams and groups in university: A class is a group of people. They have some relationship to one another, because they attend the same class, but they are only loosely connected and they don't need to work together to pass the exam. However, if students are assigned a team-project that they have to solve together, they do have to form a team. They need to coordinated (discuss who does what task, create a shared Power-Point-Presentation) and they have a common goal (completing their assignment).

While a team usually has a specified task or goal that they are trying to achieve, like a team at work, a group does not necessarily need a defined purpose, like a group of friends.

A group can also be more flexible as to when and how they want to do something, for example go to a restaurant or movie together without much prior planning, and make decisions spontaneously.
A team needs more focused communication towards achieving their goal, and should generally make use of planning ahead to meet a deadline, or if there is no deadline, have frequent or periodic reports on progress.

A group is a collection of people who are connected to each other through a common relationship and loose connection, but who each work for themselves. In contrast, a team is a group of people who pursue a common goal through joint activities, working very closely together and are in constant exchange. A school class can be mentioned as an example of a group. In a class, the individual students are connected through the class community, but everyone works on their own. In contrast, a team could be a group of students who have to give a presentation on a certain topic. Each member of this team has the goal of a successful presentation. To achieve this, the members must work together strongly and constantly exchange ideas.

A group is a number of people that are unorganized, don't have a common goal and didn't necessarily build any kind of bond between each other. A team on the other hand went through a forming phase where the members were chosen for their qualifications so that a precise goal would be achieved and that through their self organising strategies and methods. 

Examples, one for a team and one for a group:
Example one: A football team on one side of the pitch and another one on the other side with goals on each side. Each team has a common goal which is to kick the ball in the other goal. Through the play they will use strategies and methods to score. They are connected through their Club or country team.
Example two: 22 people that have no connections between them are put on a pitch with no goal posts or lines. They are given a ball and no instructions. Some of them try to pass the ball to each other, some try to dribble the ball and keep it for themselves, some of them want to pick it with their hands and play volleyball. They have no common goal, they show no sign of organization through communication and each one of them is on his own.

When independent individuals who share a common interest gather together, they form a group.

 A team is a collection of interdependent individuals who work together to achieve a common goal. 

The main difference is that while groups focus on individual goals, teams concentrate solely on team goals. 
Commitment and trust play a critical part in teams, and both must be high in order to form a successful team. Groups, on the other hand, may have a low level of commitment and trust.

Group = Persons, who know each other briefly, but dont really have build the necessary understanding necessary to operate efficiently.

Team = Group , which works efficiently and knows each other well, build on trust and understanding

Group: People who have similar work todo but everybody is it doing by his own (content of work differs between the persons).
Team: People who work on bigger task, which is splitted in smaller peaces (for each member a part-task)

Group example: Students work in a GROUP. They sit together (more motivation and better focus) but everyone is doing his own tasks. Only he profits after finishing his work. For example learning stuff about a subject.

Team example: Students have to prepare a presentation about a city. The work could be splitted in different categories like history, events and places to go. Every member of the group (out of 3) prepares one topic. After collecting the Information, the presentation is finished and all three students were responsible for reaching the target (good, informative presentation)

A group is a bunch of people, who may or may not have gotten to know each other, working on something, but they may not be good at working together. Like maybe pupils in working in groups in class, they know each others names but not much more.
A team on the other hand should trust each other and be able to work towards a collective target, like a sports team trying to win int he world championship. To do this they must be good at working together.

A Group is just a number of people which have certain relationships between them and something in commun ,but they do not share a vision or a goal that they want or need to achieve together. Every individual is on its own working on its personal goal if it had one.

A Team on the other hand is  a group of people which are strongly connected. They share the same vision and have a commun goal, that they focus on achieving while working together.

Fox example a Team can be resemble to crew of an Aircraft Carrier, in which every person onboard is doing their task while trusting that another person is doing his task in order to achieve the wanted result (eg. the Take-Off or Landing of a Jet). That means that their tasks are complementary, one can't do all the work alone.

As for a Group we can take the Example of Football-Fans in the Stadiums. They came to the Stadium with the commun goal to watch a Football game that's it. And each invidual supports his own Team.

A group of students may study in the same class independently from one another. Once they get a project assignment, the will work together as a project team to achieve the project's goal. They will have to coordinate tasks and meetings and are more connected to another than before starting the project work.
A group of people visiting a tennis class can be split into teams of two to play together in a tournament. Before being split up, they may not have known one another. Now, each team will work together aiming to win.

The difference between a group and a team is that the people in a group do not have a strong connection compared to the members of a team. Since members of a group do not have a clearly defined common goal, they work on their own, while members of a team work together to achieve their common goal.

Group is a group of people with common characteristics, but a team is a group of members who share a common goal. They coordinate their tasks to achieve their common goals. The main point is that for a group people do not work for a specific purpose together but for a team they should, so people in group they can just do what they like individually they just get together because of something in common, but in team not they should learn to cooperate and teamwork.
Two examples are for example a project team in a company that these people form a team because they have a common goal that they want to finish the project task together and they all work for that. But after this project they are maybe not a team anymore and they do not have any shared version anymore. However,  if they all like fishing they can go out to go fishing and then they are just a group of people who like to go fishing.
Another example is a tennis association is a kind of group but not a team. The tennis association is like a club to gather some people who like playing tennis and then they can find someone who plays tennis together easily. They do not have to work together. But the tennis national team is not. They have the same goal that they need to win the competition or a game. Like if it is German tennis national team they even represent Germany.

A group is just a collection of people with no joint goal. 
Like a class for example, while they do share the goal of sucessfully pass the course they are (probably) not working together at large.

A team on the other hand is a group of people, who DO share a goal and work together to achieve said goal.
While the whole class isn't one team, smaller groups can form to work on a project or learn together for example, hence: a team.

A group of people is in principle a collection of people, where participants aren't connected by any sort of strong bond or a set of common core values. Hence, the people are generally not chained to one another in the metaphorical sense, so as to ensure that the group has strong bonds. This in turn leads to the members working more individually and independently, which in turn leads to them focusing on individual goals rather than common goals. Since every individual undergoes his labour on his own, no common aim is shared.

A team of people on the other hand, is a collection of people, where participants are interconnected to one another in a meaningful and powerful way. A bit like in a pack of wolves, every team-member puts the team above themselves, which in turn leads to everyone having each other's backs. This is generally speaking fueled by the team having a common aim, or objective which they are trying to accomplish to the utmost quality. Furthermore, this leads to the requirement of a rigorous and effective way to organize, coordinate and manage business campaigns, tasks and projects. This in turn requires a widespread Team-Mentality where everyone operates as a common entity and where everyone works together.

An example of a group, would be a nation on a macroscopic scale (assuming a capitalistic system). Everyone is connected in the sense, that they are from the same nation, however, all citizens work for themselves, and on their own, without a direct common goal. A common purpose is only met indirectly, in the sense that the society only functions, when everyone does his or her job, however, the society's members are by no means focusing on a common objective, and the members are by no means strongly connected, rather they are at most barely connected with the majority of people. In fact, the free market assumes constant competition between a variety of business entities (within the context of any business-sector), hence not only are people not strongly connected to each other, but they are constantly competing with each other, by either working for different companies/business entities or by simply competing with each other to constantly try to reach the pinnacle of the business hierarchies.

An example of a team, would be a team of basketball players. Every basketball player shares the goal of wanting to contribute to and improve the basketball team. Everyone has each other's backs. And everyone is strongly connected, in their objective of trying to win competitions, by constantly assembling the best possible team to face their opponents and by constantly working in a cohesive and united manner, to complement each other's skills. Furthermore, this is done to induce the best possible system of players and tactics for a particular match, by utilizing the talent of the individual players in the best possible manner, as well as aiming to achieve the best-functioning synergistic system.

There are many differences between a team and a group but some of the most prominent ones are the differences in the types of goals that they have. For example in a group each person has a specific individual goal while a team has one collective aim which they try to achieve with joint effort. In a lot of groups the members are somewhat independent while in a team there are multiple leaders, the work process depends on the development of each member and each one of the members share responsibility for the outcome of the result. In a group there is almost never such responsibility and most of the work is individually divided while a team works on the solution collectively. 
One such example for a group is a newly formed class in a new school year. There are around 30 people who share the same room, teachers and subjects and they constantly interact with each other. Nevertheless not all of them share the same goals and there is nothing concusively binding them together. 
On another hand an appropriate example of a team would be a school volleyball team. While being in the same institution as a class, the volleyball team shares one goal - to win the game. This depends entirely on the communication and teamwork between each individual player. They are essential for a successful development of a volleball game, where miscommunication for 1 second can cost the victory of the team. When problems occur the team discusses and works on them collectively. The work process is interdependant.
People in a group are loosely connected and don't have a common goal. On the other hand a team consists of people with a shared goal that have to work together closely to achieve that goal.

In a group are a number of people that have some relationship to one another.
Participants are loosely connected and do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose.
Every individual works on his own.

A team is a group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal.
Participants are strongly connected and focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities.
Members need to work together.

A group is made up of a number of people with some relationship with each other.
The main charactereristics of a group are:
- Participants are loosely connected
- Participants do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose
- Every individual works on his own

A team is made group of people with the same activity and a common goal.
The main characteristics of a team are:
- Participants are strongly connected
- Focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities 
- Members need to work together

A Group is a set of independent individuals, each one of them is "there" for whatever personal reason. The actions of one of these people, does not necessarily influence the rest of the Group. They don't have a common goal, and the success of failure of on of them does not mean the same for the other individuals.
On the other hand, a team is a number of people, usually with complementary skillsets, they work together to reach a common goal and the failure/success of one member means the failure/success of the whole team. 
An example of this would be a "Tutor Group" and a "Project Team" : In an EIST tutor Group for example, if one student fails, it doesn't mean all the other students in that group will fail, and they don't need each other in order to reach their personal goals (maybe some are there to understand the course better, maybe some have problems with the exercices, maybe some just want to meet their friends) however, in a Project Team, if one of the members doesn't do his work, the whole team suffers and loses points and doesn't reach it's goals which are the same in the case of an EIST project Team : finish the exercices well in order to get the maximum amount of bonus points.
Another example would be in a company, a group of coworkers is different to a team responsible for a certain product, the group of coworkers each has his own goals and they do not depend on each other, even if one gets fired, the others will not be influenced. A team however work on the same product and have the same goal, if one of them gets fired or leave, the team will have difficulties and eventually break down.

A group constitutes an association of two or more people having possibly different achievements. For instance, to allow a better learning experience in a module containing thousands of students, the lecturer could create small groups of them. The goal in this case is to enhance participation and to increase students commitment and interactions, which could be difficult without theses small groups. 
Whereas teams, are groups of people with the same goal. They join their forces and competencies to achieve a common objective. A good example could be a scrum procject, in which the main goal is to deliver a product at time. For this reason, the team members works together and have a common vision. It´s also essential to respect the added value of others.

A group is a collection of people that are in a close proximity to each other and may work towards the same goal but do not depend on each other to get there. For example a group of students. They all work towards passing the next exam but they take the exam by themselves and do not need to comunicate to pass it.

A team would be a group of peolpe that depend on each other and work closly together to achieve their goal. They have to know each other well and distribute tasks between them. An example would be a soccer team. No player can win the game by themselves. They need to work together and trust one another to do their task to win.

Eine Gruppe ist eine Anzahl von Personen, die lose ein verfolgtes Ziel an einen Ort oder eine Tätigkeit bindet. Dieses Ziel wird jedoch nicht gemeinsam, sondern jeweils individuel verfolgt.

Ein Team hingegen verfolgt gemeinsam ein Ziel. Diese Personen kennen sich meist gegenseitig besser als in einer Gruppe. Oft spielt hier Arbeitsteilung eine Rolle und Teamwork ist unbedingt notwendig

Eine Gruppe ist beispielsweiße ein Hörsaal voller Studenten, sie alle verfolgen das Ziel den Kurs zu bestehen, jedoch arbeitet jeder eigenständig daran, so sind sie eine Gruppe Studenten, kein Team.

Ein Team ist z.B. eine Fußballmannschaft, hier arbeiten alle daran das Spiel zu gewinnen, hier gibt es Rollen wie Torwart, Stürmer etc. jedoch spielen alle zusammen, passen und sprechen sich ab um das gemeinsame Ziel zu erreichen, sie spielen im Team.

If for example two people in a group aim for different goals and have a different picture of what and how they want to achieve, than they are no team. If all the group members work together on the same thing and agree on their preferences in a project, if they cooperate with each other in order to succeed, than this group can be called a team.

Group is just people that just have a connection, whereas, teams are connected with stronger bonds and they try to achieve a specific goal together. 

Examples :
1- The Erasmus student group, people do not have the same goals, they are individuals with a connection. However, erasmus football team is a team that cooperatively works to win the tournament.

2- Family(group) is a collection of people that have a connection which is blood. However, the apple DevOps team is a team that works on specific tasks together.

For a team it is important to pursue the same goal:
As an example, a car racing team is a real team because all the people in the group are trying to achieve the same goal, which is to win a race. If it were just a group, it is possible that each person would have a different goal. So it could be important for the driver to win, but for the engineer to be as resource efficient as possible and so it would not be a team anymore, but only a group.

It is characteristic for a group not to have a close cooperation and relationship:
As an example, the "Daimler Group" is only a group and not a team, since there are no major dependencies and relationships between the individual persons/products. There may of course be isolated connections, but these would then only be loosely connected (i.e. there is no constant exchange, etc.).
In addition, the individuals of the various companies or subsidiaries work independently, which is indicative of a group.

Eine Gruppe besteht aus einem "losen" Zusammenschluss aus Leuten. Die nicht unbedingt ein gemeinsames Ziel haben müssen und in der Regel auch nicht davon abhängig sind zusammenzuarbeiten um ihr Ziel(meist individulles Ziel) zu erreichen. In einem Team hingegen, finden sich die "Member" des Teams gans bewusst zusammen um ein gemeinsames Ziel zu erreichen, dass sie sonst aleine gar nicht (oder nur schwer) erreichen würden. Um dieses Ziel zu erreichen muss jedes Teammitglied im Verbund "Team" funtionieren und zusammenarbeit, vlt. auch einmal Kompromisse eingehen, und seine eigenen Skills möglichst gewinnbringend für das Team und das Erreichen des gemeinsamen Ziels einbringen. Tut das ein Mitglied nicht hindert das den Erfolg des Gemeinsamen Projektes ungemein.

Group is a collection of individuals who share some common ground however they are not guided by one common goal or idea.
While a team is a collection of individuals who share similarities, with a common goal or idea or connection that unites them.

For example, a rugby team is a team, as their common goal is to make their team win while a random selection of fans watching the game is a group as they do not share a common goal.

A team of scientists working to cure a special disease is a team as they work towards a common goal, while a bunch of scientists are just a group of scientists, who do not share a direct common goal.

Ein Team besteht aus einer Anzahl von Personen, die dieselbe Tätigkeit ausführen und dabei ein gemeinsames Ziel haben. Dabei ist wichtig, dass die verschiedenen Teammitglieder eine starke Verbindung bzw. eine gute Beziehung zueinander haben. Die Beziehungen zwischen den Mitgliedern ist bei einem Team sehr viel ausgeprägter und enger als die bei einer Gruppe. 
Ein wichtiger Aspekt für ein Team ist die Zusammenarbeit. Diese spielt eine wichtige Rolle, da normalerweise die verschiedenen Aufgaben, die erledigt werden müssen um ans Ziel zu kommen, auf die Teammitglieder aufgeteilt werden. Dies erfordert neben Zusammenarbeit auch Koordination. 

Eine Gruppe besteht aus einer Anzahl von Personen, die zwar eine Beziehung zueinander haben, diese aber nicht besonders ausgeprägt ist. Jeder der Teilnehmer einer Gruppe arbeitet für sich selber, somit ist in einer Gruppe nicht wie in einem Team Zusammenarbeit notwendig. Außerdem konzentrieren sich die Gruppenteilnehmer nicht auf ein bestimmtes Ziel.

Ein Beispiel für ein Team ist eine Fußballmannschaft, denn um zu gewinnen müssen alle Teammitglieder zusammenspielen und sich miteinander abstimmen. Außerdem haben die Teammitglieder untereinander eine enge Beziehung und müssen sich auf die anderen verlassen können. Eine Gruppe hingegen sind ein paar Jungs, die sich zufällig auf dem Bolzplatz treffen um bisschen zu kicken. Die Gruppenmitglieder haben hier keine ausgeprägte Beziehung und jeder einzelne von ihnen trainiert für sich selber.


Ein Beispiel für eine Gruppe wären verschiedene Studenten, die gleichzeitig in der Bib für verschiedene Fächer lernen. Denn jeder Student lernt für sich selber und die Studenten untereinander haben keine ausgeprägte Beziehung, da sie sich zufällig in der Bib treffen. Ein Team hingegen wären 5 Studenten, die zusammen die EIST Gruppenprogrammieraufgabe bearbeiten. Diese 5 Studenten müssen zusammenarbeiten und sich koordinieren, um die Aufgabe letztendlich vollständig zu lösen. Dabei ist es wichtig, dass die Studenten sich auch untereinander gut verstehen und eine ausgeprägte Beziehung haben, um ihr gemeinsames Ziel (volle Punktzahl) zu erreichen.

Essentially the difference between groups and teams boils down to the fact that a team works together towards achieving a shared goal that also leads to a strong connection and collaboration, while a group does not possess that shared vision towards achieving that target. Therefore there is also a different intensity with which these members are connected to each other. 

One example would be a group of people in a course at university which go to the same lecture but in fact only care about their individual performance in the final exam. Hence there is no strong bond holding them together apart from having to attend the same course. That changes when a graded project is required to pass the course, then a team is formed out of a few group members that work towards a satisfactory grade and therefore strongly collaborate and it is also very likely that they spend a lot more time together in the team than they would with their fellow students in the university course. 

Second, consider a field hockey summer camp with random players from different countries and clubs with a competitive atmosphere and spirit. Individually in their groups divided by age/skill/gender the players mostly care about their own success in skill trials or shooting drills. That changes when a daily tournament with mixed teams takes place. Naturally, then the players work together and try to beat the other team by collaborating, playing together harmoniously and with better tactics with the overarching goal of ultimately winning the tournament!

A team is a group of people who have a single goal, whereas a group is a collection of individuals who coordinate their efforts.
When it comes to decision-making and teamwork, the two are quite different. Group members of a work group are self-contained and responsible for their own actions.
Team: Sports team, if the team looses, everybody looses.
Group: group project, some people may benefit because of the project while others fail.

A group is a collection of people with some relationship to another, e.g., a group of students selected for a scholarship. 

A team is a group involved in the same activity with a common goal. This typically requires the coordination of tasks and working together. An example of this is a team of students working on a project to develop a start-up idea.

A group is a number of people that have some sort of relationship with one another. A team, on the other hand, is a group that is involved in the same activity with a common goal. While groups are loosely connected and don't focus on a common goal, teams are strongly interconnected and members are required to work together. 

My neighbours in my street are a group. We are connected via our geographic and demographic attributes and don't have a common purpose. Therefore, we don't work together since everybody cares for their own property, food etc. 
My WG mates and I are a team because we work together and need to work together in order to keep the apartment clean. Therefore we have a cleaning plan which is a form of organisation and supports coordination. We are therefore far more strongly connected through thorough communication.

Groups are people that have some relationship with each others but they work individually and less connected.
Teams are people who have common goal and work together which are highly connected.

A group are people that are together, but do not share a common goal. For example, the students in a lecture could be taken as a group since they’re not working together to accomplish something. A team are people that are together but with the exact opposite focus. A team works together to accomplish something, for example a project. They share the same vision

Groups consists of people with relationships. They don't have a shared goal or purpose. Teamwork is not existent.

Teams consist of people with strong relationship. They share a goal and purpose. Teamwork is necessary for the goals to be achieved

Group is a several people, who are somehow related to each other, but still work individually.
Team is a group of people, who have common goals and work in conjunction for its implementation. So they are coordinated and connected with each other.

For example, students, who watch EIST(2200) lection are a group. They have no connection with each other .But students who prepare to the exam together in a small groups are team. They want to help each other with understanding and have a common goal (pass the exam).

The neighbors(roommates), who live together are a group, if they live together and do not even see and speak with each other. But they can be a team, when they have a common goal to keep house clean.

The difference between a group vs team.
Lets first define a group and team. A group is a collection of people whos primary goal is to focus on themselves and less in terms of team work or shared work. Their success or failure is mainly dependent on them instead of the group which they are associated to. On the otherhand, a team is also a collection of people who have a common goal which can be shared between each other and their success or failure depend on the teams effort. Mainly asscociating to the concept of "we rise together or we fail together". 

By looking at an analogy of sports, there can be a clear and distinct difference between a group and team. If you consider a sport like basketball, you can take two sides which can tell the difference between a group and team. A basketball group can be considered by looking at an individual performance of a player at the end of the game. The individual aspects of the player will be assessed and the mentaility of the player is to mainly to focus on themselevs within the group of players. Comparing their skill against others to make them better players. However, when a basketball team plays they have a specific common goal which is to win. Durring the game, the players focus of the 5 teammates are to derrive a solution with the coach (shared role of leadership) to establish a way of winning the game which is the primary goal. Each teammate will offer something specific which will allow the team to work collabrotively to achieve their final goal which is to win the game. If they win or loose they do that as a team regardless of the score.  

The final example I would want to use, is the example at a company which uses different types of leadership styles. The difference between an autocratic vs a democratic leadership style at a company. The autocratic leadership has mainly one person whos delegated control and all the people who work for the leader are mainly judged based on individual performances and based on the sole effort the group runs through one person. In a democratic leadership style it allows more people to give a say and discuss options and have a clear agenda towards the teams goal. The leader is mainly the person to rule the discussions and aspects talked between the teammates. This mainly allows for the team to work collaboratively and discuss goals, plans and strategies. Hence the clear difference between groups and teams is associated in this example with autocratic leadership (group) vs democratic leadership (team) styles.

a group is a bunch of people who are somewhat connected but not necessarily working together to achieve anything.
compared to that, a team is a group whos members are connected by a joint activity or task and aim to succuessfully engage in the activity together or fullfil the task properly together

A group are people working together while everyone is working by himself, while as a team works connected together. So a Team would be a sport team working together, like a Volleyball team trying to win by playing connected, while as a group of students work individual, just trying to pass an exam

The members in the group are not strongly connected but members in team are. The participants in the group all work on their own and not for a common purpose. In comparison ,participants in team need to cooperate and all work for a same goal.

When two or more individuals are classed together either by the organization or out of social needs, it is known as a group. People in one group could act individually. On the other hand, a team is the collection of people, who are linked together to achieve a common objective. The corporation in a team is crucial.

Groups and teams describe a number of people.
One difference between groups and teams is that teams work have a common goal and work together to reach it. Therefore, teams are connected very strongly. Groups do not have a goal and don’t work together to reach it. Members of a group have a relationship to other members but are not connected as strong as teams.

The main difference between a group and a team is the kind of working together. A group is a team if it works on a way closer level then just people who has been put together randomly. Usually in a team everybody knows his/her role and how he/she is important in the working process. 

An example you can see the difference in is a random group of people playing football in comparison to a "real" team playing. In the random group they don't exactly know the strengths and weaknesses of each other and therefore can't play together efficiently. The experienced team has strict tactics and knowlegde of each other and works more organized. 

You can also see a team vs a group in nearly every company. Teams that work together for are long time know whom to ask and what "their job" of the team is. As a consequence they can work faster and with a higher level of quality than just a group of people. It's more difficult for them to organize and they are just not that experienced that they know exactly how to handle problems and whom to ask.

Teams sind Gruppen von eng und produktiv zusammenarbeitenden Menschen die alle ein gemeinsames Ziel verfolgen. Hierbei ist meist eine erfolgreiche Kommunikation und das aufeinander abgestimmte Handeln Grundlage für das erfolgreiche Arbeiten.( Z.B Arbeit einer Stiftung oder Partei mit dem Ziel aller Beteiligten die partei/Stiftung bekannter zu machen/voran zu treiben).


Gruppen hingegen sind lediglich lose Aggregationen von individuen ohne gemeinsames Zile und meist ohne intensive Kommunikation. Sie können also mehr als ein haufen von Individuen betrachtet werden.
(Z.B Schüler an einer Schule => jeder arbeitet für seinen eigenen individuellen Erfolg)

A Group referes to several people, that have some relations(rather weak). There is no specific thing they have in common. For example the group of people travelling on a certain flight. They are somehow connected, as the take the same flight, but apart from that they are individulals, who don't have anything certain in common. Teams are a subclass of Groups, as the have relations, but the realtions are specified to be rather strong. A Team has a certain goal or function to which the members of the team contribute. Teams are structured in a way in order to reach the goal more effectively. The most forward example for a team would be a soccer team. Some of the persons in the team might be friends or they have correlating functions within the team by which they are connected, like the defense that has to work together and follow a certain tactic. But there is probably a tactic for the whole team as well, in order to reach their goal(to shot goals) more effectivley. Every Person in the team plays a role and contributes to the game/ win of the team.

Especially in computer science, the difference between teams and groups becomes very visible when it comes to efficiency and performance. Due to the strong bond and the common goal, a good working team outsmarts every group which members were only thrown together by chance and without a common goal.

A second difference comes in the way members of groups and teams work individually and how they have to interact with each other during their work. In a group, everybody can work for their own to simply reach their target. On the other hand, in a team each member has to work with their partners, so they can specialize on their skills and the work which presupposes that skill. Therefore, it needs strong communication skills in a team, through which big problems can be cracked down and as a result, solved way easier than as a normal group.

In a group the members don't have a common goal or task on which everybody is working. They are not connected through a specific work meaning that everybody is solely looking on their own work and is focussing on themselves. 
However in a team the memebers are mainly together because of a specific reason which may be for example work or sports. Therefore they are working together to achieve a related goal. That requires good structure and organization.

For example a bunch of friends that know each other from school but have already graduated, are now working on their own career which can differ between the members of the group. So at that point everybody is working on their own (dream) job and they are only connected through their friendship which means they are not working together on one outcome and are a group. 

A motorsports team is an example for a team, because the memebers are in the team to achieve wins, awards, etc. together, so they are working on a goal that is the same or at least similar for everybody there. They have memebers that work on different parts of the car and therefore need good coordination within the team to have the best possible outcome.
A Group is made of people who are somehow related and do not necessarily have a common goal. A team is in the other hand a group, whose participants work together due to its common goal.

The biggest difference between groups and teams is that people in teams will have solidarity and focus on achieving their shared goal with joint effort, which means they pay more attention to the interest of teams and have closer relationship. On contrary to  those in teams, persons in the groups will have looser relationship with each other and do their own part of work instead of participating in teamwork. 
Example 1: People work in teams when they discuss with others on topics based on the work their need to finish together and solve problems together instead of on their own. Otherwise, they may offer different ideas and opinions on diverse themes.
Example2: For example, when several people finish a task separately without discussion and just hand in the part of work they were supposed to finish, they work in groups because they don't focus on a common purpose but for a more personal purpose, such as just finishing their own work without helping others or some kind of muddling through their work.

In group people are not connected strongly, they just habe something in common, but not goal. They are not working together, everybody works with his own tasks and problems.

In team people work with a common goal, they are interested in a result and are strongly connecred, everybody make some part of a big task. They also trust each other.

Whethier people are in a group or in a team, they all have something in common and are in some type of relationship, But the difference is how strong the connection/relationship is. If you think of a team, something like a footballteam comes into ones mind. Teams have a really strong connection, they spent a lot of time together and they are coordinating things, adapting to each member and trying to work together as smooth as possible. That´s why it´s called teamwork. They especially "train" for that and that´s what makes a team. Working together, having the same mindset and the spirit and spending a lot of time together, trying to archieve something, whether it be a goal, a task or anything else. The members of a footballteam for example eat, train, chill, laugh, etc. and spend time every single day together to deepen their connection, train their coordination to be the best team out there. On the other hand, groups are somewhat like the opposite. They are just a bunch of random people, often not knowing each others names or anything about the others, but they still have something in common and that´s why they can be called a group since they have a really weak connection. For example a group of students. Many don´t know each other, but they can all be called a group since the all have in common that they are studying something. And even if they study the same subject and that´s why they are at the same place at the same time, they are just still a group, since they don´t have a strong connection to each other. While they do spent a lot of time together at the same place, there´s a huge difference between spending time at the same place and spending time together, interacting between them. They all just mind their own business, working, thinking and doing things on their own and for their own, just minding their own business. In comparison to teams, there´s no sign of any coordination or working together.

People working in a group are losely connected to each other, work individually - without a wider vision. Members of a team however work together to achive mutual goals, trust each other and share a strong bond.

As defined in the lecture a Group and a Team are two different concepts, although a team shares some properties in common with a group, a team has additional requirements. While a group is a aggregation of people that have some relationship to each other, a team is a group of people involved in the same activity that's working towards a common goal. 
	
A good example of the differences would be a group of friends: friends are usually all connected through school for example, but that doesen't mean that they would all have the same goals or the same activities that would allow them to become a team (although subsets of the group of friends would probably work as a team, since they might share the same club activities or sports for example or because they simply have a common interest that they all want to pursue).
	
Now an example for team would be chefs and cooks for example. They are all working together to be able to create the best dishes they can. Here, although they work alone in their specific area they continuously affect the work of the other chefs since they are all working on the same dishes/food so if someone fails with one step of the process the whole process feels that weight of that failure and the other cooks will get a harder time doing their part. This strong connection between each step of the cooking process makes cooks more than just a group of people that like to cook, since they are actively forced to work, coordinate and care about each step of the process , since they're affected by others as well.

A group is a collection of people with some sort of relationship, so students visiting a course might be called a group since they are connected by that fact, however their goals do not necessarily align and on top of that they do not work together to reach their goal (graduating) as a collective, but each individual needs to succeed in his own right. A team, on the other hand, is a more tight-knit community which profit of each other's work. So, a football team or any sports team can be called a team (haha it's in the name) since they form a single organism, where every part works toward the greater good, and they fail or succeed not as individuals but as the collective.

A group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another. Participants in a group are loosely connected. They do not focus on specific outcomes or a common purpose and every individual works on his own. On the other hand, a team means any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work. Participants in a team are strongly connected. They focus on a specific outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities and the members of a team need to work together.
For example, when we take part in a tour group, we become temporarily a group with some strangers. We travel together but we don't have a common purpose. The traveller A might interests in taking pictures, while the traveller B enjoy going shopping at the tourist attraction. So they enjoy the tour in different ways and travel on their own. Compared with the tour group, a documentary team is quite different. They travel together in order to make a documentary. They are strong connected with the same goal and have different works. A is responsible for taking pictures of the scenery, while B records the sound of the animals. They work together and finally make a complete documentary.

A Group is a bunch of people who have something in common, are in relation to each other, but don't share a common goal. They don't need to work together. For example, in some Modules we are split in different Tutor-GROUPS where we all participate in the same Tutorial, but we don't work together, we solve our Exercices alone.

A Team is also a group of people, but they all share the same goal and they all work together to achieve that goal. For example in GRA we will be part of a Team of 3 People where we share the same goal to develop our project and all work togther to achieve this goal.

A Group is different then a Team, because in a Group everyone focus on himself and they don't work  together. But in in a Team all work together and help eachother. In addition to that a Group barely know eachother, like they met the first time, but a Team is build of friends. A Team trust eachother, but a Group doesn't, because the members don't know the others in the Group, like I said before. A Team has also a Goal, which they want to reach together, like in a soccer game, they want to win and they do that by playing together. But a Groupmembers wouldn't pass the Ball.

While a group is a collection of people working on seperate tasks and only share a common interest, a team does not only share the same interest but also works in an organized manner.

A team has good interpersonal relations. In contrast to  teammemberrelations   people in a group dont nurse their relations to eachother. Teams have the same goal and are graded as a unit and Groups mostly focus on individual goals and are therefore graded seperately.

Eine Gruppe ist ein zusammenschluss von Menschen mit einem gemeinsamen Interesse, die aber keine Zwischenmenschliche Beziehung besitzen. Ein Team ist ein zusammenschluss an Menschen, die ein gemeinsames Interesse haben und dabei auch zwischenmenschliche Beziehungen aufbauen, da dies die Leistungen des Teams verbessern.

A group is a collection of people, a team is a group of people who share common goal, and work closely to solve problems.

Example 1:
Group: students in a lecture hall
Team: groups of people who are formed to solve a project together.  

Example 2:
Group: passengers in a train
Team: groups of train employees who share the same goal to serve the passenger and transport them to their destination.

A group is a number of people, who have little in common and are independant from one another. They usually have different priorities and visions. For example, cashiers at the supermarket are just a group, since they are only binded by the same workplace and nothing else and work in different ways and because of different reasons.

A team on the other hand, is a group of people who share the same perspective and goal and work together to reach it consistently. For example, a pair of competetive dancers are a team, since they share years of training together and dreaming together about the same goal whether it would be to become world champions or do a spin perfectly.

Eine Gruppe besteht aus einzelnen Personen die sich zusammenschließen. Eine Gruppe verfolgt kein gemeinsames Ziel. Die Mitglieder stehen für sich alleine und haben eigene Ziele.

Ein Team hingegen muss sich zunächst erst bilden und entwickeln. Danach arbeitet das Team eng zusammen an einem gemeinsamen Ziel. Dabei werden klar Aufgaben vergeben.


1. Ein Beispiel für eine Gruppe ist eine einfache Freundesgruppe bestehend aus mehreren Jugendlichen. Schließen sich nun aber mehrere Jugendliche zusammen und gründen ein Startup, so entsteht aus diesen Jugendlichen ein Team.

2. Ein weiteres Beispiel wäre ein Hobbymäßiger Basketballverein(Gruppe). Im Gegensatz zu einem Professionellen Verein(Team).

A Group is a word describing a number of people regardless of motivations, goals or connections. The people in a group are at best loosely connected. A good example is a friend group. While the people in a friend group are connected by similar interests, hobbies or personalities, they all strive towards different goals and have different motivations for being part of that friendgroup.

A team is a group, that also strives towards a common goal and has to coordinate between themselves. This can be seen in professional sports like football. The people in a football team have to coordinate perfectly between each other to achieve their common goal. This is done by having strategy meetings/discussions and focusing on teamwork between the players.

Before I list the differences between a group and a team, it is necessary to understand each definition in order to clearly discover the unique features of each ones.
If we designate, for example, five people as a group, it means we are talking about a set of people who are united according to specific interests, characteristics, professions, activities, etc.
Like a group, a team is a collection of people.
So what's the difference?
When we talk about a team, we mean people who have a common goal, trust and cooperation between members. Literally everyone on the team is important. The team is one entity. For example, if we take a football team, we will see that each person plays a role in this "organism", they distribute responsibilities through communication. With trust in each other, they follow the plan they developed together and move towards a common goal.
That's what distinguishes a close-knit team from a simple group of people - working together.

A group is composed of 2 or more persons that are classed together following a criteria (company, country, university, ethnicity...) but can yet still be totally independent from one another. A team i a number of people who have a common goal and who join their efforts to achieve it. For example, a collective sport group is a team as they all aim to win or be qualified and they all count on each other for that. As, student at the technical university of Munich are just a group of people belonging to the same educational institution, with admittedly, the same goal (to graduate), but the accountability, success or failure are individual.
