Gruppe: eine Menge von Leuten die in einer irgend einer Beziehung zu einander Stehen z.B. alle Studenten einer Vorlesung.
Team: jede Gruppe von Personen, die an derselben Aktivität mit einem gemeinsamen Ziel beteiligt sind,
insbesondere in Bezug auf Sport und Arbeit z.B. Teams in der Gruppenarbeit der Tutorübung

In groups participants are loosely connected but in teams there is a strong connection between members. 
Groups don't focus on outcomes and don't have a common outcome but teams do.

       For example in a group of friends a member doesn't have to have a close relationship with every other member. He/She doesn't have to talk or build a strong relationship with every other member since there is no need, because he/she doesn't have an outcome out of it. However in a volleyball team or an engineer team in work for example, every single participant should be able to talk and exchange ideas with each other in order to gain an outcome out of their gathering. For example, during a volleyball match the coach always gives ideas to the members of the team in order to improve the team and thus to win the match. But in a gathering of a friend group for example 2 people who don't like each-other, don't have to talk. Or the members of a tourist group don't have to build close relationships with one another since they don't have an outcome together but a team in a workplace should always share their progress on their project and share ideas to reach their aim.

Meiner Meinung nach ist eine Gruppe eine paar Menschen, die kein einziges Ziel haben und wenig miteinander kommunizieren. z.B. Wenn ich im Gymnasium war, gab es ein Aktivität heisst "Gruppenabend"(bedeutet einfach rausgehen und etwas spielen, z.B. Bowling, Kart fahren.) Alle Jungen im Internat sind eine Gruppe, aber die einzige Beziehung ist, dass wir alle männer sind. Wir müssen auch nicht miteinander zusammenarbeit, jede macht seine eigene Dinge.
Aber Team sind ganz anders, z.B. ein Esportsteam. Zuerst alle haben das gleiche Ziel : immer bessere Leistung zu kriegen. Alle Teammate müssen miteinander gut kommunizieren, Meinung austauchen. Für das Ziel zu schaffen, alle müssen jeden Tag Training machen. Außerdem spielt Teamwork eine große Rolle, um eingie Herausforderung zu überwinden z.B. wenn Team zu schlecht spielt, dann die Ünterstützung durch Sponsoren wird bestimmt verreingt. Im Vergleich zu Gruppen, ,sind die Menschen im Team wie ein Ganzen, sie arbeiten zusammen, sie verbessern zusammen, sie tragen die gleiche Verantwortung.

A lot of companies have different projects. Every project has his own team. They have common goal like finish the project in 6 months. Therefore team members should know their task. All team members are strongyl connected because of the outcome. Another example could be an football team. The members want to win the game, so they have to work together to achieve it. 

In comparison a group would not concentrate at this specific outcome like the team members. Good example for a group is a family. Of course they have common goals like holiday together but there is no listed task who does this like in a company. They can agree who does what but it is not strict like in a team.  Another example of a group is a friend group. They have some relationship but each individual works or does something else as their profession.

Both Groups and teams are collections of people but they differ in their capability to work together towards a common goal. Teams can organize themselves and divide work among themselves so it becomes possible for the team to finish this work and reach the common goal. Groups lack this organization and the necessary skills to work together with the concreate group members. 

For example a soccer team is a team because the team members have organized themselves into different roles (gate keeper, midfield, ...). Also the team members know each other and can work together in order to win the game, they can rely on each other to follow certain tactics and behave in a way, that makes winning easier (for example right positioning to pass the ball). 

Another example for a team is an orchestra. The Orchestra players are divided into different groups according to their instruments or the passages they play, with a conductor to lead and organize them during the concert. All members of the orchestra know the passages they need to play and can rely on the others to play their parts correctly too.

A team differs from a group by having a common goal, that all team members need/want to work towards.
Members of a team depend on each others work and need to coordinate to achieve their goals.
While a group is just a loose term for any formation of people that have some relation to each other.
An example for a group are the students of an arbitrary lecture.
An example for a team is a hockey team.

Groups: Kein starker zusammenhalt, kein gemeinsames Ziel, jeder arbeitet für sich selbst. Bsp.: Alle Studenten an der Tum, Einwohner einer Stadt

Teams: das Gegenteil von allem was oben steht Bsp.: Arbeitskollegen, Sportteam, Vereine...

Teams strive to complete a certain task. Each member of the team is part of, for example, the programming project. They need to work together in order to be successful. Groups on the other hand do not exist to solve a task or some kind of group work. They form through any kind of relationship. People in a group therefore do not need to work together. They rather work on their own tasks and do not need input from a group member. The second difference is partially influenced by the first one. The connection between team members is way stronger than between group members. Team members need to trust each other in order to be productive. If there is no trust, performance suffers because you constantly have to check your co-worker's work. This bond increases over time and eventually leads to a high performing team. Groups on the other hand do not share a common task. Therefore, trust and compliance is not necessarily needed. As a result, the bond between members is weak.
These differences can be illustrated using two examples. A hotel is managed by a team of employees. They need to work together in order to provide the best customer service. The visitors on the other hand form a group. They all visit the same hotel. So they share a certain interest/relation. But they do not focus on the same task. Some might want to relax. Others want to be more active.
A lecture is also a good example. The professor and his co-workers are a team. They each need to fulfill a certain task to create a lecture. Everyone has to rely on the others. They are often even connected outside the lecture hall. The students on the other hand do not need to help each other. It may occur in friend groups, but almost everyone is focused on their specific task to pass. The results of the fellow students that they do not know do not matter in this case.

A group is made up of multiple people that may potentially work towards a similar goal (but more often an individual one) and mostly do it in an independent way, without distributing parts of the problem to others. This means that everyone works on their own, but still have a slight connection (for example by being in the same company).
An example would be a company that has a group of software developers, which consists of three people for example: A front-end, back-end developer and quality assurance. They all work on their own in an isolated manner, but sometimes exchange what they have achieved in common meetings.

A team is made up of multiple people that always work towards a shared goal, mostly doing it in a way where they rely and depend on each other, for example by splitting up work and distributing it. They have to regularly keep in contact to make sure that everyone works on the right thing.
An example would be a collection of multiple front-end developers working together to design a user interface that should have a general and consistent look and feel. Some UI components or page are split up on each member of the team and sometimes multiple people work on the same thing.

Teams are a number of people who move towards a common goal by exchanging ideas and active communication. Unlike them, in groups, there is no team-spirit. That's why, they are less connected.

We can point out the board of directors of any company for the example of the teams . These people have a common purpose, to run the company in the most efficient way. For this goal, these people are connected and work together.

For the group example we can give the circle of friends. Every one of them has his own work.

The connection between participants in a group is not as tight as the connection between participants in a team. Also the group members focus on their own purpose and work on their own, unlike the team members, they have a common goal and must work together to solve tasks, that means cooperation is very essential.
The students who attended the course can count as a group. We may not have so much in common and in this group we do not have a common goal, we have to fight for our own goals like pass the exam, get more scores, or improve ourselves.
But a soccer team can then be seen as a team. They have a common goal of winning the game. To do this they must have a close relationship, work together seamlessly, and score after many cooperations and combinations.

The difference between goups and teams are, that in a group for example the members of the group doesn't know each other very well and they do their exercises by them selfs and only compare their results and the end. In a team on the other hand the members know each other well, because most of the time they are already working together for some time and they work together on their exercises and they often want the best possible result possible.

Each member of a team has the same goal and cooperates with one another to achieve this common goal for example in a football team every member of the team wants their team to win and they all work together in a structured and cooperative environment to make that happen.
In a group the members share a connection but everyone is focused on themselves and their own goals and ambitions for example in a group of friends they like each other and most likely share some interests but when it comes to achieving their goals everyone will have to work on their own to achieve them.

A group is a simple aggregation of people that are loosely connected but do not share a common goal or necessarily work together.
A team is a group of people that work together in a cordinated way and share a common goal.
Example:
Group: the group of students in a lecture hall, where the students work on their own and may not have a common goal to work together for.
Team: a basketball team, where the members have a common purpose (competing and winnning a match) and work together for achieving that goal.

Group: a number of people loosely connected, not  focus on common purpose/goal: a group of students in a tutorium/lecture.

Team: a number of people strongly connected, work together towards a same goal, complete different tasks for the final outcome:  sport team (football, basketball), Software engineering/ development team

A group of people are loosely connected, so they are not depending on each other. A great example can be golf players, who are playing on their own and not working together with other players.

 On the other hand, the people in a team are strongly connected and working together on a common goal. An example is here a football team, where the players have to collaborate with each other to reach that common goal.

A group is a collection of individuals, who work by themselves.
Teams on the other hand are a collection of people, who through discussion, interaction, negotiation and communication achieve work in a collaborative manner.

In a group this leads to individuals with individuals goals and individual accountability, which leads to individual success or failure. Individual failure can also lead to the group failing.
In a team there are shared goals, which have to be negotiated by the teams. This leads to some overhead in the beginning, which can later be resolved through the collaborative nature of work in a team, which allows a team to reassign work dynamically and finish work in a more parallel and efficient manner. A team can also fail, if the workload shifts to much on individual people, because the effectiveness of a dynamic workload gets exploited in that way.

A "group" of people is no more than the sum of its parts, multiple individuals with little to no connection, usually working sparsely together, if at all. An example would be a random selection of 10 random (willing of course)  students from a University put into a room.

A "team" is a group, but also so much more. A team consists not only of its members, but also the bonds between them and a shared vision and the will to cooperate and reach a common goal. This is only achieved after the members have gotten to know each other and are able and willing to empower another and complement each-others strengths.

Any people can form a group, but not everyone can form a team.

Group is a number of people who are loosely connected that gather together and only focus on their own thing, while a team is a number of people with a common goal that work together in order to achieve this goal.

Groups are people who have some kind of relationship to each other. They are losely connected, dont have a common goal and everybody works on his own things.
A Team is bound to common goals, they work together, and are connected in a way that they rely on each other to work better.

A group is a number of people that are loosely connected even though they have some relationship with one another.  They don't focus on a specific purpose and each person works on their own.

As an example in a tutorial group we normally don't really know each member individually. We have some relationships as a student in that specific module and the same common purpose to join the tutorial class for a better understanding of the material. But every individual works on their own problem. 

While a team is any group of people that have the same activity with a common goal, the participants are strongly connected with each other and focus on specific goals/outcomes.

As an example, in the module Diskrete Strukturen, we may build a group with 4 members to solve our homework together. In this case, we have a common goal together which was passing the minimum score for our Notenbonus, and each week we need to coordinate our tasks and stay strongly connected with each other.

A group is a gathering of people who are connected in some way (e.g. by a joint work project). A team on the other hand is a group of people who work together towards a common goal. Therefore, every team is a group but not every group is a team. 
In a team, every member contributes because everyone wants to achieve the common goal. In a group though there might be people who just lean back and rely on the others to do all the work.
Furthermore, a team works together. Communication and coordination are key. A group on the other hand, does not necessearily work together. They might just each do their own thing without communicationg with the others.

A group is a set of people who are connected, but do not share a common goal or purpose. They connections to oneanother are heterogeneous and they don't work together.
An example for a group are students attending this lecture.

A team knows each others flaws and strengths, works together and shares a common goal/task/activity. They have a strong connection.
An example would be five students working together on the project studies and knowing each other well.

A group is a set of random people who have something/one thing in common. Everyone works only for themselves and not for a general purpose. Thus, the only members have little to do with each other and everyone tries to achieve their own personal goals.
While a team works together. They talk to each other and divide the individual tasks among themselves, preferably in such a way that everyone gets a task that is tailored precisely to their skills. In this way they achieve a common goal, whereby they are also strongly dependent on each other. Either the whole team achieves a goal together or no one achieves one, because there are no individual goals, except maybe to fulfill their task.
Example 1: The TUM Informatik students in an exam (group) - They all have one thing in common, namely the exam, but everyone tries to pass the exam as well as possible.
A team, on the contrary, works together and everyone does their part to achieve a result. So if a team were to write an exam, then either the joint performance would be evaluated, or if an individual performance was recorded, they would prepare together and mutually benefit from the strengths of the others.
Example 2: A team in soccer can only win together, for this the team must firstly be coordinated (a lineup is required), secondly, everyone must fulfill their task in the team and thirdly, the players are highly dependent on each other. Finally, all players are focused on winning the game. If the soccer team were not a team but just a group of soccer players, then everyone would play their favorite position, regardless of whether each position is occupied. It would be uncoordinated as everyone is looking to themselves and trying to do their best individually and there would not be a strong connection between the players.

A Group is a set of people who have one or another relationship.
A Team is a set of people who share a common goal and aid each other in completing their own subgoals.

An Example of a Group would be a class of students.
An Example of a Team would be a soccer team.

A class simply listens to the same lecture, whereas soccer team all have interlinked function, wherein the function of the individual is defined by the rest of the team. The connection between the soccer team is by far stronger than the connection in between the class of students. 
A class does not share a common goal, therefore the effort each student puts into studying varies greatly and individual effort doesn't affect the effort of others. 
But a soccer team shares the common goal of winning a soccer match and to win the match they are required to cooperate and specialize in certain positions to emphasize their individual good attributes and make up for defficiencies.

A group is a loosely related number of people that act independently of one another while a team is an organized group whose members coordinate their activities to achieve a common goal.

For example, in a work environment, a group of people could be tasked to work towards a specific goal together. They might start out as a group if they do no know each other well and have different ideas on how to reach this goal. Over time, they could become a team as they work more smoothly together and have alignment on the tasks each member should do to best complete their goal.

Another less obvious example would be a group of employees with a manager that delegates tasks to each person to achieve some goal. Here, there is no real common goal and only one person is involved in the organization of the group. In contrast, a team would have a leader that facilitates collaboration among the team members rather than dictating how things should be done.

- Definition:
	Group is a number of people that have some relationship to one another
	Team is any group of people involved in the same activity with a common goal, especially referring to sports and work
- Connectedness
	Group participants are loosely connected
	Team members are strongly connected
- Focus:
	Group: no focus on speciﬁc outcomes or a common purpose
	Team: has a focus on a speciﬁc outcome, requires coordination of tasks and activities
- Cooperation:
	Group: Every individual works on his own
	Team: Members need to work together

Example 1: the participants in a football training session form a group. The football team members form a team.
Example 2: the participants on EIST tutorials form a group. The tutors form a teaching team.

For example, a group would be several students in a tutor group, that don't really know each other that well and that have to do the team project, but neither of them wants to do it and they are not really interested in getting a good grade. They also don't communicate, they just do the minimum work on their own no matter what the outcome is. 

On the other hand, a team would be for example a student initiative where students came together with the common goal of developing an application. Their passion for software connects them and they communicate often and exchange ideas in order to successfully launch their application.

As a conclusion you could say that, in a team they have a common goal and in order to reach that goal the team members work together, while in a group they don't really have a goal that connects them and they don't work together.

A team is a set of people that come together to produce something common, in which they interact and work together. A group is a bunch of people that have the same goal, but work independently and without interaction.Giving an example from my own experience would be:
In a basketball team, if you have a group of people, which does not act like a team, it is then individual players trying to step up and not sharing the ball. On the other hand, playing like a team enables to step up as a whole and win together.In a programming context, a group would be a bunch of programmers that implement something without communicating , however a team, would be people that interact and work on a project, where everyone shares the same goal.

A group are a number of people, who dont know each other well and dont have a common goal. They all work on their own.

A Team is a group of people, who share the same goal and know each other strengths and weaknesses. They also work together. A team uses these advantages to outperform a group.

A group of people are a number of people who have a specific relationship to one another but do not chase the same goal, the relationships are not deep and everyone works on his own. A team is a number of people who are strongly connected with each other and chase the same outcome, they work together to get this goal.
As an example a class of students is a group, everyone is studying for their own to get their degree.
As an example a team is a number of soccer players, they train everyday with each other to win a championship together.

A group is just a bunch of people, that are taking part in the same activity. A team is however a group of people that participate in the same activity, but also have the same goal in it that they want to achieve together, e.g. a group of students watching lecture vs a team of 4 students that watch the lecture together and help each other in topics and questions they don't understand in order to get the best results. 

Furthermore, no personal connections are actually developed between group members, whereas team members are strongly connected,  e.g. 2500 Students watching EIST lecture vs 5 Students doing EIST Project.

The difference between groups and teams is the connection the members of both have. In a group, the connection inbetween the members is weaker and there is no strong common goal / motivation, just a simple basic relationship.
In a team its quite the opposite: strong common goal / motivation for achieving the teams aims. More an advanced work relationship.

Examples: 
1. Me and my friends playing video games for fun (group) - An e-sports team playing in a championship (like Worlds First - World of Warcraft (WoW)) (team)
2. A family going on vacation and taking a tour in the mountains with guides (group) - the guides on that tour are a team, working on making it a good experience for the family and getting paid and, which makes it a team: taking care of securtiy and a safe passage through the mountains (team)

Differences:
A group is a loosely connected bunch of people, whereas a team has strong ties between its members. Second, a group is not working on a set goal or common vision/purpose. A team, by contrast,, knows exactly which specific outcome it wants to attain through collaboration. Therefore, everybody in a group is still focused on his/her own work and performance with an individualistic mindset, whereas a team has understood that with good coordination together it can achieve more - a common vision is the guiding star.

Examples: 
Before a football world cup, the individual players are scouted from their club "teams" and thrown into the national "team", which is actually more of a "group" at this stage. Many players have not played together, the connections are loose. Players want to show off their indiviual skills to qualify for the final selection. Then, in the qualification phase leading up to the world cup, the group is growing together more and more  - shaped by the coach and by its own members. It establishes a common vision  and purpose ("we want to win" / "we want to go beyond group stage"). In the final weeks before the world cup, the training intensifies and the coaches place emphasis on strenghtening the idea of team collaboration, where everybody has a specific role going beyond the role on the pitch. Players truly need to work together to compete on the highest level. There was even a documentary about how Germany excelled as a "team" in the 2014 world cup and won despite not having the best individual players.

A second example is actually a personal one: In the TechChallenge course at UnternehmerTUM I met my project members through a virtual matchmaking initiative - initially, we were total strangers to each other. We did not know each other and the only tie was that we had all signed up for this course out of curiosity and to apply some of the theoretical knowledge to practice. Exploring the problem space of food waste in hospitals, we quickly developed a common vision for a software product we could build but it took some time until everybody stopped working on his/her domain of expertise but actually collaborated as a team. The specific outcome we wanted to reach was to win the TechChallenge. By now, we have turned the win into a startup and I would say we have grown from a group into a team and work together very well - even in a remote setting where coordination is key.

A team is a group of people doing their work with a specific purpose and together. They have a joint target that they want to reach and they work together in order to achieve these goals. 
A group on the other hand is just a group of people being thrown together but not exactly having a common goal that they want to reach. Instead they just work together but they don't have a specific result in mind that they want to reach. 

A good example is how people playing soccer is a group of people that just want to have fun together and enjoy the time. This group can be separated in two teams that both share the goal of achieving a goal. Their target is to have more goals at the end of the game in order to win. Here the clear separation of team and group is necessary to understand their targets.

example_solution:
While members of a team work towards the same goal, members of a group work towards their own. In a company we have different departments. Within the departments, all of the employees work in a certain field. However, they do not all have the same tasks. Within the department, there may be smaller teams which are responsible for successfully achieving an assignment. In a software company we might have a group of people who are responsible for the code quality, with a smaller subteam which is responsible for maintaining a certain software.

In addition, the members of a team are closely connected due to being involved in the same activities whereas participants of a group are only loosely connected. While subteams within our software department are closely connected and stay in contact every day, they might not have much contact with colleagues who are not part of any team they work in.

problem_statement:
Explain the differences between groups and teams.

Point out the differences using two examples in your own words.

- up to 2 Points for  2 Examples
- Make sure, that the Examples are about the differences of group and teams, not examples for either group or team.
